revision.text:
{{Infobox convention | name = Torcon 3, the 61st World Science Fiction Convention | image = [[File:61st Worldcon logo.png|200px]] | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]] | location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | country = [[Canada]] | first = August 28-September 1, 2003 | last = | organizer = Toronto World Science Fiction Convention in 2003 | filing = Non-profit | attendance = | website = [http://www.torcon.org/ www.torcon.org] }} '''Torcon 3''' was the 61st [[Worldcon|World Science Fiction Convention]], held in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] on August 28-September 1, 2003. The convention was held in the [[Metro Toronto Convention Centre]], as well as the [[Fairmont Royal York]] and Crowne Plaza (now the InterContinental Toronto Centre) hotels. Torcon 3 was also the site of the 2003 [[Canvention]]. ==Guests== *[[George R. R. Martin]] (pro) *[[Frank Kelly Freas]] (artist), unable to attend due to illness *[[Mike Glyer]] (fan) *[[Spider Robinson]] (toastmaster) *[[Robert Bloch]] (GoHst of honor) ==Awards== {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== This was the first time that the 'Best Dramatic Presentation, Long Form' and 'Best Dramatic Presentation, Short Form' awards were presented as separate categories. *Best Novel: ''Hominids'' by [[Robert J. Sawyer]] *Best Novella: ''[[Coraline]]'' by [[Neil Gaiman]] *Best Novelette: "Slow Life" by [[Michael Swanwick]] *Best Short Story: "Falling Onto Mars" by [[Geoffrey A. Landis]] *Best Related Book: ''Better to Have Loved: The Life of Judith Merril'' by [[Judith Merril]] and Emily Pohl-Weary *Best Dramatic Presentation, Long Form: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers]]'' *Best Dramatic Presentation, Short Form: "[[Conversations with Dead People]]", ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' *Best Professional Editor: [[Gardner Dozois]] *Best Professional Artist: [[Bob Eggleton]] *Best Semiprozine: [[Locus (magazine)|Locus]] *Best Fanzine: [[Mimosa (magazine)|Mimosa]] *Best Fan Writer: [[David Langford]] *Best Fan Artist: Sue Mason ===Other awards=== *[[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]]: [[Wen Spencer]] ====Prix Aurora Awards==== *Best Long-Form Work in English: ''Permanence'' by [[Karl Schroeder]] *Best Long-Form Work in French: ''Le Revenant de Fomalhaut'' by Jean-Louis Trudel *Best Short-Form Work in English: "Ineluctable" by [[Robert J. Sawyer]] *Best Short-Form Work in French: ''"La Guerre sans temps"'', [[Sylvie Bérard]] *Best Work in English (Other): ''Be VERY Afraid!'' by [[Edo van Belkom]] *Artistic Achievement: Mel Vavaroutsos *Fan Achievement (Publication): ''Made in Canada Newsletter'', Don Bassie, ed. [webzine] *Fan Achievement (Organizational): Georgina Miles ([[Toronto Trek]] 16) *Fan Achievement (Other): [[Jason Taniguchi]], one-man SF parody shows ==Information== ===Site selection=== Two site selection votes were held at Torcon 3. *Los Angeles won the vote for the [[64th World Science Fiction Convention]] in 2006. *[[Seattle]] won the vote for the [[8th North American Science Fiction Convention]] in 2005. ===Notable program participants=== (in addition to guests of honor listed above) {|width=80% |valign="top" align="left" width=33%| *[[Stephanie Bedwell-Grime]] *[[Russell Blackford]] *[[David Brin]] *[[Jack L. Chalker]] *[[Hal Clement]] *[[John Clute]] *[[Julie Czerneda]] *[[Ellen Datlow]] *[[Cory Doctorow]] *[[Candas Jane Dorsey]] *[[Sheila Finch]] *[[Esther Friesner]] *[[Neil Gaiman]] *[[James Alan Gardner]] *[[Elizabeth Hand]] |valign="top" width=33%| *[[Harry Harrison (writer)|Harry Harrison]] *[[Nalo Hopkinson]] *[[Tanya Huff]] *[[James Patrick Kelly]] *[[Ellen Klages]] *[[Nancy Kress]] *[[Geoffrey A. Landis]] *[[Paul Levinson]] *[[Jacqueline Lichtenberg]] *[[China Miéville]] *[[Steve Miller (writer)|Steve Miller]] *[[Elizabeth Moon]] *[[Larry Niven]] *[[Fiona Patton]] *[[Frederik Pohl]] |valign="top" width=33%| *[[Terry Pratchett]] *[[Eric Raymond]] *[[Mike Resnick]] *[[Robert J. Sawyer]] *[[Stanley Schmidt]] *[[Mark Shainblum]] *[[Charles Stross]] *[[Cecilia Tan]] *[[Michelle Sagara West]] *[[Liz Williams]] *[[Walter Jon Williams]] *[[Connie Willis]] *[[Robert Charles Wilson]] *[[Sarah Zettel]] |} ===Committee=== *Chair: Peter Jarvis *Vice-chair: Ken Smookler ====Division heads==== *Programming: Terry Fong *Finance/Legal: Larry Hancock, Ken Smookler *Facilities: Murray Moore *Operations: Robbie Bourget *Events: Kathryn Grimbly-Bethke *Exhibits: Elaine Brennan *Communications: Michelle Boyce *Administration: Kent Bloom *Member Services: Lance Sibley ====Board of directors==== *President: Ken Smookler *Directors: Peter Jarvis, Larry Hancock, Murray Moore, Jody Dix, Linda Ross-Mansfield, Hope Leibowitz ====Bid==== *Bid Chair: Larry Hancock ==See also== *[[Prix Aurora Awards]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web|work=The Hugo Awards |title=2003 Hugo Awards |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/2003-hugo-awards/ |accessdate=February 28, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407144122/http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/2003-hugo-awards/ |archivedate=April 7, 2015 }} {{cite news |first=Cynthia |last=Lee |work=Toronto Star |title=GTA writer wins sci-fi prize |page=A.02 |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/648535241.html?dids=648535241:648535241&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+31%2C+2003&author=Cynthia+Lee&pub=Toronto+Star&desc=GTA+writer+wins+sci-fi+prize&pqatl=google |date=August 31, 2003 |accessdate=February 10, 2010}} }} ==External links== *[http://www.torcon3.info/ Official website] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[60th World Science Fiction Convention]]
ConJose in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], United States (2002) | title=[[List of Worldcons]] | years='''61st World Science Fiction Convention'''
Torcon 3 in [[Toronto]], Canada (2003) | after=[[62nd World Science Fiction Convention]]
Noreascon 4 in [[Boston]], United States (2004) }} {{s-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 061}} [[Category:2003 in Ontario]] [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:Science fiction conventions in Canada]] [[Category:2003 conferences]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Olympic bid|2020|Summer| | main = yes | Paralympics = yes |logo = |logo-size = 200x |winner = Tokyo |votes1 = 60 |runner-up = Istanbul |votes2 = 36 |shortlisted1 = Madrid |1stBid = 1 September 2011 |decision = 7 September 2013 }} {{2020 Summer Olympics}} There were a total of six bids which were initially submitted for the [[2020 Summer Olympics]]. [[Tokyo]] was ultimately elected as the host city at the [[125th IOC Session]] in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]], on 7 September 2013.
==Bidding process== The Olympic bidding process begins with the submission of a city's application to the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) by its [[National Olympic Committee]] (NOC) and ends with the election of the host city by the members of the IOC during an ordinary session. The process is governed by the [[Olympic Charter]], as stated in Chapter 5, Rule 34.<ref name="Charter">{{cite book | url = http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_122.pdf | title = Olympic Charter | publisher = International Olympic Committee |accessdate = 2008-06-04 | date = 1 September 2004 | format = PDF | isbn = 92-9149-001-6 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080609022618/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_122.pdf| archivedate= 9 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Since 1999, the process has consisted of two phases. During the first phase, which begins immediately after the bid submission deadline, the "applicant cities" are required to answer a questionnaire covering themes of importance to a successful Games organization. This information allows the IOC to analyze the cities' hosting capacities and the strengths and weaknesses of their plans. Following a detailed study of the submitted questionnaires and ensuing reports, the IOC Executive Board selects the cities that are qualified to proceed to the next phase. The second phase is the true candidature stage: the accepted applicant cities (from now on referred to as "candidate cities") are required to submit a second questionnaire in the form of an extended, more detailed, candidature file.<ref name="CityElectionProc">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/missions/cities_uk.asp | title = Host City Election Procedure | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080619122311/http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/missions/cities_uk.asp| archivedate= 19 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> These files are carefully studied by the IOC Evaluation Commission, a group composed of IOC members, representatives of [[List of international sport federations|international sport federations]], NOCs, athletes, the [[International Paralympic Committee]], and international experts in various fields.<ref name="EvalCommis">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/commission_uk.asp | title = Role and composition of the Evaluation Commission | work = 117th IOC Session | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080613200643/http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/commission_uk.asp| archivedate= 13 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> It is chaired by Sir [[Craig Reedie]]. The members of the Evaluation Commission then make four-day inspection visits to each of the candidate cities, where they check the proposed venues and are briefed about details of the themes covered in the candidature file. The Evaluation Commission communicates the results of its inspections in a report sent to the IOC members up to one month before the electing IOC Session.<ref name="CityElectionProc"/>
The IOC Session in which a host city is elected takes place in a country that did not submit an application to stage the Olympics.<ref name="CityElectionProc"/> The election is made by the assembled active IOC members (excluding honorary and honor members), each possessing one vote. Members from countries that have a city taking part in the election cannot vote while the city is in the running. The voting is conducted in a succession of rounds until one bid achieves an [[absolute majority]] of votes; if this does not happen in the first round, the bid with the fewest votes is eliminated and another voting round begins. In the case of a tie for the lowest number of votes, a special runoff vote is carried out, with the winner proceeding to the next round. After each round, the eliminated bid is announced.<ref name="ElectionProc">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/utilities/faq_detail_uk.asp?rdo_cat=24_55_0 | title = FAQ – Election of an Olympic Games Host City – Host city election | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080717043751/http://www.olympic.org/uk/utilities/faq_detail_uk.asp?rdo_cat=24_55_0| archivedate= 17 July 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="SingElectionProc">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/election_uk.asp | title = Election procedure | work = 117th IOC Session | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080601234735/http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/election_uk.asp| archivedate= 1 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Following the announcement of the host city, the successful bid delegation signs the "Host City Contract" with the IOC, which delegates the responsibilities of the Games organisation to the city and respective NOC.<ref name="HostCityContract">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/ocog/index_uk.asp | title = The Organizing Committees of the Olympic Games | work = The Movement | publisher = International Olympic Committee |accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080606065920/http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/ocog/index_uk.asp| archivedate= 6 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Bidding timeline===
The timeline of the host city selection process was approved by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) executive board as follows:<ref name="olympic.org">[http://www.olympic.org/content/press-release/six-applicant-cities-for-the-2020-olympic-games/ Six Applicant Cities for the 2020 Olympic Games] – 2 September 2011 – ''[[International Olympic Committee]]''</ref><ref name="ioc" >[http://www.olympic.org/media?articleid=112731&articlenewsgroup=-1 Executive Board concludes first meeting of the new year] 13 January 2011.</ref>
*'''2011''': :'''16 May''' – IOC sent letters inviting the National Olympic Committees (NOCs) to submit bids :'''July and August''' – IOC asked for NOCs to submit letters regarding compliance with the World Anti-doping Agency code by 29 July. The IOC also requested submissions of proposed dates if countries want to stage the Games outside the normal period set by the IOC (15 July to 31 August). The IOC responded to NOCs on these points by the end of August. :'''1 September''' – Deadline to submit the names of cities interested in hosting the 2020 Summer Games :'''2 September''' – IOC confirmed that they had received six bids :'''3–4 November''' – IOC held an information seminar for 2020 applicants :'''8 December''' – IOC announced the drawing lots order of applicant cities *'''2012:''' :'''15 February''' – application files and guarantee letters submitted to the IOC :'''23 May''' – IOC executive board in [[Quebec City]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://host321.evolutra.com/csta/index_e.aspx?DetailID=658 |title=SportAccord Convention 2012 Awarded to Québec City |work=Canadian Sport Tourism Alliance (CSTA) |accessdate=27 March 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120711062402/http://host321.evolutra.com/csta/index_e.aspx?DetailID=658 |archive-date=11 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> decided which cities were to be approved as official candidate cities<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aroundtherings.com/articles/view.aspx?id=38370 |title=2020 Olympic Bids Huddle With IOC |publisher=Aroundtherings.com |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref> :'''27 July – 12 August''' – Olympic Games Observers’ Programme at the [[2012 Summer Olympics|Games of the XXX Olympiad]] in [[London]] :''' 14–21 November''' – 2012 Olympic Games debrief in [[Rio de Janeiro]] *'''2013:''' :'''7 January''' – Candidature Files Submitted<ref>[http://www.olympic.org/news/2020-candidate-cities-deliver-candidature-files/187656 2020 Candidate Cities deliver Candidature Files]</ref> :'''4–7 March''' – IOC Evaluation Commission visited Tokyo :'''18–21 March''' – IOC Evaluation Commission visited Madrid :'''24–27 March''' – IOC Evaluation Commission visited Istanbul :'''25 June''' – Report of the IOC evaluation commission<ref>[http://www.olympic.org/news/ioc-releases-2020-evaluation-commission-report/201526 IOC releases 2020 Evaluation Commission Report]</ref> :'''3–4 July''' – Candidate cities briefing to IOC Members at Extraordinary session in [[Lausanne]]<ref>[http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/1014470-ioc-presidential-candidates-to-present-to-session-in-lausanne-this-july IOC Presidential candidates to present to Session in Lausanne this July]</ref> :'''7 September''' – Election of the host city at [[125th IOC Session]] in [[Buenos Aires]]<ref>[http://www.buenosaires2013.com/index.php COI - 125th Session] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906053440/http://www.buenosaires2013.com/index.php |date=2013-09-06 }}</ref>
===Evaluation of applicant cities===
Six cities were put forward by their respective [[National Olympic Committee]]s (NOCs) to apply to host the Games initially, but Rome withdrew its bid shortly before the applicant files were due.<ref>[http://www.olympic.org/content/press-release/six-applicant-cities-for-the-2020-olympic-games/ Six Applicant Cities for the 2020 Olympic Games] – ''[[International Olympic Committee]]'' press release – 2 September 2011</ref> The bidding cities come from two continents, Europe and Asia (Istanbul is considered to be located on the border between Asia and Europe). In 2020 it will be twelve years since an Asian city hosted the Summer Olympics ([[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing 2008]]) and eight years since a European city hosted the Summer Olympics ([[2012 Summer Olympics|London 2012]]). Out of the six bidders, Tokyo had previously hosted the Summer Olympic Games in [[1964 Summer Olympics|1964]]. The other four bidders have made bids in the past. It is the first time in 20 years that no city in the Americas bid to host the Summer Olympic Games. [[Rio de Janeiro]] was awarded the [[2016 Summer Olympics]]. Baku and Doha bid for the 2016 Games but failed to become candidate cities, while Tokyo and Madrid also bid for the 2016 Games and became candidate cities.

#ffd5e5" | 5.0 | style="background: #d5e5ff" | 8.0 |- |} </center> ===Final selection process===
{{main article|125th IOC Session}} The IOC voted to select the host city of the 2020 Summer Olympics on 7 September 2013 at the [[125th IOC Session]] at the [[Buenos Aires Hilton]] in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. An [[exhaustive ballot]] system was used. No city won over 50% of the votes in the first round, and Madrid and Istanbul were tied for second place. A run-off vote between these two cities was held to determine which would be eliminated. In the final vote, a head-to-head contest between Tokyo and Istanbul, Tokyo was selected by 60 votes to 36 votes.
{{2020 Olympic host city election}} ==Bidding cities== The candidate cities for the 2020 Olympics are, in order of drawing lots:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/about-ioc-institution?articlenewsgroup=-1&articleid=149098 |title=Games organisers present activity reports to IOC Executive Board |publisher=Olympic.org |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Sunset over Shinjuku.jpg|thumb|right|Sunset in [[Shinjuku]]]] [[File:Shibuya District at Night 2015-04 (17806976882).jpg|thumb|right|[[Shibuya]] at night]] [[File:Bosphorus.jpg|thumb|right|View of the [[Bosphorus]] in Istanbul]] [[File:Calle de Alcalá (Madrid) 16.jpg|thumb|right|[[Calle de Alcalá|Alcalá Street]] and the [[Metropolis Building]]]] === Candidate cities === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- ! style="background-color: #BFD7FF" width="20%" | City ! style="background-color: #BFD7FF" width="20%" | Country ! style="background-color: #BFD7FF" width="40%" | National Olympic Committee ! style="background-color: #BFD7FF" width="20%" | Result |- ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | '''[[Tokyo]]''' ! scope="row" | {{Flag|Japan}} ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | [[Japanese Olympic Committee]] (JOC) ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | Winner |- | colspan="4" style="text-align: left" | {{further information|Tokyo bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics}} [[Tokyo]] was selected by the [[Japanese Olympic Committee]] on 16 July 2011, and was confirmed as Japan's bidding city for the 2020 Games.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/15/olympics-tokyo-bid-idUSL3E7IF1XH20110715 | work=Reuters | first=Alastair | last=Himmer | title=Olympics-Tokyo tiptoes into 2020 bid race | date=15 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110716x1.html |title=JOC launches bid for 2020 Olympics on centennial day | The Japan Times Online |work=Japan Times |date=17 July 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref> [[Hiroshima]] was considering making a bid for the games but opted to pull out following poor public reaction to the bid as well as a lack of funding.<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/future_bids_2016/1216135715.html "Hiroshima Opts Out Of 2020 Olympic Bid"]. GamesBids.com, 22 May 2011.</ref>
Tokyo hosted the [[1964 Summer Olympics]]. Japan has also hosted the [[Winter Olympics]] in [[1972 Winter Olympics|1972]] and [[1998 Winter Olympics|1998]] which were organized in [[Sapporo]] and [[Nagano, Nagano|Nagano]] respectively. Japan previously co-hosted the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]] with [[South Korea]]; the final was held in [[Yokohama]], near Tokyo. Further, Japan hosted the [[2006 FIBA World Championship]]. In 2011, the Gymnastics World Championships were also held in Tokyo. Japan will host the [[2019 Rugby World Cup]] and two of the venues for the event are located in the [[Greater Tokyo Area]]. |- ! colspan="6" style="background-color: #BFD7FF" | |- ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | '''[[Istanbul]]''' ! scope="row" | {{Flag|Turkey}} ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | [[Turkish Olympic Committee]] (TMOK) ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | First runner-up |- | colspan="4" style="text-align: left" | {{further information|Istanbul bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics}} [[Istanbul]] was nominated on 7 July 2011, at the 123rd [[IOC]] session, and was confirmed as Turkey's bid on 24 July 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insidethegames.biz/olympics/summer-olympics/2020/13679-turkey-prime-minister-confirms-istanbul-bid-for-2020-olympics |title=Turkey Prime Minister confirms Istanbul bid for 2020 Olympics | 2020 Summer Olympics |publisher=insidethegames.biz |date=24 July 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/future_bids_2016/1216135804.html |title=Istanbul To Bid Again – This Time For 2020 Summer Games |access-date=2011-07-21 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/663fdr0yX?url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/future_bids_2016/1216135804.html |archive-date=2012-03-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Istanbul hosted the [[2005 UEFA Champions League Final]], [[2009 UEFA Cup Final]] and [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in [[association football|football]], the [[2010 FIBA World Championship]] for Men, the [[Euroleague 2011–12 Final Four]] in [[basketball]], the [[WTA Tour Championships]] in [[tennis]], the [[2012 FINA World Swimming Championships (25 m)]], and the [[2012 IAAF World Indoor Championships]] in [[track and field|athletics]]. Istanbul will host the [[2013 WTA Tour Championships]], the [[2014 FIBA World Championship for Women]], and is considering a bid for the [[2032 Summer Olympics]]. |- ! colspan="6" style="background-color: #BFD7FF" | |- ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | '''[[Madrid]]''' ! scope="row" | {{Flag|Spain}} ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | [[Spanish Olympic Committee]] (COE) ! style="text-align:center" scope="row" | Second runner-up |- | colspan="4" style="text-align: left" | {{further information|Madrid bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics}} [[Madrid]] was nominated by the [[Spanish Olympic Committee]] executive committee on 1 June 2011.<ref name=Madrid2020>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/local/madrid/20110601/54163909960/jj-la-ejecutiva-del-coe-aprobaria-la-candidatura-de-madrid-2020.html |title=La Ejecutiva del COE aprobaría la candidatura de Madrid 2020 |publisher=La Vanguardia |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=13 June 2011 |language=Spanish }}</ref> Madrid's 2020 bid was their [[Bids for Olympic Games|third consecutive bid]]. Spain previously hosted the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] at Barcelona.
Spain hosted the [[1982 FIFA World Cup]] and the [[1982 FIFA World Cup Final|final]] was held in Madrid. It has also hosted the final of [[UEFA Champions League|European Champions League]] ([[1956–57 European Cup|1957]], [[1968–69 European Cup|1969]], [[1979–80 European Cup|1980]], [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League|2010]]); the final of [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] ([[1984–85 UEFA Cup|1985]], [[1985–86 UEFA Cup|1986]]); final of the [[FIBA EuroBasket]] (several times); 1974 [[EuroHockey Nations Championship]]; [[European Judo Championships]] ([[1965 European Judo Championships|1965]], [[1973 European Judo Championships|1973]], [[1981 European Judo Championships|1981]]); [[2005 UCI Road World Championships]]; [[European Karate Championships]] (1983, 1986); [[2005 World Taekwondo Championships]]; [[2002 IAAF World Cup|2002 World Cup in Athletics]]; [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]] ([[1960 Intercontinental Cup|1960]], [[1966 Intercontinental Cup|1966]], [[1974 Intercontinental Cup|1974]]); [[2004 European Aquatics Championships]]; [[1964 European Nations' Cup]]; [[2003 FIVB Volleyball World League]]; [[European Athletics Indoor Championships]] ([[1968 European Indoor Games|1968]], [[1986 European Athletics Indoor Championships|1986]], [[2005 European Athletics Indoor Championships|2005]]); [[UCI Mountain Bike World Cup]] (every year); [[WTA Tour Championships]] ([[2006 WTA Tour Championships|2006]], [[2007 WTA Tour Championships|2007]]); [[Spanish International Badminton Tournament]] (every year); [[1986 World Aquatics Championships]] and several other. Spain hosted the [[1986 FIBA World Championship]] and hosted the [[2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup]]; the 2014 final match was held at the [[Palacio de Deportes de la Comunidad de Madrid|Palacio de los Deportes de la Comunidad de Madrid]] in Madrid. |- ! colspan="6" style="background-color: #BFD7FF" | |}
===Non-selected applicant cities===
*{{flagicon|AZE}} '''[[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]]''' [[File:Baku Targov.JPG|thumb|200px|right|View of [[Nizami Street]] in Baku]]
{{further information|Baku bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics}} It was announced at the 1 September 2011 deadline for bidding that [[Baku]] had submitted a bid to host the 2020 Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|title=Azerbaijan bids for 2020 Olympics in Baku|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=oly&id=6915971|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref> Baku submitted their application file to the IOC on 1 February 2012.<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2020_bid_news/1216136069.html Azerbaijan Submits Baku 2020 Bid Application To IOC]</ref> The [[National Assembly of Azerbaijan]] voted to endorse the bid in February 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2020_bid_news/1216136077.html |title=Azerbaijani Parliament Supports Baku 2020 |publisher=Gamesbids.com |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref> Baku hosted the [[2015 European Games]]. ----
*{{flagicon|QAT}} '''[[Doha]], [[Qatar]]'''
{{further information|Doha bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics}} On 26 August 2011, [[Doha]] announced that it was bidding for the 2020 Games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dohastadiumplusqatar.com/doha-launches-bid-2020-olympics |title=Doha launches bid for 2020 Olympics | Doha Stadium Plus |publisher=Dohastadiumplusqatar.com |accessdate=5 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323173350/http://www.dohastadiumplusqatar.com/doha-launches-bid-2020-olympics/ |archive-date=23 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=<!--[if IE 6]> <![endif]--> |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/26/164219.html |title=Qatar’s Doha officially launches bid for 2020 Olympics |publisher=English.alarabiya.net |date=26 August 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111200409/http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/26/164219.html |archive-date=2012-01-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Doha hosted the [[2006 Asian Games]] and the [[2011 Pan Arab Games]]. In 2010, Qatar was selected to host the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]]. Several stadiums will be located in Doha. The country also hosted the [[1988 AFC Asian Cup|1988]] and [[2011 AFC Asian Cup]]s. ----
===Cancelled bid===
*{{flagicon|ITA}} [[Rome]], [[Italy]] [[File:Rzym Oltarz Ojczyzny.jpg|thumb|200px|right|View of Vittorio Emmanuele II Monument in Rome]]
{{further information|Rome bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics}} [[Rome]] was nominated by the [[Italian National Olympic Committee]] on 19 May 2010. Italy's capital city was chosen over [[Venice]] as the country's bid for the 2020 Games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/future_bids_2016/1216135186.html |title=Rome Is Italy's Candidate In 2020 Summer Games Bid |publisher=GamesBids.com |accessdate=2 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.2020roma.it/public/it/news.php?page=6&ipp=4&n=87 |title=ROMA 2020 – Sala Stampa e News – News |publisher=2020roma.it |accessdate=2 May 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Rome previously hosted the Summer Olympics in [[1960 Summer Olympics|1960]] and was chosen to host the [[1908 Summer Olympics]], but was relocated to [[London]] due to the 1906 eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]]. It bid to host the [[2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Games]] but lost to [[Athens]] in the final round of voting. Rome hosted the [[2009 World Aquatics Championships]] as well as the [[1990 FIFA World Cup Final]]. Italy previously hosted the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] in [[Turin]] and the [[1956 Winter Olympics]] in [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]].
However the Rome municipal administration withdrew its support from the bid on the eve of the delivery of the application files, stating that it would not be a responsible use of money in "Italy's current condition."<ref name="Rome Olympic bid Scrapped">{{cite web|last=Simpson|first=Victor|title=Rome's 2020 Olympic bid scrapped by Monti|url=http://sports.sympatico.ca/news/romes_2020_olympic_bid_scrapped_by_monti/ec43469d|accessdate=14 February 2012}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

web|url=http://esporte.uol.com.br/outros/ultimas/2004/11/27/ult807u683.jhtm |title=Lisbon 2016 or 2020 |publisher=Esporte.uol.com.br |date=27 November 2004 |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://dn.sapo.pt/inicio/interior.aspx?content_id=630340 |title=Artificial island in plans for 2020 Lisbon bid |publisher=Dn.sapo.pt |accessdate=5 March 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://risco4.wordpress.com/2005/05/01/objectivo-lisboa-2020/ |title=Ojective: Lisbon 2020 |publisher=Risco4.wordpress.com |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref>
The following cities proposed submitting bids but announced prior to the 1 September deadline that they would not put forth a bid. The following list is in order of cancellation:
*{{flagicon|CZE}} [[Prague]], Czech Republic, cancelled its bid because of the [[Late-2000s financial crisis|global financial crisis]].<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/future_bids_2016/1216134440.html "It’s Official – Prague Out Of 2020 Bid"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100910085801/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/future_bids_2016/1216134440.html |date=10 September 2010 }}. GamesBids.com, 16 June 2009.</ref> *{{flagicon|ROU}} [[Bucharest]], Romania, decided not to proceed with its bid because the city hall's general counsellors believed the project would be unachievable.<ref>[http://english.hotnews.ro/stiri-bucharest-8137979-bucharest-will-not-host-the-summer-olympic-games-2020-general-counsellors-rejected-the-project.htm "Bucharest will not host the Summer Olympic Games in 2020 / General counsellors rejected the project"]. HotNews.ro, 17 December 2010.</ref> *{{flagicon|KOR}} [[Busan]], South Korea, decided not to bid following [[Pyeongchang County|Pyeongchang]]'s successful bid for the [[2018 Winter Olympics]]. They are, however, planning to bid for the [[2028 Summer Olympics]].<ref>[https://af.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idAFJOE76609J20110707?feedType=RSS&feedName=sportsNews "S.Korea's Busan pulls plug on 2020 Games bid"]. [[Reuters]] Africa, 7 July 2011.</ref> *{{flagicon|FRA}} [[Paris]], France, was eventually selected to host the [[2024 Summer Olympics|2024 Olympic Games]], as France pulled out of the 2020 bid following the defeat of [[Annecy]]'s [[Annecy bid for the 2018 Winter Olympics|bid]] for the [[2018 Winter Olympics]]. 2024 will coincide with the 100th anniversary of the [[1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Olympics]] which were held in the French capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2011-07-12-2785855112_x.htm |title=France rules out 2020 Olympic Games bid, USA Today, 12 July 2011 |work=USA Today |date=12 July 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref> *{{flagicon|UAE}} [[Dubai]], United Arab Emirates, was considering a bid for 2020 but decided to instead wait until [[2024 Summer Olympics|2024]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/29/olympics-emirates-dubai-idUSL3E7IT28F20110729 "Olympics—Dubai opts out of 2020 bid, targets 2024"]. [[Reuters]], 29 July 2011.</ref> *{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada, had long considered a bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics, especially after their successful bid for the [[2015 Pan American Games]], but announced on 11 August 2011 that the idea will be dropped due to budgetary restrictions.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2011/08/11/toronto-olympics.html "Toronto won't bid for 2020 Olympics"]. [[CBC News]], 11 August 2011.</ref> *{{flagicon|RSA}} [[Durban]], South Africa, was discussed as a potential bid, however it was announced on 17 August 2011, that South Africa would not put forth a 2020 bid.<ref>{{cite web |author=Lelo Mzaca |url=http://www.eyewitnessnews.co.za/Story.aspx?Id=72249 |title=Mbalula drops 2020 Olympics bid |publisher=Eyewitness News |date=17 August 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2012 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia, decided not to bid despite having discussed the plan with the head of the Russian Olympic Committee. They withdrew on 22 August 2011, instead planning on bidding for either [[2024 Summer Olympics|2024]] or [[2028 Summer Olympics|2028]].<ref>{{cite web|script-title=ru:Петербург решил не претендовать на проведение Олимпиады-2020|url=http://www.rosbalt.ru/piter/2011/08/22/881672.html|publisher=Rosbalt.ru|accessdate=22 August 2011|language=Russian}}</ref> *{{flagicon|USA}} Multiple cities in the United States were interested in bidding, but the [[USOC]] confirmed that the US would not bid, citing an ongoing dispute with the IOC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=oly&id=6884167 |title=US pulls out of bid for 2020 Summer Olympics – Olympics – ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=22 August 2011 |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2020_bid_news/1216135855.html |title=USOC confirms – United States won't bid for 2020 Olympics |publisher=GamesBids.com |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref> The IOC stated that it would like to have received a bid for 2020 from the United States.<ref name="USA Out">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics/14676969.stm |work=BBC News | title=IOC ponders 2020 autumn Olympics | date=26 August 2011}}</ref> On 29 August 2011, it was revealed that [[Las Vegas]] submitted a bid to the IOC without USOC consent. The IOC rejected the bid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2020_bid_news/1216135866.html |title=Exclusive: Las Vegas submitted 2020 Olympic bid to IOC without USOC Concurrence |publisher=GamesBids.com |accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Books-A-Million Inc. | logo = File:Books-A-Million_logo.svg | type = [[Private company]] | traded_as = | foundation = {{Start date and age|1917}} in [[Florence, Alabama]] | founder = Clyde W. Anderson | hq_location = [[Birmingham, Alabama]] | locations = 260 | key_people = {{nowrap| Clyde B. Anderson, [[Chairman]]
Terrance G. Finley, [[CEO]] & [[President (corporate title)|President]]
R. Todd Noden, [[CFO]]}} | revenue = {{increase}} $474.084 million (2014) | operating_income = {{increase}} $4.619 million (2014) | net_income = {{increase}} $2.908 million (2014) | assets = {{decrease}} $294.251 million (2014) | equity = {{increase}} $113.264 million (2014) | num_employees = 5,400 (2014) |subsid = [[Yogurt Mountain]] (40%) | industry = [[Retail]]
[[Entertainment]]| | homepage = {{URL|http://www.booksamillion.com/}} | footnotes = {{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/891919/000089191915000011/bamm-4162015x10k.htm | title=Books-A-Million Inc. 2014 Form 10-K Annual Report | publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}} }} [[File:HoustonPavilionsHoustonTX.JPG|thumb|Books-A-Million in [[Houston Pavilions]], [[Downtown Houston]]]] [[File:Books-A-Million in Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio.jpg|thumb|A Books-A-Million store in [[Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio]]]] '''Books-A-Million, Inc.''', also known as '''BAM!''', owns and operates the second largest bookstore chain in the United States, operating 260 stores in 32 states.{{cite web | url=http://www.booksamillion.com/aboutus | title=Books-A-Million: About Us | publisher=Books-A-Million}} Stores range in size from 4,000 to 30,000 square feet and sell books, magazines, collectibles, toys, technology, and gifts. Most Books-A-Million stores feature "Joe Muggs" [[cafés]], a coffee and espresso bar. Stores operate under the names Books-A-Million, Bookland, Books & Company, and 2nd & Charles.{{cite press release | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20151210006077/en/Books-A-Million-Completes-Go-Private-Transaction | title=Books-A-Million, Inc. Completes Go-Private Transaction | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=December 10, 2015}} The company owns Yogurt Mountain Holding, a [[frozen yogurt]] retailer and franchisor with 40 locations. The company also owns Preferred Growth Properties, which develops and manages commercial real estate investments. The company also owns and operates American Wholesale Book Company (AWBC), an e-commerce division operating as booksamillion.com, and an internet development and services company, NetCentral, in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. In December 2015, the company was acquired by its chairman, Clyde B. Anderson, and his family, for $21 million.{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/books-a-million-in-21-million-buyout-deal-with-chairman-1436833186 | title=Books-A-Million in $21 Million Buyout Deal With Chairman | first=Josh | last=Beckerman | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=July 13, 2015}}{{subscription required}} ==History== Books-A-Million was founded in 1917 in [[Florence, Alabama]] as a newsstand by 14-year old Clyde B. Anderson, who dropped out of school to support his family after his father died.{{cite web | url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/h-1619 | title=Books-A-Million | first=Herbert Jim | last=Lewis | publisher=[[Encyclopedia of Alabama]]}} Anderson saw a business opportunity after workers on the nearby [[Wilson Dam]] complained that they could not get their hometown newspapers. In 1950, Charles C. Anderson, the founder's son, inherited the store and expanded it into a chain. The company incorporated as Bookland in 1964. By 1980, the company had 50 stores. In 1988, Bookland acquired the Gateway Books retail chain based in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]]. The same year, the company opened its first superstore format store. In 1992, the company changed its name to Books-A-Million, Inc. and became a [[public company]] via an [[initial public offering]] of 2.6 million shares at a price of $13 per share.{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZXUOASHVf_YC&pg=PA170 | title=How Net Fever Sent Shares of a Firm on a 3 Day Joy Ride | first1=Carrick | last1=Mollencamp | first2=Karen | last2=Lundergaard | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=December 9, 1998}} In 1998, the company launched its [[website]], booksamillion.com. On November 25, 1998, during the [[dot-com bubble]], the stock price soared from $3 per share to $38.94 on November 27, 1998 and an intra-day high of $47.00 on November 30, 1998 after the company announced an updated website. Two weeks later, the share price was back down to $10. By 2000, the share price had returned to $3. Those days included suspenseful times for [[day trader]]s, such as when the stock moved up 6 points in 13 minutes. During this time, insiders sold hundreds of thousands of shares.{{cite web | title=CNNfn market movers | url=http://money.cnn.com/1998/11/25/markets/hotstox2p/ | work=[[CNNMoney]] | date=November 25, 1998}} In 1999, the company acquired NetCentral, the designer of its website, and began operating American Wholesale Book Company, a book wholesaler and distributor. In April 2010, the company paid $3 million for a 40% stake in [[Yogurt Mountain]], a [[frozen yogurt]] retailer and franchisor.{{cite news | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/birmingham/stories/2010/04/12/daily48.html | title=Books-A-Million paid $3M for Yogurt Mountain stake | first=Jimmy | last=DeButts | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=April 16, 2010}} In October 2010, the company opened Yogurt Mountain locations in its bookstores.{{cite news | url=http://www.theledger.com/news/20101025/yogurt-mountain-coming-soon-to-books-a-million | title=Yogurt Mountain Coming Soon to Books-a-Million | first=Sarah | last=Stegall | work=[[The Ledger]] | date=October 25, 2010}} In September 2010, the company launched 2nd & Charles, a trader of used media, with its first store in [[Hoover, Alabama]] across from [[Riverchase Galleria]].{{cite news | url=http://blog.al.com/businessnews/2010/09/new_idea_in_used_books_2nd_and.html | title=New idea in used books: 2nd and Charles opens with recycling theme | first=Dawn | last=Kent Azok | work=[[The Birmingham News]] | date=September 25, 2010}} In 2017, it opened its first store in [[North Alabama]].{{cite news | url=http://www.al.com/business/index.ssf/2017/05/books-a-million_division_2nd_c.html | title=Books-A-Million division 2nd & Charles opening store soon in Madison | first=Lucy | last=Berry | work=[[The Birmingham News]] | date=May 9, 2017}} In December 2015, the company was acquired by its chairman, Clyde B. Anderson, and his family, for $21 million.{{cite news | url=http://www.al.com/business/index.ssf/2015/07/books-a-million_private_again.html | title=Books-A-Million may go private again: Anderson family buying company, pending shareholder approval | first=Kelly | last=Poe | work=[[The Birmingham News]] | date=July 13, 2015}} In November 2016, the company began to sell [[Self-publishing|self-published]] books.{{cite news | url=http://www.al.com/business/index.ssf/2016/11/books-a-million_distributing_s.html | title=Books-A-Million to begin selling self-published books | first=Kelly | last=Poe | work=[[The Birmingham News]] | date=November 4, 2016}} ==Corporate responsibility== The company operates a bi-annual donation drive whereby it donates coffee to troops overseas based on customer purchases at its cafes.{{cite press release | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170501006299/en/Books-A-Million-Honors-U.S.-Military-Biannual-Coffee-Troops | title=Books-A-Million Honors U.S. Military with Biannual Coffee for the Troops Campaign April 30 – May 30 | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=May 1, 2017}}{{cite news | url=http://www.fdlreporter.com/story/news/local/action-advertiser/2017/05/11/books--million-sell-coffee-troops/101464322/ | title=Books-A-Million to sell coffee for troops | work=[[USA Today]] | date=May 11, 2017}} The company runs a bi-annual educator's week whereby it gives discounts to teachers.{{cite press release | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170320005693/en/Books-A-Million-Honors-Teachers-Educator-Week-April-1-7 | title=Books-A-Million Honors Teachers with Educator Week, April 1–7 | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=March 20, 2017}} ==Criticism== In 2014, Books-A-Million was identified by ''24/7 Wall Street'' as America's worst company to work for, citing low satisfaction among employees due to "high stress and low pay... low chance of promotion, [and] hours are based on magazine and discount card sales."{{cite news | title=New idea in used books: 2nd and Charles opens with recycling theme | url=http://247wallst.com/special-report/2014/06/21/americas-worst-companies-to-work-for-3/4/ | first1=Thomas C. | last1=Frohlich | first2=Douglas A. | last2=McIntyre | publisher=24/7 Wall Street | date=June 21, 2014}}{{cite news | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/birmingham/news/2014/06/24/books-a-million-lands-on-list-of-americas-worst.html | title=Books-A-Million lands on list of America's Worst Companies to Work For | first=Jason | last=Frost | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=June 24, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|1}} ==External links== {{Portal|Alabama|Companies|Books}} * {{official website|http://www.booksamillion.com}} {{Bookstore Chains}} [[Category:1917 establishments in Alabama]] [[Category:Bookstores of the United States]] [[Category:Book selling websites]] [[Category:Dot-com bubble]] [[Category:E-commerce]] [[Category:Companies based in Birmingham, Alabama]] [[Category:Florence, Alabama]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1917]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Gary Cooper}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Cary Cooper | image = Cary Cooper - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting Davos 2010.jpg | image_size = | caption = Cary Cooper at the [[World Economic Forum]]'s Annual Meeting 2010. | birth_name = | birth_date = 28 April 1940 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = United States & United Kingdom | other_names = | known_for = 50th Anniversary Professor of Organizational Psychology and Health at the [[Manchester Business School]] | education = | alma mater = | employer = | occupation = Academic | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = }} '''Sir Cary Lynn Cooper''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|FAcSS}} (born 28 April 1940), is an American-born British [[psychologist]] and 50th Anniversary Professor of [[Organizational Psychology]] and [[occupational health|Health]] at the [[Manchester Business School]], [[University of Manchester]].
Before moving to Manchester he was Distinguished Professor at [[Lancaster University]]. Cooper was Head of the Manchester School of Management (within [[UMIST]]) from the early 1980s. In 1995 he became Pro-Vice-Chancellor and then Deputy Vice-Chancellor of UMIST until 2002. From 1979 to 1980 he was chairman of the Management Education and Development Division of the [[Academy of Management]] and was elected as Founding President of the [[British Academy of Management]].<ref name=aston>{{cite web |url=http://www.aston.ac.uk/aston-business-school/staff/professor-cary-cooper/ |title=Professor Cary Cooper |accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> In June 2005 he was appointed head of the [[Sunningdale Institute]], which, managed by the United Kingdom [[National School of Government]], brings international academics and industry figures together to advise on issues facing UK public sector organisations.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.lancs.ac.uk/Web/News/Pages/EBC6865D03E024D88025702A0040C15B.aspx |title=Professor Cary Cooper to lead new Sunningdale Institute |accessdate=30 April 2015}}</ref> He was Chair of the [[Academy of Social Sciences]],<ref name=personally>{{cite web |url=http://www.personallyspeakingbureau.com/speaker/cary-cooper-cbe-prof/ |title=Cary Cooper CBE, Prof. - Personally Speaking Bureau |accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> a body representing over 88,000 social scientists and 46 learned societies in the social sciences (e.g. [[Royal Geographical Society]], [[British Psychological Society]], [[Political Studies Association]], [[Royal Statistical Society]], etc.). He is immediate past President of [[Relate]],<ref name=relate>{{cite web |url=http://www.relate.org.uk/about-us/media-centre/press-releases/2013/12/11/prof-cary-cooper-announced-new-president-relate |title=Prof Cary Cooper announced as the new President of Relate |accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> Clinical Advisor to [[Anxiety UK]],<ref name=anxiety>{{cite web|url=http://www.anxietyuk.org.uk/about-us/whos-who/medical/ |title=Clinical Advisors Anxiety UK |accessdate=17 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617185402/http://www.anxietyuk.org.uk/about-us/whos-who/medical/ |archivedate=17 June 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> President of the Institute of Welfare,<ref name=welfare>{{cite web |url=http://www.instituteofwelfare.com/the-institute/our-leadership/ |title=Our Leadership Institute of Welfare |accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> President of the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development 2016-, and past President of the [[British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy]].<ref name=bacp>{{cite web |url=http://www.bacp.co.uk/about_bacp/history_officers.php |title=BACP About BACP - History of Officers and Chief Executive |accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> Cooper is also a director of well-being specialists and business psychologists at Robertson Cooper Limited, a university spin off company which he set up in 1999 with Ivan Robertson.<ref>{{cite web |author=Home |url=http://www.robertsoncooper.com |title=Business psychology company founded by Cary Cooper and Ivan Robertson, based Manchester and London, offering well-being, stress and resilience, leadership development and talent management consultancy and tools |publisher=Robertson Cooper |date=17 August 2012 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref> He was the founding editor-in-chief of the ''[[Journal of Organizational Behavior]]''.
Cooper's parents were Jews from Romania and Ukraine who settled in [[West Hollywood]].<ref>[http://evolution.skf.com/cary-cooper/ "Cary Cooper"] in ''Evolution Online'', 15 March 2004</ref><ref>[http://www.lancaster.ac.uk/news/articles/2014/knighthood-and-mbe-for-lancaster-professors/ "Knighthood and MBE for two Lancaster professors"], Lancaster University, 16 June 2014</ref> He became a British citizen in 1993.
== Education == Cooper has obtained a BSc, an [[M.B.A.]], and a PhD
== Recognition == Cooper has received the following awards from professional and academic organisations: * 1994 Fellow of the [[British Academy of Management]] * 1994 Elected a Fellow of the (British) Institute of Management * 1997 Elected by the (American) Academy of Management as one of the first UK Fellows * 1997 Became a Companion of the Institute of Management (now the [[Chartered Management Institute]]) * 1998 Awarded the Distinguished Service Award by the (American) Academy of Management for services to the field of management *1998 Awarded an Honorary Doctorate of Letters from [[Heriot-Watt University]] (Edinburgh) for contributions to organizational psychology *1999 Awarded an Honorary Doctorate of Business Administration by [[Wolverhampton University]] *2002 Awarded an Honorary Doctorate of Science by [[Aston University]] *2003 Awarded an Honorary Doctorate by [[Middlesex University]] *2005 Cooper was elected as an Honorary Fellow of the Faculty of Occupational Medicine of the [[Royal College of Physicians]] *2006 Cooper was made Hon Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians *2008 Awarded Hon Fellow of the British Psychological Society *2008 Cooper was made an Hon Fellow of the Faculty of Occupational Medicine of the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland *2008 Cooper was selected as Chair of the [[Academy of Social Sciences]] (body of nearly 90,000 social scientists and 47 learned societies). *2009 Cooper was appointed Chair of the Chronic Diseases Global Agenda Council of the World Economic Forum. *2010 Awarded the Lord Dearing Lifetime Achievement Award for Higher Education by THE *2011 Awarded an Honorary Doctor of Science by [[University of Sheffield]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.lancs.ac.uk/Web/News/Pages/75EDD4F47577DB828025781F004DC0C2.aspx |title=Honorary Degree for Cary Cooper |publisher=News.lancs.ac.uk |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref> *2012 Awarded Hon Fellowship of the Institution of Occupational Safety and Healt *2014 Awarded an Honorary Doctor of Laws by Bath University *2014 Elected as President of the British Academy of Management *2015 Elected as [[CIPD]] President <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cipd.co.uk/about/media/press/151215-cooper-president |title=Professor Sir Cary Cooper elected as new CIPD President |publisher=www.cipd.co.uk |date=15 December 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref> *2017 Awarded an Honorary Doctor of Science by the University of Chester *2018 Awarded the WFPMA Petitpas Award for Distinguished Service to the Global HR Profession by the World Federation of People Management Associations, Chicago.
== Queen's Birthday Honours == Cooper was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the 2001 Birthday Honours for his contribution to occupational/organizational health and was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[2014 Birthday Honours]] for services to social science.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=60895 |date=14 June 2014 |page=b2 |supp=y}}</ref>
== Media work == Cooper has been described as the media’s first choice for comment on workplace issues,<ref name=personally /> and is often interviewed by the UK press (including [[BBC]] and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]) for both news and current affairs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/6444565.stm |title=Health | Office workers 'risk blood clots' |publisher=BBC News |date=13 March 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.scotsman.com/uk.cfm?id=435392007 |title=News - Scotsman.com |publisher=News.scotsman.com |date= |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/26/business/worldbusiness/26iht-workcol27.4728521.html?_r=1 |title=The Workplace: U.S.-style work stress is spreading to Europe |publisher=International Herald Tribune |author=Matthew Saltmarsh |date=26 February 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.personneltoday.com/Articles/2007/02/27/39412/who-will-replace-duncan-brown-as-assistant-director-general-at-the-chartered-institute-of-personnel.html |title=Who will replace Duncan Brown as assistant director-general at the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development? – 2/27/2007 |publisher=Personnel Today |date=27 February 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/tm_headline=mourinho-s-moans-help-lift-blues-says-top-psychologist-professor-cary-cooper--&method=full&objectid=18972465&siteid=89520-name_page.html/Mourinho's |title=Mourinho'S Moans Help Lift Blues – Mirror Online |publisher=Mirror.co.uk |date=27 April 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hrzone.com/talent/development/resilient-employees-likely-to-be-physically-healthier-and-more-productive |title=Resilient employees likely to be physically healthier and more productive HRZone |accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Workplace bullying]] * [[Women in the workforce|Women in the workplace]] * [[Work-life balance]] * [[Hours of work]] * [[Gender pay gap]]
== Selected bibliography == *"Presenteeism" (with Luo Lu, Cambridge University Press, 2018) *"The Myths of Management" (with Stefan Stern, Kogan Page, 2018) *"21st Century Workforces and Workplaces" (with Bevan, Brinkley & Bajorek, Bloomsbury, 2018) *"Boards that Dare" (with Marc Stigter, Bloomsbury, 2018) *"Managing Health and Wellbeing in the Public Sector" (with Ian Hesketh, Routledge, 2017). *"The Spartan Worker" (with Kostas Perrotis, Routledge, 2017). *"Handbook of Stress and Health" (with James Quick, Wiley Blackwell, 2017). *"The Outstanding Middle Manager" (with Gordon Tinline, Palgrave Macmillan, 2016) *"Stress in the Construction Industry" (with Leung and Chan, Wiley Blackwell, 2015). *"Wellbeing: The Complete Reference Guide (6 volumes), Wiley Blackwell, 2014. *"Building Resilience for Success. (with Jill Flint-Taylor and Michael Pearn, Palgrave-Macmillan, 2013. *"High Engagement Work Culture: Balancing WE and ME. (with David Bowles), Palgrave-Macmillan, 2012.S *"Wellbeing: Productivity and Happiness at Work. (with Ivan Robertson), Palgrave-Macmillan, 2011.s *"The Science of Occupational Health". (with Ulf Lundberg), Wiley-Blackwell, 2011. *''Employee Morale: Driving Performance in Challenging Times'' (with David Bowles), Palgrave-Macmillan October 2009 *''Mental Capital and Wellbeing" (with Field, Goswami, Jenkins & Sahakian), Wiley-Blackwell, 2009. *"Managing Executive Health" (with Quick, Gavin and Quick), Cambridge University Press, 2008. *"Happy Performing Managers" (with P. Hosie), Edward Elgar Publ, 2006. *"Business and the Beautiful Game" (with T. Theobald), Kogan Page 2005 * ''Leadership and Management in the 21st Century: Business Challenges of the Future'', Oxford University Press 2004 * ''The Blackwell Encyclopaedia of Management'' (Editor, with Associate Editors C Argyris and W H Starbuck), Blackwell 2004 * ''Stress: A Brief History'' (with P Dewe), Blackwell 2004 * ''International Review of Industrial and Organizational Psychology: Vols.1–19 (with I T Robertson), John Wiley and Sons, 1986–2004. * "Managing the Emotions in Mergers and Acquisitions" (with Dr. V. Kusstascher), Edward Elgar Publ., 2005. * ''Work Psychology: Understanding Human Behaviour in the Workplace'' (with I T Robertson, J Silvester, B Burnes, F Patterson and J Arnold, Financial Times Prentice Hall 2004 * ''Managing the Safety Risk of Workplace Stress'' (with S Clarke), Routledge 2003 * "Destressing Doctors" (with Dr. V. Sutherland), Butterworth Heinemann, 2003.

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = CubeSat for Solar Particles (CuSP) | names_list = | image = | image_caption = | image_alt = | image_size = | mission_type = Technology, reconnaissance | operator = [[Southwest Research Institute]] | COSPAR_ID = | SATCAT = | website = | mission_duration = | distance_travelled = | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = 6U [[CubeSat]] | spacecraft_bus = | manufacturer = [[Southwest Research Institute]] | launch_mass = {{convert|14|kg|abbr=on}} | BOL_mass = | payload_mass = | dimensions = 10×20×30 cm | power = | launch_date = December 2019{{cite news |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2017/04/28/nasa-confirms-first-flight-of-space-launch-system-will-slip-to-2019/ |title=NASA confirms first flight of Space Launch System will slip to 2019 |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=28 April 2017 |access-date=29 April 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Space Launch System|SLS Block 1]] | launch_site = [[Kennedy Space Center|Kennedy]] [[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39|LC-39B]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | declared = | deactivated = | destroyed = | last_contact = | recovery_by = | recovery_date = | decay_date = | orbit_reference = [[heliocentric]] | orbit_regime = | orbit_longitude = | orbit_slot = | orbit_semimajor = | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = | orbit_RAAN = | orbit_arg_periapsis = | orbit_mean_anomaly = | orbit_mean_motion = | orbit_repeat = | orbit_velocity = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_rev_number = | apsis = |interplanetary = {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = Flyby |object = [[Moon]] |orbits = |component = |arrival_date = |departure_date = |location = |distance = }} | instrument_type = | telescope_name = Miniaturized Electron and Proton Telescope ('''MERiT''') | telescope_type = | telescope_diameter = | telescope_focal_length= | telescope_area = | telescope_wavelength = | telescope_resolution = | instruments = Suprathermal Ion Spectrograph ('''SIS''')
Vector Helium Magnetometer ('''VHM''') | trans_band = | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} '''CubeSat for Solar Particles''' ('''CuSP''') is a planned [[nanosatellite]] spacecraft that will study the dynamic [[Solar energetic particles|particles]] and [[Sun#Magnetic field|magnetic fields]] that stream from the Sun. {{cite news |url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2016/heliophysics-cubesat-to-launch-on-nasa-s-sls |title=Heliophysics CubeSat to Launch on NASAs SLS |work=NASA |date=February 2, 2016 |accessdate=2016-02-05 }}{{cite news |last=Messier |first=Doug |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2016/02/05/swri-cubesat-explore-deep-space/ |title=SwRI CubeSat to Explore Deep Space |work=Parabolic ARC |date=February 5, 2016 |accessdate=2016-02-05 }} CuSP is a low-cost 6U [[CubeSat]] nanosatellite that once deployed, will orbit the Sun, measuring [[Solar irradiance|incoming radiation]] that can create a wide variety of effects at Earth, from interfering with radio communications to tripping up satellite electronics to creating electric currents in power grids. The principal investigator for CuSP is Mihir Desai, at the [[Southwest Research Institute]] in San Antonio, Texas. It will fly as a secondary payload mission on the first flight of the [[Space Launch System]], [[Exploration Mission 1]] (EM-1) scheduled to launch in 2019. ==Objective== To create a network of [[space weather]] stations would require many instruments scattered throughout space millions of miles apart, but the cost of such a system is prohibitive. Though the [[CubeSat]]s can only carry a few instruments, they are relatively inexpensive to launch because of their small mass and standardized design. So, CuSP also serves as a test for creating a network of space science stations. ==Payload== This CubeSat will carry three scientific instruments: #The Suprathermal Ion Spectrograph ('''SIS'''), is built by the [[Southwest Research Institute]] to detect and characterize low-energy solar energetic particles. #Miniaturized Electron and Proton Telescope ('''MERiT'''), will return counts of high-energy solar energetic particles. #Vector Helium Magnetometer ('''VHM'''), being built by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, will measure the strength and direction of magnetic fields. ;Propulsion The satellite features a [[cold gas thruster]] system for propulsion, [[attitude control]] (orientation) and orbital maneuvering.[http://www.cubesat-propulsion.com/cusp-propulsion-system/ CuSP Propulsion].. ''VACCO Propulsion Systems''. 2017. ==See also== {{portal|Spaceflight|Moon}} ;The 13 CubeSats flying in the Exploration Mission 1 *[[Lunar Flashlight]] will map exposed water ice on the Moon *[[Near-Earth Asteroid Scout]] by NASA is a [[solar sail]] spacecraft that will encounter a [[near-Earth asteroid]] *[[BioSentinel]] is an [[astrobiology]] mission *[[SkyFire (spacecraft)|SkyFire]] by [[Lockheed Martin]] *[[Lunar IceCube]], by the [[Morehead State University]] *CubeSat for Solar Particles (CuSP) *[[Lunar Polar Hydrogen Mapper]] (LunaH-Map), designed by the Arizona State University *[[EQUULEUS (spacecraft)|EQUULEUS]], submitted by [[JAXA]] and the [[University of Tokyo]] *[[OMOTENASHI]], submitted by JAXA, is a lunar lander *[[ArgoMoon]], designed by [[Argotec]] and coordinated by [[Italian Space Agency]] *[[Cislunar Explorers]], Cornell University, Ithaca, New York *[[Earth Escape Explorer]] (CU-E3), University of Colorado Boulder *[[Team Miles]], by Fluid & Reason, LLC. Florida ==References== {{reflist}} {{Moon spacecraft}} {{Future spaceflights}} [[Category:CubeSats]] [[Category:Proposed NASA space probes]] [[Category:Missions to the Sun]] [[Category:2019 in spaceflight]] [[Category:2019 in the United States]]

{{pp-pc1}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{calendar}} {{This date in recent years}} {{Day}}
==Events== * [[362]] – [[Athanasius of Alexandria|Athanasius]] returns to [[Alexandria]]. *[[1245]] – [[Thomas (bishop of Finland)|Thomas]], the first known [[Bishop of Finland]], is granted resignation after confessing to torture and [[forgery]]. *[[1437]] – [[James I of Scotland]] is assassinated. *[[1440]] – The [[Prussian Confederation]] is formed. *[[1543]] – [[Battle of Wayna Daga]]: A combined army of [[Ethiopia]]n and Portuguese troops defeats a Muslim army led by [[Ahmed Gragn]]. *[[1613]] – [[Michael I of Russia|Mikhail I]] is unanimously elected [[Tsar]] by a [[Zemsky Sobor|national assembly]], beginning the [[Romanov dynasty]] of [[Imperial Russia]]. *[[1797]] – A force of 1,400 French soldiers [[Battle of Fishguard|invaded Britain]] at [[Fishguard]] in support of the [[Society of United Irishmen]]. They were defeated by 500 British reservists. *[[1804]] – The first self-propelling [[steam locomotive]] makes its outing at the [[Penydarren Ironworks|Pen-y-Darren Ironworks]] in Wales. *[[1808]] – Without a previous declaration of war, Russian troops cross the border to Sweden at Abborfors in eastern Finland, thus beginning the [[Finnish War]], in which Sweden will lose the eastern half of the country (i.e. Finland) to Russia. *[[1828]] – Initial issue of the [[Cherokee Phoenix]] is the first periodical to use the [[Cherokee syllabary]] invented by [[Sequoyah]]. *[[1842]] – John Greenough is granted the first U.S. patent for the [[sewing machine]]. *[[1848]] – [[Karl Marx]] and [[Friedrich Engels]] publish ''[[The Communist Manifesto]]''. *[[1862]] – [[American Civil War]]: [[Battle of Valverde]] is fought near [[Fort Craig]] in [[New Mexico Territory]]. *[[1874]] – The ''[[Oakland Daily Tribune]]'' publishes its first edition. *[[1878]] – The first [[telephone directory]] is issued in [[New Haven, Connecticut]]. *[[1885]] – The newly completed [[Washington Monument]] is dedicated. *[[1896]] – An Englishman raised in Australia, [[Bob Fitzsimmons]], fought an Irishman, [[Peter Maher (boxer)|Peter Maher]], in an American promoted event which technically took place in Mexico, winning the [[1896 World Heavyweight Championship]] in [[boxing]]. *[[1913]] – [[Ioannina]] is incorporated into the [[Greek state]] after the [[Balkan Wars]]. *[[1916]] – [[World War I]]: In France, the [[Battle of Verdun]] begins. *[[1918]] – The last [[Carolina parakeet]] dies in captivity at the [[Cincinnati Zoo]]. *[[1919]] – German socialist [[Kurt Eisner]] is [[assassination|assassinated]]. His death results in the establishment of the [[Bavarian Soviet Republic]] and parliament and government fleeing [[Munich]], Germany. *[[1921]] – [[Constituent Assembly of Georgia|Constituent Assembly]] of the [[Democratic Republic of Georgia]] adopts the country's first constitution. * 1921 – [[Rezā Shāh]] takes control of Tehran during a [[1921 Persian coup d'état|successful coup]]. *[[1925]] – ''[[The New Yorker]]'' publishes its first issue. *[[1937]] – The [[League of Nations]] bans foreign national "[[Unlawful combatant|volunteers]]" in the [[Spanish Civil War]]. *[[1945]] – [[World War II]]: During the [[Battle of Iwo Jima]], Japanese [[kamikaze]] planes sink the escort carrier {{USS|Bismarck Sea|CVE-95|6}} and damage the {{USS|Saratoga|CV-3|6}}. * 1945 – [[World War II]]: the [[Brazilian Expeditionary Force]] defeat the German forces in the [[Battle of Monte Castello]] on the [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian front]] *[[1947]] – In New York City, [[Edwin Land]] demonstrates the first "[[instant camera]]", the [[Polaroid Land Camera]], to a meeting of the [[Optical Society of America]]. *[[1948]] – [[NASCAR]] is incorporated. *[[1952]] – The British government, under [[Winston Churchill]], abolishes [[Identity document|identity cards]] in the UK to "set the people free". * 1952 – The [[Bengali Language Movement]] protests occur at the [[University of Dhaka]] in [[East Pakistan]] (now [[Bangladesh]]). *[[1958]] – The CND symbol, aka [[peace symbol]], commissioned by the [[Direct Action Committee]] in protest against the [[Atomic Weapons Research Establishment]], is designed and completed by [[Gerald Holtom]]. *[[1965]] – [[Malcolm X]] is assassinated at the [[Audubon Ballroom]] in New York City. *[[1971]] – The [[Convention on Psychotropic Substances]] is signed at [[Vienna]]. *[[1972]] – United States President [[Richard Nixon]] visits the People's Republic of China to normalize [[Sino-American relations]]. * 1972 – The [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] unmanned [[Spacecraft|spaceship]] [[Luna 20]] lands on the Moon. *[[1973]] – Over the [[Sinai Desert]], Israeli [[fighter aircraft]] shoot down [[Libyan Arab Airlines Flight 114]] jet killing 108 people. *[[1974]] – The last Israeli soldiers leave the west bank of the [[Suez Canal]] pursuant to a truce with [[Egypt]]. *[[1975]] – [[Watergate scandal]]: Former [[United States Attorney General]] [[John N. Mitchell]] and former [[White House]] aides [[H. R. Haldeman]] and [[John Ehrlichman]] are sentenced to prison. *[[1995]] – [[Steve Fossett]] lands in [[Leader, Saskatchewan]], Canada becoming the first person to make a solo flight across the Pacific Ocean in a [[hot air balloon|balloon]]. *[[2013]] – At least 17 people are killed and 119 injured following [[2013 Hyderabad blasts|several bombings]] in the [[India]]n city of [[Hyderabad]].
