page.title: Festival Rock y Ruedas de Avándaro

revision.comment: Fixed typos found with [[Wikipedia:Typo_Team/moss]] and reduced ALLCAPS.
revision.text:
{{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Avandaro | image = | caption = Photograph of the Avandaro Festival poster | location = Tenantongo, Valle de Bravo, State of Mexico, Mexico. | years_active = Original festival held in 1971 | founders = Luis de Llano Macedo, Justino Compean and brothers Alfonso and Eduardo Lopez Negrete (President). | dates = September 11–12, 1971 | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] and [[Folk music|folk]], including [[jazz-rock]], [[blues-rock]], [[folk rock]], [[Chicano rock|latin rock]], [[experimental rock]] and [[psychedelic rock]] styles. }} The '''Festival Rock y Ruedas de Avándaro''' (also known as the '''Festival de Avándaro''' or simply '''Avándaro''') was a historic [[Mexican rock music|Mexican rock]] festival held on September 11–12, 1971, on the shores of Lake Avándaro near the [[Avándaro Golf Club]], in a [[Hamlet (place)|hamlet]] called [[:es:Tenantongo|Tenantongo]], near the town of [[Valle de Bravo]] in the central [[State of Mexico]]. The festival, organized by brothers Eduardo and Alfonso Lopez Negrete's company Promotora Go, [[McCann Erickson]] executive and sports promoter [[:es:Justino Compeán|Justino Compean]] and [[Telesistema Mexicano]] producer [[Luis de Llano Macedo]], took place at the height of [[La Onda]] and celebrated life, youth, ecology, music, peace and [[free love]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jimenez Izquierdo|first1=Juan|title=Avandaro, mas que drogas y desnudos|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/815718.html|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=El Universal|date=12 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Monsivais|first=Carlos|editor1-first=Ana del |editor1-last=Sarto|editor2-first=Alicia|editor2-last=Ríos|editor3-first= Abril|editor3-last=Trigo|title=The Latin American Cultural Studies Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NW1CXsOKRc8C&pg=PA219|year=2004|publisher=Duke UP|isbn=9780822333401|pages=203–32|chapter=Would So Many Millions of People Not End Up Speaking English?: The North American Culture and Mexico}}</ref> has been compared to the American [[Woodstock]] festival<ref>{{cite book|last=Kramer|first=Michael J.|title=The Republic of Rock: Music and Citizenship in the Sixties Counterculture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yahvEERWHXsC&pg=PA220|year=2013|publisher=Oxford UP|isbn=9780195384864|pages=220–}}</ref> for its [[psychedelic music]], [[counterculture]] imagery and artwork, and open drug use. A milestone in the history of Mexican rock music, the festival has drawn anywhere from an estimated 100,000 to 500,000 concertgoers.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Anaya|first1=Vicente|title=Avandaro: Aliviane o Movida?|date=1971|publisher=Extemporaneos|url=https://books.google.com/?id=JnfSygAACAAJ|accessdate=3 March 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Rodriguez Florez|first1=Juan|title=El sumo sacerdote del rock|url=http://www.chron.com/spanish/entertainment/article/El-sumo-sacerdote-del-rock-1983120.php|accessdate=3 March 2015|publisher=The Houston Chronicle|date=5 November 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Azul del Olmo|first1=Luis Castaneda|title=De Avandaro al Vive Latino|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/2012/01/02/funcion/798501|accessdate=27 June 2014|publisher=Excelsior|date=2 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Zolov|first=Eric|editor1-first=Deborah Pancini|editor1-last= Hernandez|editor2-first=Héctor D. Fernández|editor2-last= l'Hoeste|editor3-first= Eric|editor3-last= Zolov|title=Rockin' Las Américas: The Global Politics of Rock in Latin/o America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-o51rAMJEUIC&pg=PA38|publisher=U of Pittsburgh P|isbn=9780822972556|pages=22––42|chapter=La Onda Chicana: Mexico's Forgotten Rock Counterculture|year=2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=,|first=Colin M. MacLachlan, William H. Beezley|title=El Gran Pueblo: a history of greater Mexico|url=https://books.google.com/?id=8ZlVAAAAMAAJ&q=avandaro+250+000&dq=avandaro+250+000|accessdate=23 August 2012|isbn=9780131841147|year=2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Rubli Kaiser|first1=Federico|title=Avándaro 1971: A 40 Años de Woodstock en Valle de Bravo|publisher=Nexos|date=16 September 2011}}</ref>
The festival originally scheduled 12 bands booked by music impresarios Waldo Tena and Armando Molina Solis' agency, but a total of 18 acts performed outdoors during the first, sometimes rainy weekend, before a massive crowd.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nava Durand|first1=Pepe Nayeli|title=Lo que siempre quiso saber de Avandaro|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/107117.html|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=El Universal|date=10 September 2011}}</ref> The event was captured in film by, among others, Cinematográfica Marco Polo, Telesistema Mexicano, [[Izzi Telecom|Cablevision]] and [[:es:Raúl Candiani|Peliculas Candiani]]. Audio was captured by [[Polydor Records]] and a live radio broadcast was sponsored by [[The Coca-Cola Company]]. Images of the festival were captured by photographers like [[Graciela Iturbide]], [[Pedro Meyer]] and others.
The [[Super 8 film|Super 8]] [[short films]] ''[[Avándaro (film)|Avándaro]]''<ref>{{cite web|last1=IMDB|title=Avandaro|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0412469/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> produced by Gutiérrez y Prieto of Cablevision and directed by [[Alfredo Gurrola]] and ''[[Tinta Blanca en Avándaro]]'' produced by Raul Candiani of Peliculas Candiani and directed by [[Humberto Rubalcaba Zuleta|Humberto Rubalcaba]] were the only films exclusively about the first festival. They were exhibited at international film festivals and theaters in 1972. Other movies, which partially used footage of the festival, were the Cinematográfica Marco Polo film "La verdadera vocación de Magdalena" produced by Anuar Badin and directed by [[Jaime Humberto Hermosillo]] and the Super 8 films "The year of the rat" by Enrique Escalona<ref>{{cite web|title=Enrique Escalona|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0260156/?ref_=fn_al_nm_2|website=IMDB|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref> and "La segunda primera matriz"<ref>{{cite web|title=La segunda primera matriz|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0323916/?ref_=nm_flmg_dr_61|website=IMDB|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref> by Alfredo Gurrola.
An accompanying soundtrack with a selection of the live recordings produced by [[Luis de Llano Macedo|Luis de Llano]]'s company LUDELL/BAKITA Records and named ''[[Avandaro (soundtrack)|Avandaro, por fin... 32 años después]]'' (Avandaro, at last ... 32 years later), was finally released in 2003.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cruz Barcenas|first1=Arturo|title=Presentarán disco con 12 temas que se tocaron en Avándaro en 1971|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2003/08/07/07an2esp.php?printver=0&fly=1|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=La Jornada|date=7 August 2003}}</ref>
==Before Avandaro: Massive events, student repression and ''La Onda''== By 1971 Mexico, ruled by the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party|PRI]], had organized two of the most important sporting events in the world: the [[1970 FIFA World Cup]] and the [[1968 Summer Olympics]], gaining a fresh and modern image its government wanted to show to the outside world. At the same time, its government had violently repressed political youth movements known as the ''[[Tlatelolco massacre]]'' and the ''[[Corpus Christi massacre|Halconazo]]'', which in turn gave way to the so-called [[Dirty War (Mexico)|Mexican Dirty War]] of the early 1970s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Forero|first1=Juan|title=Details of Mexico's Dirty Wars From 1960s to 1980s Released|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/21/AR2006112101740.html|accessdate=26 September 2014|publisher=The Washington Post|date=22 November 2006}}</ref>
The Mexican hippies, called "[[jipitecas]]" by [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|Catholic priest]] and scholar [[Enrique Marroquin]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Marroquin|first1=Enrique|title=La contracultura como protesta|year=1975|publisher=Ed. Joaquín Mortiz|location=Mexico|edition=First}}</ref> created a multidisciplinary movement called ''[[La Onda]]'' (The wave). In accordance to their hippie values, La Onda did not advocate a violent overthrow of the PRI, but it did advocate change. By 1969 the government had already banned the musical ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'' after a unique performance of it in [[Acapulco]], censuring the rock band ''Los Shakes'' (which included stars [[Pixie Hopkin]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Pixie Hopkin|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0394093/|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> [[Mayita Campos]] and [[Nono Zaldivar]]),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Goff|first1=Charlie|title=Pixie: A versatile star.|url=http://www.thenews.com.mx/index.php/ch-th-articles/15601-pixie-a-versatile-star|accessdate=30 September 2014|agency=The News|date=5 November 2013}}</ref> investigating impresario [[Alfredo Elias Calles]] (grandson of late president [[Plutarco Elias Calles]]) and deporting foreign actors and producers like [[Michael Butler (producer)|Michael Butler]], [[Gerome Ragni]] and [[James Rado]]. Such actions were heavily covered by local and American media like [[The New York Times]] and [[Time (magazine)|Time]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Gerome Ragni; Co-Wrote Broadway Musical "Hair"|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-07-15/news/mn-1492_1_gerome-ragni|accessdate=13 October 2014|agency=L.A. Times|date=15 July 1991}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dowling|first1=Colette|title=Hair - Trusting the Kids and the Stars|journal=Playbill|date=May 1971|url=http://michaelbutler.com/hair/holding/articles/HairArticles/Playbill5-71.html|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Rebolledo|first1=Anituy|title=Acapulco y Elvis.|url=http://suracapulco.mx/archivos/39144|accessdate=13 October 2014|agency=El Sur|date=30 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Butler|first1=Michael|title=Hairzapoppin'|journal=TIME|date=12 December 1969|url=http://www.michaelbutler.com/hair/holding/articles/HairArticles/Time12-12-69.html|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Mexico shuts hair and expels its cast after one showing|journal=The New York Times|date=January 6, 1969|volume=88|url=http://www.orlok.com/hair/holding/articles/HairArticles/NYT1-6-69.html|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> Writer [[Carlos Monsivais]], who witnessed the event, wrote an extensive article about the incident in his book ''Dias de guardar''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Monsivais|first1=Carlos|title=Dias de Guardar|year=1970|publisher=Era|location=Mexico|isbn=9684111886|edition=First}}</ref> Also in 1969, the band [[Pop Music Team]] had suffered censorship due to their hit "Tlatelolco" (which only had two weeks of radio airplay)<ref>{{cite book|last1=Krauze|first1=Enrique|title=Yo no era rebelde, Rock mexicano 1957-1971|year=1999|publisher=ClioTV|location=Mexico}}</ref> and in February 1971 in [[Monterrey]], a collective band called Sierra Madre, led by [[Teja Cunningham]], and a state-of-the-art lights spectacle named "Music and light show" had faced repression after a failed attempt to hold a three-day concert, called ''[[The ''Concierto Blanco'' incident|Concierto Blanco]]'' (white concert) inside the State government palace in Monterrey's main square. The violent incidents after the White concert, which were extensively covered by the media, seriously damaged then [[Nuevo Leon]] governor [[:es:Eduardo A. Elizondo Lozano|Eduardo Elizondo's]] political career.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Teja Cunningham|first1=Alfonso|title=40 años del Concierto Blanco|journal=La Quincena|date=February 2011|volume=88|url=http://www.15diario.com/laquincena/88/00.html|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
News from [[Cuba]] ([[Varadero '70]]), [[Colombia]] ([[:es:Festival de Ancon|Festival de Ancon]]), [[Argentina]] ([[Festival Buenos Aires Rock]]),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Garcia Villegas|first1=Juan José|title=Ancón 71, el festival hippie del amor y la paz|url=http://www.elcolombiano.com/proyectos/Ancon2005/notas/ancon71_historia.htm|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=El colombiano|year=2005}}</ref> [[Chile]] ([[Piedra Roja|Festival de los Dominicos "Piedra Roja"]]),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Munoz|first1=Arturo Alejandro|title=Piedra Roja, el ‘Woodstock’ chileno que los abuelos de hoy tratan de ocultar y que el viejo milicaje fascista tiembla al recordarlo|url=http://www.kaosenlared.net/america-latina/item/83365-piedra-roja-el-%E2%80%98woodstock%E2%80%99-chileno-que-los-abuelos-de-hoy-tratan-de-ocultar-y-que-el-viejo-milicaje-fascista-tiembla-al-recordarlo.html|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=Kaos en la red|date=18 March 2014}}</ref> [[England]] ([[Isle of Wight Festival|Isle of Wight]]) and films from American festivals like "[[Monterey Pop]]" and "[[Woodstock]]" fueled the desire for the jipitecas to host their own major counterculture event. The opportunity arrived in the spring of 1971.
==History== Trying to resurrect their popular [[auto racing]] spot, ''Circuito Avándaro'', after being cancelled in 1969 as a result of the fatal accident of [[racing driver]] [[Moisés Solana]], ''Promotora Go'' owners brothers Eduardo and Alfonso López Negrete in partnership with [[McCann (company)|McCann]] executive and sports promoter [[:es:Justino Compeán|Justino Compeán]] decided to organize a massive auto race with live rock music acts <ref>{{cite book|last1=Zolov|first1=Eric|title=Refried Elvis|date=1999|page=202|edition=1st|url=https://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft5q2nb3w6&brand=ucpress|accessdate=20 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=EDGAR VALERO Y ENRIQUE BERMÚDEZ|title=Sería un suicidio alejar a las familias de los estadios: Justino Compeán|url=http://www.cronica.com.mx/notas/2007/283868.html|accessdate=20 November 2017|agency=Cronica|date=2007-02-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Gomez Zuniga |first1=Anahi |title=Avandaro tenia aval de Televisa y del gobierno. |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/colaboracion/mochilazo-en-el-tiempo/nacion/sociedad/avandaro-tenia-aval-de-televisa-y-del-gobierno |accessdate=28 August 2018 |agency=El Universal |date=11 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ochoa|first1=Raúl|title=Las andanzas de Compeán|journal=Proceso|date=September 3, 2006|url=http://hemeroteca.proceso.com.mx/?page_id=278958&a51dc26366d99bb5fa29cea4747565fec=94751&rl=wh|accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref> and consulted then [[Telesistema Mexicano]] promoter [[Luis de Llano Macedo]] to video-record the motoring event and to hire [[:es:Javier Batiz|Javier Bátiz]] and [[La Revolución de Emiliano Zapata]], two of the most popular Mexican rock acts of the time. Luis de Llano was at the time producing a section named ''La onda de Woodstock'' in the [[Jacobo Zabludovsky]]'s program ''Hoy Domingo'' (Today Sunday). De Llano assembled a team of around 330 individuals to organize the music part of the festival, among them reporter/musicologist Jaime Almeida, screenwriter [[Armando Molina|Armando Molina Solis]], publicist [[Carlos Alazraki]], and [[Master of ceremonies|MCs]] Roberto Naranjo and Eduardo Davis.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Almeida|first1=Jaime|title=Avándaro: 40 años de mito y leyenda|url=http://lastresyuncuarto.wordpress.com/2011/09/11/jaime-almeida-avandaro-40-anos-de-mito-y-leyenda%E2%80%8F/|accessdate=7 October 2014|agency=Las Tres y un cuarto|date=11 September 2011}}</ref> Molina, himself an impresario and musician from ''[[La Maquina del Sonido]]'' fame, was appointed Music Coordinator.<ref name="Hernandez">{{cite news|last1=Hernandez|first1=Ricardo|title=Avándaro, a 40 años de distancia|url=http://www.oem.com.mx/elmexicano/notas/n2222229.htm|accessdate=24 June 2014|agency=Organizacion Editorial Mexicana|publisher=El sol de Mexico|date=10 September 2011}}</ref> The music coordination was in the hands of the company ArTe, owned by Molina and Waldo Tena (of [[:es:Los Rebeldes del Rock|Los rebeldes del Rock]] fame). After many negotitations and declining invitations Molina proceeded to book 12 bands. Designer [[Joe Vera]] was hired to design the official poster and tickets were sold at AUTOMEX-[[Chrysler]] agencies across the country for MX$25.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roma|first1=Tiziana|title=Joe Vera: El logo de una ciudad naciente|url=http://galucomunicacion.com.mx/joe-vera-el-logo-de-una-ciudad-naciente-por-tiziana-roma/|accessdate=26 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140826041104/http://galucomunicacion.com.mx/joe-vera-el-logo-de-una-ciudad-naciente-por-tiziana-roma/|archivedate=26 August 2014|df=}}</ref> Jacobo Zabludovsky heavily supported and promoted the festival in his daily news program "24hrs" and he was one of the few mainstream broadcasters to defend it in its aftermath.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Amador|first1=Diana|title=Jacobo Zabludovsky: con Dios y con el diablo|url=http://diez4.com/2013/jacobo-zabludovsky-con-dios-y-con-el-diablo/|website=Diez4|publisher=Diez4|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref>
==The venue==
===Expectations=== As was reported in the [[Corpus Christi Caller-Times]], a maximum of 25,000 attendees, 122 pilots with their staff (with their number expected to reduce after the technical inspections) and 12 Mexican bands with a possible last-minute inclusion of American bands to bolster the event was expected. The bands were going to play from Saturday 7 pm to Sunday 7 am, making way for the auto race to start in public roads around the lake. 2 weeks before the event, the 5 hotels in town were already booked.<ref name="Mexican village set for youths">{{cite news|title=Mexican village set for youths|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/21063832/|accessdate=30 September 2014|agency=Corpus Christi Caller-Times|date=11 September 1971}}</ref> In the [[TV Azteca]] documentary "Historias Engarzadas: Alex Lora" [[Alex Lora]] explained that this possible "''inclusion of American bands''" was going to be a surprise visit by [[Santana (band)|Santana]].
===Live Radio Broadcasting=== Sports promoter Justino Compean and Radio Juventud General Manager Ramiro Garza made a deal with then [[Coca-Cola Company]] Marketing Director, [[Vicente Fox Quezada]], to sponsor the live broadcasting.<ref>{{cite journal|title=El festival de rock y ruedas en Avandaro, en el olvido.|journal=Proceso|date=Sep 16, 2006|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/221358/platos-laser-el-festival-de-rock-y-ruedas-en-avandaro-en-el-olvido|accessdate=22 December 2016}}</ref>
===Lighting and sound systems=== Héctor Yaber from Telesistema Mexicano was in charge of the lighting system and Gustavo Cota from the company Audiorama S.A. of the [[PA system]]. All equipments were transported by the company Mudanzas Galván of José C. Galván Castro.
===Security=== The security was going to be in charge of the State of Mexico's Judicial Police chief Cuauhtémoc Cardenas, who was going to receive support from 200 state troopers, 120 army troops and 50 Special Agents from the Secretariat of the Interior. Nevertheless, reports of the total amount of security agents were mixed.''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported a total of 700 law-enforcement agents.<ref name="Mexican village set for youths"/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Zolov|first1=Eric|title=Refried Elvis|year=1999|publisher=University of California Press|location=USA|isbn=0520215141}}</ref>
===Terms between the organizers and mayor Montes de Oca=== The festival president Eduardo Lopez Negrete and Valle de Bravo's then-mayor Juan Montes de Oca Loza agreed that no liquor was going to be sold. Beer would be sold only with a meal.<ref name="Mexican village set for youths"/> In an in-depth radio/video interview with radio host Rafael Catana, Armando Molina stated that mayor Montes de Oca suggested to Valle de Bravo's inhabitants to be polite with the hippie crowd as they felt being overwhelmed by the excessive numbers of them. In the end, not a single Valle de Bravo inhabitant complained about the hippies.
==Cancellation of the auto race== Early Saturday morning it was decided, as stated by Alfonso Lopez Negrete, in an on-site interview made by a Telesistema Mexicano, to cancel the auto race due to the quantity of festival attendees which surpassed all expectations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Castellanos G.|first1=Ernesto|title=Avándaro, a 39 años|url=http://www.oem.com.mx/esto/notas/n1778125.htm|accessdate=24 June 2014|agency=OEM|publisher=Esto|date=11 September 2011}}</ref>
The ''Circuito Avandaro'' auto-race was going to be suspended for decades to come since authorities tied the sport with massive crowds.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jalife Villalon|first1=Carlos E.|title=Avándaro: primera pista internacional mexicana y último concierto masivo del siglo XX|journal=Scuderia Hnos. Rodriguez|date=September 2006|issue=22|url=http://www.sporcar.com/scuderia/historica/022.asp|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
==The music==
===Pre-festival=== As stated by Armando Nava, Alex Lora and De Llano in the "Memorias de un cierto dia: Avandaro" documentary, tens of thousands of jipitecas were already on-site so activities started September 9 (Thursday) with special shows and even some brief concerts some bands like El Amor, Dug Dug's and Three Souls in my Mind offered while at the same time doing their sound-check for Saturday. By Saturday 11 at 6AM, hundreds of thousands of attendees were already on-site so Molina and De Llano decided to formally start the festival with a "Pre-festival". The acts which performed were:
*[[Carlos Baca]] ([[Yoga]] session and [[ecology]] lecture) *[[Eduardo Ruiz Saviñón]] and [[UNAM]]'s experimental theater troupe with [[Carlos Steward]]. (Performed [[The Who]]'s "[[The Who's Tommy|Tommy]]" [[rock opera]]) *La Ley de Herodes (band of the famous [[Alfonso Arau|Arau]] family.) *Zafiro *[[La Sociedad Anonima]] *[[Los Soul Masters]] *[[La Fachada de Piedra]] with [[Larry Sanchez (39.4)]]
===Festival=== La Fachada de Piedra concluded their act at approx. 5pm. After a brief pause the festival resumed as follows: *[[Los Dug Dug's]] *El Epilogo *[[La División del Norte]] *[[Tequila (Mexican rock band)|Tequila]] *[[Peace & Love (Mexican rock band)|Peace & Love]] *[[El Ritual]] *[[Bandido (Mexican jazz-rock band)|Bandido]] *[[Los Yaki]] with Mayita Campos *[[Tinta Blanca]] *[[El Amor (Mexican rock band)|El Amor]] *[[:es:Three Souls In My Mind|Three Souls in my Mind]]
At around Sunday 9am, Three Souls in my Mind finished their act and the massive exodus started.
==Festival development== As stated by Armando Molina in the official soundtrack (narration part)<ref>{{cite book|last1=Molina|first1=Armando|title=Por fin...32 años después|year=2003|publisher=Bakita-Ludell Records|location=Mexico}}</ref> and by his then assistant Jaime Almeida,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Almeida|first1=Jaime|title=Avándaro: 40 años de mito y leyenda|url=http://lastresyuncuarto.wordpress.com/2011/09/11/jaime-almeida-avandaro-40-anos-de-mito-y-leyenda%E2%80%8F/|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=Milenio|date=7 July 2011}}</ref> the whole festival was held in peace with the only problem being that the attendees destroyed the barricade and invaded reserved areas of the light towers and even the stage. In the official soundtrack desperate calls for order from Molina's assistant Roberto Naranjo and band members from ''Dug Dug's'', ''El Epilogo'', and ''Peace and Love'' can be heard. At one point, an attendee fainted and Tequila's world-class Mexican-American singer, Maricela Durazo, ordered the crowd to take good care and protect her. As many thousands of jipitecas were on-site since Friday 10, co-organizer Luis de Llano stated the famous phrase: "They survived for three days sharing rain and mud; that was in attempt to have an identity."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pepe Navar|first1=Nayeli Durand|title=Lo que siempre quiso saber de Avandaro|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/107117.html|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=El Universal|date=10 September 2011}}</ref>
Francisco Martinez Gallardo, chief of the medical team and voluntaries of the improvised in-site hospital stated: "There was one case of acute appendicitis, 20 intoxicated with pills, 50 with marijuana, 5 with alcoholic congestion, 5 cases of gastroenteritis and some with wounded heads, ankle fractures and burns."<ref name="El Universal">{{cite web|title=A 40 años, las otras anécdotas de Avándaro|url=http://blogs.eluniversal.com.mx/weblogs_detalle14781.html|publisher=El Universal|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
==Exodus== President Luis Echeverria agreed to send 300 buses to pick up some of the attendees. The news were cheered with a rarely seen approval for a Mexican president from his country's youth. As one of the organizers yelled, with heavy use of slangs, through the audio system: "Lets cheer up Luis Echeverria, who is gonna send 300 buses of 50 seats each so we can go back...is a good guy that fella" (un aplauso para Luis Echeverría que nos va a mandar 300 camiones de 50 pasajeros para el regreso ... a todo dar el chavo ese).<ref name="El Universal"/> As can be seen in the Gurrola film, thousands upon thousands of hippies were walking from the site and many of them were overwhelming the buses.
==Aftermath: ''Avandarazo'' and controversies== As can be heard in the soundtrack, the band ''Peace and Love'' performed the songs "Marihuana" and "We got the power," that were considered controversial to Mexican society. At the same time, Peace and Love front-man Ricardo Ochoa used some foul language in order to cheer up the crowd, echoing what [[Country Joe McDonald]] did at Woodstock. Since the festival was being broadcast live through ''Radio Juventud'' and relay stations all over the country, some segments of society took this as a direct threat to the establishment ("Marihuana" for advocating open drug-use and "We got the power" for wrongly associating it with a possible popular uprising). The possible association of jipitecas with subversive and radical political movements is what caused the so-called ''Avandarazo''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rock|first1=Chava|title=Aváaaandaroooooooooo. A 39 años del festival más grande de México|url=https://mx.musica.yahoo.com/blogs/blogcanrol/avaaandaroooooooooo-a-39-aos-del-festival-ms-grande-de-mxico.html|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gutierrez Galaviz|first1=Julio|title=A 43 años del 'Avandarazo'|url=http://www.expreso.com.mx/estelar/estelar-musica/88554-a-43-anos-del-avandarazo.html|accessdate=26 September 2014|publisher=EXPRESO|date=15 September 2014}}</ref>
In the aftermath of the post-festival turmoil, several interviewed Avandaro attendees declared that the whole festival was held in peace and not a single major accident happened<ref>{{cite book|last1=Arana|first1=Federico|title=Guaraches de ante azul|year=1986|publisher=Ed. Posada|location=Mexico|isbn=9786076100196|url=http://blogs.eluniversal.com.mx/weblogs_detalle14781.html|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> but [[Mario Moya Palencia|Moya Palencia]], then [[Secretariat of the Interior (Mexico)|Secretary of the Interior]], accused the organizers of acting with intent and [[Carlos Hank González]], then governor of the State of Mexico, condemned the festival's organizers and in his own defense stated that "They were given permission to perform a sporting event, but instead presented a rock festival"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ochoa|first1=Raul|title=Las andanzas de Compean|journal=Proceso|date=3 September 2006|url=http://nakaksan.tumblr.com/post/64337987216/las-andanzas-de-compean|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Luna Pérez|first1=Sandra|title=Avandaro: Del exhorto a la censura|url=http://www.inehrm.gob.mx/pdf/exc_img_avandaro.pdf|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=Excelsior|date=9 September 2007}}</ref> but, as stated by [[:es:Armando Fuentes Aguirre|Armando Fuentes Aguirre ''Caton'']], his political opponents took this as an opportunity to destroy his presidential aspirations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fuentes Aguirre ''Caton''|first1=Armando|title=Lo que hizo el rock|url=http://www.frontera.info/EdicionDigital/Ediciones/20110912/pdfs/GENERAL_23.pdf|accessdate=25 June 2014|publisher=Frontera|date=12 September 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714202953/http://www.frontera.info/EdicionDigital/Ediciones/20110912/pdfs/GENERAL_23.pdf|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Catón remembers 40th anniversary of Mexico's Woodstock, Avándaro|url=http://mexicoperspective.com/caton-remembers-4o-th-anniversary-of-avandaro-mexican-woodstock.html|publisher=Mexico Perspective|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref>
Opinions from the world of politics, religion and academia were deeply divided. While influential university professors and La Onda writers such as [[:es:Parménides García Saldaña|Parménides García]] and [[José Agustín]], mostly gave the festival a positive review,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Martinez Rodriguez|first1=Jorge|title=Opinan profesores de la Universidad|url=http://robquero.tripod.com/Opinion.htm|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> and some intellectuals like [[Paco Ignacio Taibo I]], [[Elena Poniatowska]] (herself an attendee), [[Octavio Paz]] and [[José Emilio Pacheco]] gave a fairly positive evaluation too,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schelonka (edited by Alejandro Madrid and Ignacio Corona)|first1=Greg|title=RockIn' La Frontera (from the book Postnational Musical Identities)|date=2008|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=0-7391-1821-8|pages=151–173|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/?id=c2tu6oXxmkYC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2 March 2015}}</ref> others criticized it negatively like [[:es:Roberto Blanco Moheno|Roberto Blanco Moheno]] and [[Rius|Eduardo "Rius" del Rio]]. Writer and political activist [[Carlos Monsiváis]] initially gave the festival a negative review but changed his mind soon afterwards.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Figueroa|first1=Fernando|title=Avandaro segun tres Monsivais|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/cultura/66353.html|accessdate=25 June 2014|publisher=El Universal|date=11 September 2011}}</ref> As [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Guadalajara|Guadalajara Cardinal]] [[José Garibi y Rivera]] condemned it,<ref>{{cite news|title=Enérgica condena al festival de musica y vicio, en Avandaro|url=http://hemeroteca.informador.com.mx/|accessdate=21 March 2015|agency=Excélsior|publisher=El Informador|date=15 September 1971}}</ref> popular liberal priest and festival attendee Enrique Marroquin praised it, publishing in Piedra Rodante a controversial article in its defense called "God wants the rain so we can unite."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Marroquin|first1=Enrique|title=Dios quiere que llueva para unirnos|journal=Piedra Rodante|date=30 October 1971|url=http://robquero.tripod.com/Avandaro.htm|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> There was also a notable incident at [[Temple of San Felipe Neri "La Profesa"|La Profesa]], when during mass in homage to Mexico's Independence figure [[Agustin de Iturbide]], a group of about 250 individuals belonging to a conservative civil movement left the building in protest as mass was being served by [[Monsignor]] Rafael Vazquez Corona, a strong supporter of the festival.<ref>{{cite news|title=Exaltacion de Iturbide como autor de la consumacion de la Independencia.|url=http://hemeroteca.informador.com.mx/|accessdate=20 March 2015|agency=Excelsior|publisher=El Informador|date=27 September 1971}}</ref> Monsignor Vazquez Corona was then heavily criticized by then rector of the [[Universidad de Guadalajara|University of Guadalajara]], Dr. Garibay Gutiérrez, in his 1972 book about the festival "El gran desafio: Volver a pensar".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Garibay Gutiérrez|first1=Luis|title=El gran desafio: Volver a pensar.|date=1972|publisher=UAG|location=ITESO|edition=1st|url=http://148.201.128.23:8991/F/AX3NJJBX67G77VUKU2VLLCQH5SKXV2B1CBTTKYSI3LHA5MYT9A-66111?func=full-set-set&set_number=000287&set_entry=000006&format=999|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref>
Union leader [[Fidel Velazquez]] simply called the festival "a [[Bacchanalia]]", [[Attorney General of Mexico|Attorney General]] [[:es:Pedro Ojeda Paullada|Ojeda Paullada]] labelled it as a "[[witches' Sabbath]]" and President of the [[Senate of the Republic (Mexico)|Senate]], [[Enrique Olivares Santana]], yelled in a press conference: "Let there be no more Avandaros in the republic!". Finally and under pressure, president [[Luis Echeverría]] made a strong statement against the festival, saying: "While we regret and condemn the phenomenon of Avándaro, it also encourages us in our belief that only a small part of our youth are in favor of such acts and entertainment."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bizbera|first1=Andrea|title=Cifras con historia|url=http://www.loshijosdelamalinche.com/opinion/cifras-con-historia-20112014|website=Los hijos de la Malinche|publisher=REFORMA|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
President Echeverria then proceeded to crack down La Onda. Some early 1970s hit-songs like "Avandaro" from Rosario, "Seguir al sol" by Pajaro Alberto and others which commemorated the event, were banned from radio air play,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Poniatowska|first1=Elena|title=El poeta Alberto Blanco|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2007/11/18/index.php?section=opinion&article=a04a1cul|accessdate=27 September 2014|agency=La Jornada|date=18 November 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Doggett|first1=Peter|title=There's A Riot Going On: Revolutionaries, Rock Stars, and the Rise and Fall of '60s Counter-Culture|date=4 October 2007|publisher=Canongate Books Ltd.|location=UK|isbn=978-1847671141|page=431|edition=1st}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Pilcher|first1=Jeffrey M.|title=The human tradition in Mexico|year=2002|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|location=USA|isbn=978-0842029766|page=221|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jbeXAsUsxyMC&pg=PA221&lpg=PA221&dq=luis+echeverria+avandaro#v=onepage&q=luis%20echeverria%20avandaro&f=false|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lopez Segura|first1=Eduardo|title=Avandaro y el festival de rock de 1971|url=http://noticieros.televisa.com/mexico/1309/avandaro-festival-rock-1971/|accessdate=24 June 2014|agency=Noticieros Televisa|publisher=Televisa|date=12 September 2013}}</ref> Radio Juventud DJs Félix Ruano Mendez, Jaime Marin and Agustín Meza de la Peña were temporarily suspended but, contrary to popular belief, they were not terminated.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Galvan|first1=Hugo|title=Rock Impop|date=2013|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/?id=H1Dy_LrCTPUC&pg=PA124&lpg=PA124&dq=alfredo+gurrola+habla+sobre+avandaro#v=onepage&q=ruano&f=false|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hernandez|first1=Javier|title=Avándaro y la mentada que detuvo el tiempo|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2008/09/13/index.php?section=opinion&article=a10o1esp|accessdate=3 March 2015|publisher=La Jornada|date=13 September 2008}}</ref> On the other hand, the influential Piedra Rodante magazine was indeed terminated in early 1972<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cabrera Lopez|first1=Patricia|title=Una inquietud de amanecer|date=2006|publisher=UNAM|location=UNAM|isbn=970-722-485-1|pages=184–191|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Imz1bZ5jNm4C&pg=PA189&lpg=PA189&dq=la+nacion+de+avandaro#v=onepage&q=Manuel%20Aceves&f=false|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Martinez|first1=Jose Luis|title=Recuerdos de la inquisición|url=http://www.milenio.com/cultura/Recuerdos-inquisicion_0_241176112.html|accessdate=3 March 2015|agency=MILENIO|date=9 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Martinez Renteria|first1=Carlos|title=Desagravio a la Piedra Rodante|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2001/09/18/10an1esp.html|accessdate=3 March 2015|agency=La Jornada|date=14 September 2001}}</ref> and festival co-organizer Justino Compean left the country for a while.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Molina|first1=Armando|title=PLATOS LASER: El Festival de Rock y Ruedas en Avándaro, en el olvido|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=221358|accessdate=25 June 2014|publisher=Proceso|date=16 September 2006}}</ref>
The band Tinta Blanca and other rock musicians tried unsuccessfully to hold a meeting with president Echeverria with a famous protest outside [[Los Pinos]]. After a short time the protest was peacefully dissolved.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cortés.|first1=David|title=La vida despues de Avandaro|url=http://www.milenio.com/blogs/qrr/vida-despues-Avandaro_7_375032494.html|accessdate=27 September 2014|publisher=MILENIO|date=18 September 2014}}</ref>
==Films and TV==
===Short films=== *''Avandaro''. A 1971 Super 8 short film of approximately 20 minutes of footage with live soundtrack, produced by Luis Gutiérrez y Prieto<ref>{{cite web|last1=IMDB|title=Luis Gutierrez y Prieto|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1646261/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref> and directed/edited by [[Alfredo Gurrola]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=IMDB|title=Alfredo Gurrola|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0348735/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref> Photographers were awarded-filmmakers Héctor Abadie, David Celestinos and [[Sergio Garcia Michel]]. Facing government pressure in the aftermath of the festival, the film was briefly screened in selected theaters, cultural centers and international Super 8 film festivals only. By the end of the 1970s, the film was acquired by ''[[Cablevision (Mexico)|Cablevision]]'' thanks to the efforts of Gutiérrez y Prieto. As stated in Garcia Michel essay ''Toward a fourth cinema'': "Apart from the technical achievements, Luis always sympathized with this Movement, sponsoring films such as Avándaro, Pasiones [Passions] and La lucha [The Struggle]; the first two were transferred from super-8 to videotape and belong to Cablevisión."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Garcia Michel|first1=Sergio|title=Toward a fourth cinema|journal=Wide Angle|year=1999|volume=21|issue=3|url=https://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/lerner/wide_angle/21_3/213garcia_s.htm|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> In 2006, the company Video Grupo Empresarial included it as a DVD-extra in the release of the 1983 Sergio Garcia film ''Three Souls in my mind: Una larga experiencia''. *''Tinta Blanca en Avándaro''. [[16mm film|16mm]] short film produced by Raul Candiani and directed by the band's manager, Humberto Rubalcaba Zuleta, about the band's participation in the festival. The film was exhibited at the Berlinale and awarded third prize ("Sombrero de Bronce") at the IVth Guadalajara's International Short Film Festival. Mexico, 1972.<ref>{{cite book|title=Anuario de la producción cinematográfica mexicana 1972|date=1972|publisher=Banco Nacional Cinematográfico|pages=183|edition=1st|url=http://sic.conaculta.gob.mx/ficha.php?table=fondo_editorial_imcine&table_id=15946|accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Filmoteca |url=https://www.filmoteca.unam.mx/programacion/pelicula/tinta-blanca-en-avandaro_humberto-ruvalcaba |website=Filmoteca de la UNAM |accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=IV Festival Internacional Guadalajara de Cortometraje |url=https://hemeroteca.informador.com.mx |accessdate=28 August 2018 |agency=El Informador |date=November 23, 1972}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Una pelicula alemana triunfo en el IV festival del corto metraje |url=https://hemeroteca.informador.com.mx |accessdate=28 August 2018 |agency=El Informador |issue=November 26, 1972}}</ref> *''Avándaro: Imágenes Inéditas''. Rarely seen footage shot on-site by Sergio Garcia in 1971 and transferred from Super 8 to digital in 2008 by American filmmaker Angela Reginato. This posthumous work was premiered in February 2, 2014 in Mexico City at the Benemérito de las Américas cultural center. Mexico 2008.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Homenaje póstumo a Sergio García Michel|journal=Cine Toma|date=15 January 2014|url=http://revistatoma.wordpress.com/2014/01/15/homenaje-sergio-garcia-michel/|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=El cineasta independiente Sergio García Michel será recordado con retrospectiva y mucho rock|url=http://www.conaculta.gob.mx/detalle-nota/?id=31621#.VLWOHMkwC1w|website=CONACULTA|publisher=CONACULTA|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Angela Reginato|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1301920/|website=IMDB|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
===Documentaries=== *''Avándaro 20 años después''. Documentary produced by Enrique Quintero Marmol, Mexico 1991. *''Avándaro''. Documentary produced by Tres Tristes Tigres/Enrique Quintero Marmol. A longer version of the 1991 documentary. Mexico 1996. *''Las glorias de Avandaro''. An independently produced documentary by Arturo Lara Lozano, Carlos Cruz, Manuel Martinez, Angel Velazquez and Arnulfo Martinez y Torres, Mexico 2005. *''Bajo el sol y frente a Dios''. Independent documentary by Arturo Lara Lozano/Enciclopedia del rock mexicano. Mexico, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Quiriarte|first1=Xavier|title=Arturo Lara celebra los 45 de Avandaro.|url=http://www.milenio.com/cultura/avandaro_0_865713433.html|accessdate=22 December 2016|agency=MILENIO|date=14 October 2016}}</ref>
===TV specials=== *''Jueves Espectaculares : Avándaro''. Special program of this Telesistema Mexicano's [[variety show]]. Presenter [[Julio Aleman]] interviewed some of the Festival's organizers as well as the mayor of Valle de Bravo, Mr. Juan Montes de Oca Loza. Mexico, 1971.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Hoy Canal 9 presenta.|journal=El Informador|date=September 23, 1971|pages=10–B|url=http://www.informador.com.mx|accessdate=28 July 2016}}</ref> *''Pantalla de Cristal: Enrique Quintero Marmol''. Special program produced by Canal 22-CONACULTA. Presenter Jose Fernandez interviews Quintero Marmol about the festival and his 1991-1996 documentaries. Mexico, 2002. *''In Memoriam: Avándaro''. Special program produced by [[Canal Once (Mexico)|Canal Once]]/Enrique Quintero Marmol, Mexico 2003. *''Memoria viva de ciertos dias: Festival de Avándaro''. Special program produced by Canal 22 ([[CONACULTA]]). Includes interviews with Alex Lora, Luis de Llano, Armando Nava and others. Mexico 2003. *''La historia detras del mito: Avándaro''. Special program produced and aired by [[Azteca (multimedia conglomerate)|TV Azteca]], Mexico 2012. *''El observador: 40 años de Avándaro, Partes 1 y 2''. Special program produced by Television Metropolitana S.A. de C.V.- [[XEIMT-TV|Canal 22]]. [[National Council for Culture and Arts|Consejo Nacional para la Cultura y las Artes]], Mexico 2013. * ''Susana Adicción: Hablando del Festival de Avándaro''. Special program dedicated to the festival conducted by [[Monclova, Mexico|Monclova]]-born singer [[Susana Zabaleta]]. Produced by Luis de Llano for UNICABLE-TELEVISA. Mexico 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Neto|first1=Tavo|title=De Avándaro a Johnny Laboriel|url=http://www.vanguardia.com.mx/columnas-deavandaroajohnnylaboriel-1835182.html|accessdate=9 February 2015|publisher=Vanguardia|date=20 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hidalgo|first1=Juan Carlos|title=Avándaro y la Ceremonia de la música|url=http://www.milenio.com/firmas/juan_carlos_hidalgo/Avandaro-Ceremonia-musica_18_156164428.html|accessdate=9 February 2015|agency=MILENIO|date=18 September 2013}}</ref> *''Observatorio Cotidiano: 45 años de Avándaro''. Special program to commemorate the 45th anniversary of the festival. Includes a short documentary about festival photographer Graciela Iturbide. Produced by [[TV UNAM]]. Mexico, 2016. *''Leyendas: Avándaro''. Special program hosted by Luis de LLano where he interviews Justino Compean, Graciela Iturbide, Alex Lora and other people involved with the festival. Produced by Televisa. Mexico, 2017. *''Maravillas y Curiosidades de la Filmoteca de la UNAM: Avandaro''. Special program hosted by Rafael Avina where he conducts an in-depth interview with filmmaker Alfredo Gurrola about his legendary Super 8mm shortfilm 'Avandaro'. Produced by TV UNAM. Mexico, 2017.
===The festival in documentaries about Mexican rock=== *''Nunca digas que no: Tres decadas de rock mexicano''. Documentary produced by [[MTV]], USA 1996. *''Yo no era rebelde, Rock mexicano 1957-1971''. Documentary from ClioTV, produced by [[Enrique Krauze]]. Mexico 1999.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Krauze|first1=Enrique|title=Yo no era un Rebelde: Rock mexicano 1957-1971|url=http://www.cliotv.com/prueba/index.php?go=programas_uno&ser=c&id_coleccion=8&id_subcoleccion=21&id_programa=143&idioma=esp|publisher=ClioTV|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> *''BACK''. Documentary about the history of rock music in Guadalajara and the involvement of some of its bands in the Avandaro Festival. Produced by the [[Universidad Autonoma de Guadalajara]], Mexico 2006. *''Rock n Roll made in Mexico: From evolution to revolution''. Documentary directed by Lance Miccio and produced by [[Canned Heat]] drummer [[Adolfo de la Parra|Fito de la Parra]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=de la Parra|first1=Fito|title=Rock n Roll made in Mexico: From evolution to revolution|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1109631/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> USA, 2007. *''Documental 1968-1971: Los Jefes del Rock''. Documentary directed by Guillermo Piñón. Set as a fictional story, several persons involved with the festival are interviewed. Produced by Canal 22/CONACULTA. Mexico, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Los Jefes del Rock|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1603886/?ref_=nm_flmg_wr_1|website=IMDB|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> *''[[Gimme the Power]]''. Documentary by [[Olallo Rubio]] about the band [[Molotov (band)|Molotov]] and how Mexican rock music has always had, since the late 1950s and passing through the Avandaro Festival until modern times, an ambiguous relationship with the Mexican government and society. Contains interviews with people involved in the festival like Luis de Llano, [[Sergio Arau]], [[Alex Lora]] and Armando Molina. IMCINE-[[CONACULTA]] Mexico, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gimme the Power|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2169326/?ref_=fn_al_tt_2|website=IMDB|accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref>
===Documentaries in production=== *''Avandaro''. In 2012, Mexican filmmaker Javier "Panda" Padilla<ref>{{cite web|last1=Padilla|first1=Franciso Javier|title=Franciso Javier Padilla|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2514999/?ref_=tt_ov_dr|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> of the movie ''[[:es:Suave patria|Suave patria]]'' stated that he was making a documentary about Avandaro but with no due date on sight.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pérez Raigosa|first1=Veronica|title=Retratará Javier "Panda" Padilla el Festival de Avándaro en documental|url=http://www.publimetro.com.mx/entretenimiento/retratara-javier-panda-padilla-el-festival-de-avandaro-en-documental/nlij!somTKUFHFqd2ZbBk4ngGQ/|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=Publimetro|date=10 September 2012}}</ref> In late 2013 he stated that the project, made in cooperation with Enrique Krauze’s Editorial CLIO, is stalled due to copyright issues and that it might take years to come into fruition.<ref>{{cite news|last1=CRESPO ARRONA|first1=Juana|title=Prepara 'Panda' proyectos para 2014.|url=http://www.am.com.mx/leon/espectaculos/prepara-panda-proyectos-para-2014--73482.html|accessdate=12 May 2015|agency=AM|date=29 Dec 2013}}</ref>
===The festival in movies and TV shows=== *''[[:es:La verdadera vocación de Magdalena|La verdadera vocación de Magdalena]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=IMDB|title=La verdadera vocacion de Magdalena|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067938/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> Contains a segment with a fictional appearance of La Revolucion de Emiliano Zapata and [[Angélica María|Angelica Maria]] at the festival. It uses some real footage of the festival interspersed with a fictional recreation of it. Directed by [[Jaime Humberto Hermosillo]]. Mexico, 1971. *''[[:es:Los Polivoces|Los Polivoces]]''. A comedy TV show of the early 1970s. The frequently seen [[fictional character]] ''Armandaro Valle de Bravo'', was supposed to be a jipiteca and was named after the event and Armando Molina.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Catana|first1=Rafael|title=Pueblo de Patinetas: Armando Molina|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M32qZEHqJG4|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> In his debut episode, he is supposed to be interviewed as he and his parents were returning from the festival. Mexico, 1971-1973. *''[[:es:Güeros|Güeros]]''. [[Ariel Award|Ariel awarded]] [[road movie]] directed by [[Alonso Ruizpalacios]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Alonso Ruizpalacios|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2091911/?ref_=tt_ov_dr|website=IMDB|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> It tells the fictional story of four characters who, in the middle of the [[1999 UNAM strike]], decide to find the legendary ''Epigmenio Cruz'', an artist who once "made [[Bob Dylan]] cry" and was scheduled to perform at the festival. México, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=GUEROS|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3499048/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1|website=IMDB|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref>
===The ''Telenovelas'' (soap operas)===
*''[[Así en el barrio como en el cielo|Así en el Barrio como en el Cielo]]'' (English: So in the neighborhood as in heaven). A [[TV Azteca]] soap opera, produced by [[:es:Fides Velasco|Fides Velasco]] and written by Guillermo Ríos and Leticia López Margalli. The plot uses the Avándaro festival as its starting point and main base.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Perea|first1=Arturo|title=En Avándaro inicia su maleficio|url=http://www.reforma.com/aplicacioneslibre/preacceso/articulo/default.aspx?id=461677&sc=740&urlredirect=http://www.reforma.com/aplicaciones/articulo/default.aspx?id=461677&sc=740|accessdate=12 March 2015|agency=REFORMA|date=11 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Azteca America announces the premiere of Así en el Barrio como en el Cielo|url=http://hispanicad.com/el-blog/television/azteca-america-announces-premiere-as%C3%AD-en-el-barrio-como-en-el-cielo|website=Hispanicad|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> Mexico, 2015.
In May 2009 and then in May 2014, Luis de Llano, of [[Televisa]], formally announced that he was preparing a soap opera with the Avándaro festival as its background.<ref>{{cite news|title=De Llano regresa a Avandaro.|url=http://mundo52.com/musica/de-llano-regresa-avandaro|accessdate=24 October 2014|agency=Mundo 52|date=15 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Luis de Llano prepara telenovela sobre el festival de Avandaro|url=http://sipse.com/entretenimiento/luis-de-llano-prepara-telenovela-sobre-festival-de-avandaro-90195.html|accessdate=27 June 2014|agency=NOTIMEX|date=12 May 2014}}</ref>
== The Play == *''Avandaro'': A comedy written by Carlos Alfonso Nava and directed by Cristian Magaloni. Three women from very different walks of life check in at a hotel close to the festival. As they are getting ready to show up to the concert, things will not go as planned. The play received laudatory reviews by critics and the blessing of Alex Lora. Mexico, 2018.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rivera |first1=Niza |title=Microteatro 32: Rock con servicio a la carta. |journal=Proceso |date=April 5, 2018 |url=https://www.proceso.com.mx/528475/microteatro-32-rock-con-servicio-a-la-carta |accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Microteatro despide su 32º temporada "Por Rock". |url=http://www.laescaleta.mx/microteatro-despide-su-32o-temporada-por-rock/ |website=La Escaleta |accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref>
==Literature exclusively about Avandaro==
===Books=== *''Avándaro: Aliviane o movida?'' Book written by [[:es:José Vicente Anaya|Vicente Anaya]], Eligio Calderon, Carla Zenzes and José Luis Fernandez. Published by Editorial Extemporaneous, Mexico, 1971. *''[[Avándaro (Book)|Avándaro]]''. Book written by [[Luis Carrión Beltrán]] with pictures by [[Graciela Iturbide]], published by Editorial Diogenes. Mexico, 1971. *''Avándaro ¡Yeah, Yeah, Yeah!''. A collection of essays from different authors collected by Antonio Elizondo. Published by Editorial Paralelo 32, S.A. Mexico, 1971. *''La Trampa'' (The Trap). A three-part essay about the Mexican youth. Its third chapter, entitled ''El gran desafío : volver a pensar'' (The great challenge : to think again), deals with the festival. Written by Luis Garibay Gutiérrez, published by the [[Autonomous University of Guadalajara]]. Mexico, 1972. *''[[Nosotros (book)|Nosotros]]''. Comprehensive [[photo-book]] about the festival, written by ''Tinta Blanca's'' manager [[Humberto Rubalcaba Zuleta|Humberto Rubalcaba]], with collaborations from Karen Lee de Rubalcaba, Alfredo Gonzalez and Mario Ongay. Pictures by Jorge Bano, José Pedro Camus, Francisco Drohojowski and Joel Turok. Contains an often cited Prologue by world-renowned journalist [[Jacobo Zabludovsky]]. Editorial NOSOTROS. Mexico, 1972. *''Avandaro: Una leyenda'' (Avandaro: A legend). Book written by Juan Jiménez Izquierdo, a Festival attendee. Eridu Producciones. Mexico, 2011. *''Informe Avándaro 1971''. Published in 2014 but originally written in 1971 by intellectual Francisco Javier Estrada and politician Héctor Marín, then recently graduated from [[Normal school]]. According to their testimony, they were both appointed by the then General Direction of Public Education (the actual [[Secretaria de Educacion Publica|SEP]]) to make a report about the events of the festival.<ref>{{cite web|title=CONCLUYE MUSEO DE CULTURAS POPULARES EXPOSICIÓN DE ROCK|url=http://edomexinforma.com/2014/11/concluyeexposicionderock/|website=EI|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Quirarte|first1=Xavier|title=Avándaro, un testimonio|url=http://www.milenio.com/cultura/Festival_Avandaro-Avandaro_1971-libro_Avandaro_0_449955006.html|accessdate=8 February 2015|agency=MILENIO|date=21 Jan 2015}}</ref> Published by Casa del Poeta Laura Méndez de Cuenca, Mexico 2014. *''[[Yo estuve en Avándaro]]''. Written by Federico Rublí K. With photographs by Graciela Iturbide and a prologue by Luis de Llano. Trilce Ediciones. Mexico, 2016. *''Avandaro: Lo que se dijo y lo que no se habia dicho''. A yet-to-be-published book by Armando Molina Solis.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mendoza Mocino|first1=Arturo|title=Entrevista ''Avándaro... 30 años después. Lo que se dijo y lo que no se había dicho''|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2001/09/14/avandaro.html|accessdate=26 June 2014|publisher=La Jornada|date=14 September 2001}}</ref>
===Comics=== *''Aliviane a la Madre Tierra''. A series of comics produced by Carlos Baca about the adventures of "Avandarito" (Little Avandaro) and his friends. Published by ''Revista Pop'', Mexico 1971-1973.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Baca|first1=Carlos|title=Aliviane a la Madre Tierra|url=http://www.carlosbaca.mx/comic_portaditas.html|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref>
===Magazines=== Among many others, the most notorious ones were: *''[[Siempre!|SIEMPRE!]]: "Avandaro"''. Reputable political magazine. While it did not approve some of the excesses committed by the jipitecas, it defended the position taken by then governor [[Carlos Hank González|Hank]] and severely criticized the exaggerations of the media about the event. Mexico, 1971. *''Casos de Alarma: Avandaro, el infierno''. Exploitation magazine. Fictional story, purported to be real, about a troubled couple; a hippie woman (''La encuerada de Avandaro'') and a man with an opposing point of view of the Festival and the counterculture. Published by [[¡Alarma! (magazine)|Alarma]], Mexico 1971.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Avándaro: el Infierno|journal=Casos de Alarma|date=24 November 1971|volume=5889}}</ref> * ''Piedra Rodante: "La verdad sobre Avándaro"''. La Onda magazine. In-depth reportages about the festival including the renown "Dios quiere que llueva para unirnos" by liberal priest Enrique Marroquin. Published by Editoriales Tribales S.A., México, 1971. * ''Por Que?: "Avándaro: Miseria del régimen"''. Left-leaning magazine. In-depth reportage criticizing La Onda hippies and the festival, according to the magazine's political point of view. Published by Mario Menéndez. México 1971. * ''Cancionero internacional de oro En Onda: "Festival 11 de septiembre de 1971". Music magazine. In-depth reportage about the festival and the band Peace & Love. México, 1971. * ''Alerta: "Musica, droga y sexo: El frenesi de Avándaro"''. Exploitation magazine.. México, 1971. * ''Figuras de la cancion: "La noche de Avándaro"''. Music magazine. In-depth reportage about the festival and the band Three Souls in my Mind. The magazine was an instant hit, selling 100,000 units in its release.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hernandez|first1=Javier|title=EN EL CHOPO|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2004/08/28/23an1esp.php?origen=espectaculos.php&fly=2|accessdate=28 February 2015|agency=La Jornada|date=28 August 2004}}</ref> México, 1971. * ''POP: "Avándaro"''. Music magazine, which included the famous comic "Aliviane a la Madre Tierra" by Carlos Baca. México, 1971.
==Soundtracks==
===Live soundtrack=== *''[[Avandaro (soundtrack)|Avandaro: Por fin...32 años después]]''. Released by Luis de Llano's own company Bakita-Ludell Records and produced by Javier Tena. Initially to include only 12 live tracks, the final product includes 17 live tracks as recorded in the festival. The CD was presented at the [[Hard Rock Café]] in Mexico City. Comprehensive description by Armando Molina. Mexico, 2003.<ref>{{cite journal|title=PLATOS LÁSER: Editan disco sobre Avándaro|journal=Proceso|date=August 9, 2003|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/255202/platos-laser-editan-disco-sobre-avandaro|accessdate=7 July 2016}}</ref>
===Other soundtracks=== *''La Fachada de Piedra en Avandaro Valle de Bravo''. An EP with four studio tracks produced by [[:es:Discos Orfeón|Discos Orfeon]], Mexico 1971. *''Love Army en Avandaro''. An EP with four studio tracks produced by Discos Orfeon, Mexico 1971. *''Los Free Minds en Avandaro Valle de Bravo''. An EP of four studio tracks produced by Discos Orfeon, Mexico 1971. *''Los Soul Masters en Avandaro Valle de Bravo''. An EP of four studio tracks produced by Discos Orfeon, Mexico 1971.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Discogs|title=Los Soul Masters en Avandaro Valle de Bravo|url=http://www.discogs.com/Soul-Masters-2-Los-Soul-Masters-Los-Soul-Masters-En-Avandaro/release/5154532|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> *''Super Onda Chicana Vol. II: Vibraciones del 11 de Septiembre de 1971''. Compilation by [[:es:Interscope-Geffen-A&M|Fontana Records]], which [[Billboard (magazine)|BILLBOARD]] magazine incorrectly labelled as a Live Recording of the event, Mexico 1971.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ortiz |first1=Enrique |title=From the music capitals of the world |journal=Billboard |date=1972 |volume=84 |issue=15 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=BkUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT76&lpg=PT76&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> *''Rosario: Avandaro'': Hit single by the band Rosario, issued by Philips. Mexico, 1972. *''Rock en Avandaro''. A compilation of twelve studio tracks produced by Discos Orfeon, re-issued in CD in 2005. Mexico 1972.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Discogs|title=Rock en Avandaro Valle de Bravo|url=http://www.discogs.com/Various-Rock-En-Avandaro-Valle-De-Bravo/release/2934217|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> *''Tinta Blanca: Avandaro''. Hit single from Tinta Blanca, issued by Philips. Mexico, 1971. *''Tinta Blanca: Ecos de Avandaro''. A re-issue of the band's 1971 hit single "Everything's gonna change" originally released by Philips. Re-issued by Cisne RAFF, Mexico 1973. *''Coleccion Avandaro''. LP, CD and Cassette re-issues by Discos y Cintas Denver of Peace & Love and El Ritual's debut albums as well as Three Souls in my Mind's first two albums. Mexico, 1985-1987-1992-1999.<ref>{{cite web |title=Discos y Cintas Denver |url=https://www.discogs.com/en/label/238298-Discos-Y-Cintas-Denver |website=DISCOGS |accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> *''Vibraciones de Avandaro''. A compilation of studio tracks produced by [[PolyGram|PolyGram Records]] in 1994 and re-issued in 1996 to celebrate the festival's 25th anniversary. Mexico, 1994-1996. *''Festival de Rock y Ruedas en Avandaro Valle de Bravo''. A compilation of studio tracks of different bands produced by [[Universal Music Group|Universal Music]], Mexico 2002. *''[[Ecos de Avandaro]]''. A double CD compilation with studio works of different bands. Produced by [[Sony BMG|Sony BMG Music Entertainment]], Mexico 2007.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Garcia Barcenas|first1=Arturo|title=Lanzan Ecos de Avandaro, con primicias en cidi del rock chicano|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2007/07/11/index.php?section=espectaculos|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=La Jornada|date=11 July 2007}}</ref>
==Curiosities==
===''La encuerada de Avandaro''=== In spite the spirit of the age and that many people were completely naked swimming in the lake, walking in the middle of the crowd or even on stage without a problem as can be seen in the film, one woman, as the band La Division del Norte was playing, performed a [[striptease]] and caught the attention of the cameras. Her strip-tease was captured in the Gurrola film and shots of her appeared in many other media. When the footage and pictures were shown, the public baptized the woman as ''La encuerada''(the naked woman).<ref name="Woldberg"/> The woman was interviewed on-site by Elena Poniatowska;<ref>{{cite web|title=Los muchachos de entonces, entrevista con Elena Poniatowska|url=http://www.nexos.com.mx/?p=5033|website=NEXOS|publisher=Nexos|accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> however, another interview, thought to have been real for decades, was published in the rock magazine ''Piedra Rodante'' in late 1971.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Benitez|first1=José Luis|title=Entrevista a la encuerada de Avandaro|url=http://www.chilango.com/musica/nota/2014/03/25/la-entrevista-original-a-la-encuerada-de-avandaro|publisher=Piedra Rodante|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> In 2001, a bitter dispute between the owner of ''Piedra Rodante'' Manuel Aceves and then collaborator and music critic Oscar Sarquiz about the veracity of the interview took place in ''La Jornada'' newspaper.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sarquiz|first1=Oscar|title=De Sarquiz a Aceves-De Aceves a Sarquiz. Entrevista Armando Molina|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2001/09/14/avandaro.html|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=La Jornada|date=14 September 2001}}</ref> Finally, it was confirmed by Federico Rubli and further explained in the TV Azteca documentary that the interview was completely bogus.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rubli K.|first1=Federico|title=Estremécete y Rueda|year=2007|publisher=Casa Veerkamp|isbn=978-9685546027|edition=First}}</ref> A few years after the festival the band Three Souls in my Mind composed a song called ''La encuerada de Avandaro'' which would become a hit in the underground movement.<ref name="Woldberg">{{cite news|last1=Woldberg|first1=José|title=La encuerada de Avandaro|url=http://www.debate.com.mx/eldebate/noticias/default.asp?IdArt=11282159&IdCat=6115|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=El Debate|date=9 August 2011}}</ref>
===The lost Telesistema Mexicano videotapes=== Shot by Telesistema Mexicano cameramen under direction of [[Carlos Alazraki]], those tapes were destined to become part of the planned TV special but were confiscated by their own company as soon as Luis de Llano showed up for work. Some footage of these tapes has been released since 1971 in movies and documentaries. In a 2001 interview, Luis de Llano recalled this situation and stated that may he find the tapes he will produce a movie with them though it is widely believed that they were sent to a storage in [[Tijuana]], and that years later the whole place burnt out. He also made clear that, contrary to popular belief, the [[Secretariat of the Interior (Mexico)|Secretariat of the Interior]] did not confiscate the tapes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mendoza Mocino|first1=Arturo|title=Gracias a Zabludovsky y Timbiriche, la llama del rock sigue viva: Luis de Llano|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2001/09/14/02an2esp.html|accessdate=24 June 2014|publisher=La Jornada|date=14 September 2001}}</ref> An independent investigation, as shown in the ''Las glorias de Avandaro'' documentary, made as a request through the Federal Institute of access to information ([[:es:IFAI|IFAI]]) produced the official document proving that, indeed, the government did not confiscate the tapes.
===Booked acts who failed to show up=== *[[Love Army]] - As stated by the former band singer Pajaro Alberto in the ''Glorias de Avandaro'' documentary, the band suffered a minor car accident while on the road from Mexico City to Avandaro. *[[La Tribu (Mexican rock band)|La Tribu]] - As stated by Armando Molina in the live soundtrack, La Tribu cancelled at the very last minute but their record company, [[Polydor Records|Polydor]], sent La Division del Norte in their place.
===Acts who declined to participate=== *La Revolucion de Emiliano Zapata: As stated by member Javier Martin del Campo in the fair use trailer for ''Bajo el sol y frente a Dios'' documentary, the band was already booked for September 11 to appear in Monterrey. As the band was heading north, they saw thousands of fans going south for the festival.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lara Lozano|first1=Arturo|title=Javier Martin del Campo en el documental de Avandaro|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Oq2O-eVFv4E|publisher=Enciclopedia del rock mexicano|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> *Javier Batiz: As stated on the fair use TV Azteca documentary ''La historia detras del mito: Avandaro'', he considered Molina's payment offer too low. Later, he regretted his decision and tried, together with his sister singer Baby Batiz some members of ''Los Locos'' and his girlfriend, to get to the festival but were stranded in the traffic jam and his girlfriend at the time got ill while on the road.
==Legacy== The festival remains a controversial issue in Mexican society.<ref>{{cite news|title=A 30 de años de Avándaro.|url=http://hemeroteca.imagenzac.com.mx/2001/09/11/Sociales3.htm|accessdate=24 February 2015|agency=NOTIMEX|publisher=IMAGEN|date=11 September 2001}}</ref> After the festival, Mexican rock music was almost banned and was segregated to the so-called ''Hoyos Funkies'', illegal gatherings in abandoned warehouses and supported mostly by the proletariat. A few years after the festival the hippie movement around the world collapsed and Mexico's La Onda was no exception, giving way to the ascension of other music genres of the mid-1970s such as [[Disco]], [[Urban rock]], [[Punk rock|Punk]], [[Romantic ballad|Romantic Ballads]], [[Heavy metal music|Heavy Metal]], [[Progressive rock]] and, exclusively in the Mexican scene, the ''Rupestre movement'' championed by [[Rockdrigo Gonzalez]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Villarreal|first1=Rogelio|title=La larga noche de Avándaro|url=http://clarimonda.mx/la-larga-noche-de-avandaro/|publisher=Clarimonda|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Canales|first1=Miriam|title=ROCK MEXICANO: DEL HOYO FUNKIE A LA LUZ|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/06-04-2013/549229|website=SIN EMBARGO|accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref>
The world-class quality of the bands that participated is generally praised and while the festival is little by little being acknowledged by official publications from respected institutions such as [[INEGI]] and [[Colegio de México|COLMEX]] <ref>{{cite book|title=Historia minima de México ilustrada|year=2008|publisher=COLMEX-Secretaria de edicacion del gobierno del DF|location=COLMEX|page=513|edition=1st|url=http://www.colmex.mx/pdf/historiaminima.pdf|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=125 años de la DGE|year=2009|publisher=INEGI|location=INEGI|isbn=978-970-13-5159-8|page=141|edition=1st|url=http://www.inegi.org.mx|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref> is still not completely accepted as part of the official Mexican history class, but it's often regarded as a milestone in the history of rock music, the hippie movement and [[Aftermath of World War II|post-WWII]] Mexican society in general.<ref>{{cite news|last1=de Llano Macedo|first1=Luis|title=Avándaro: mitos, hechos, dichos y actualidad|url=http://www2.esmas.com/entretenimiento/musica/noticias/203665/|accessdate=27 June 2014|agency=ESMAS|date=13 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cisneros|first1=Ernesto|title=Avándaro: ¿cuarenta años de qué?|url=http://sonnigetage.wordpress.com/2011/11/16/avandaro-cuarenta-anos-de-que/|website=Sonnigetage|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref>
==Picture gallery== Photographer [[Pedro Meyer]], himself an Avandaro attendee, produced a collection named ''Avandaro 1971'', available online.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meyer|first1=Pedro|title=Avandaro 71|url=http://www.pedromeyer.com/galleries/avandaro/|publisher=Pedro Meyer|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
In 2016, the [[Museo Universitario del Chopo]] in Mexico City, exhibited a collection of Avandaro photographs taken by [[Graciela Iturbide]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Avandaro, bajo la mirada de Iturbide|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/articulo/cultura/artes-visuales/2016/09/13/avandaro-bajo-la-mirada-de-iturbide|accessdate=22 December 2016|agency=El Universal|date=13 September 2016}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Rock music}} *[[List of historic rock festivals]] *[[List of historic music festivals]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
== Further reading == *{{Cite book | last = Agustin | first = José | title = Tragicomedia Mexicana Vol. 2 | publisher = Debolsillo | year = 2013 | asin = B00DUGYL4M }}
*{{Cite book | last = de Llano Macedo | first = Luis | title = Expedientes Pop | publisher = Planeta | year = 2016 | isbn = 978-607-07-3582-0 }}
*{{cite book | last = Cruz | first = Octavio Hernandez | title = A 25 Años del Festival de Rock y Ruedas en Avandaro | work = | pages = 4 | language = | publisher = ''La Banda Elástica'' | date = Oct–Nov 1996 | url = | accessdate = }} *{{Cite book | last = Rodríguez O. | first = Jaime |author2=Kathryn Vincent | title = Common Border, Uncommon Paths: Race, Culture, and National Identity in U.S.-Mexican Relations | publisher = Rowman & Littlefield | year = 1997 | isbn = 0-8420-2673-8 }} *{{Cite book | last = Zolov | first = Eric | title = Refried Elvis: The Rise of the Mexican Counterculture | publisher = University of California Press | year = 1999 | isbn = 0-520-21514-1 }} *{{Cite book | last = Monsivais | first = Carlos | title = Dias de Guardar | publisher = Editorial Era | year = 1970 | isbn = 9684111886 }} *{{Cite book | last = Garcia | first = Parmenides | title = La ruta de la onda | publisher = Editorial Diogenes | year = 1972 }} *{{Cite book | last = Pacini Hernandez | first = Deborah | title = Rockin Las Americas: The Global Politics Of Rock In Latin/o America | publisher = University of Pittsburgh Press | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-0822958413 }} *{{Cite book | last = Rubli | first = Federico | title = Estremécete y Rueda: Loco por el Rock & Roll | publisher = Casa Veerkamp | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-9685546027 }} *{{Cite book | last = Arana | first = Federico | title = Guaraches de ante azul | publisher = Editorial Posada | year = 1985 | isbn = 978-9684331419 }} *{{Cite book | last = Marroquin | first = Enrique | title = La contracultura como protesta | publisher = Editorial Mortiz | year = 1975 }}
==External links== {{Commons category|Festival Rock y Ruedas de Avándaro}} *[http://www.siempre.mx/2015/11/festival-de-avandaro/ SIEMPRE!: Festival de Avándaro.] Fair-use ISSUU powered document of the magazine's Avandaro special. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=09ZD5UrOKIU Avandaro: The Play.] Fair-use trailer of the play with the same name. From Alegoria TV channel. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4nMOVIsEJQo Tinta Blanca en Avandaro]. Humberto Rubalcaba's short film, available for fair-use. No sound and with watermark. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-UnJ5FMfaX8 Maravillas y Curiosidades de la Filmoteca de la UNAM: Avandaro]. Fair use TV special, from TV UNAM's official YT channel. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1DVR66NZBHk Observatorio Cotidiano: 45 años de Avándaro]. Fair use TV special, from TV UNAM's official YT channel. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iaxat3VosiQ Pantalla de Cristal: Enrique Quintero Marmol]. Fair use CONACULTA video interview from Quintero Marmol's own YouTube channel. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H6_WPXNurMI In Memoriam: Avandaro]. Documentary from Canal Once IPN. Available for fair use from the Producer's channel. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7-u5MQx1J14 Documental 1968-1971: Los Jefes del Rock.] Fair use documentary from the official Canal 22-CONACULTA YouTube channel. *[https://www.youtube.com/user/AztecaNovelasHD/videos Así en el Barrio como en el Cielo]. Free streaming TV Azteca's Telenovela based on the Avandaro festival. Free streaming authorized by and from the official TV Azteca [[YouTube]] channel. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yj9Nk6bLE_A Memoria Viva de Ciertos Días - Festival de Avándaro]. Fair use documentary produced by [[CONACULTA]]. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DNbnbgb61DE Avándaro, Imágenes Inéditas]. Fair-use posthumous documentary by Sergio Garcia, available from Cultura Independiente channel. *[http://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft5q2nb3w6&brand=ucpress Refried Elvis: The rise of the Mexican counterculture]. Available as e-book for fair use from the [[University of California Press]] website. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M32qZEHqJG4 Rafael Catana: Armando Molina en Pueblo de Patinetas]. In-depth video/radio interview with festival co-organizer Armando Molina. *[http://www.pedromeyer.com/galleries/avandaro/ ''Avandaro 1971'']. Collection of art photos by Pedro Meyer. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VluRoXlIY_8 BACK]. Fair use documentary about rock music in Guadalajara and the bands that were involved in the Avandaro festival. Contains interviews with musicians from La Fachada de Piedra, Spiders, 39.4, La Revolucion de Emiliano Zapata and more. From the official channel of 39.4 singer Larry Sanchez as professor of the [[Universidad Autónoma de Guadalajara|UAG]], its producer. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ePrgvbaKSPQ Historias Engarzadas: Alex Lora.] Fair use documentary about El TRI's frontman Alex Lora, his involvement in the Avandaro festival and career in general. Contains interviews with Three Souls in my Mind drummer Charlie Hauptvogel, La Onda writer José Agustin, impresario Armando Molina and more. [[TV Azteca]]-approved YT channel. *[http://uvideos.com/shows/susana-adiccion/la-represion-de-avandaro SuSana Adiccion: La represion de Avandaro]. Fair use spots of the TV special available in the [[Univision]] website. Interviews with filmmaker Alfredo Gurrola, producer Luis de Llano and more. *[https://www.scribd.com/doc/68941180/Nosotros-1972-Libro-Sobre-el-Festival-de-Avandaro Nosotros]. 1972 book by Humberto Rubalcaba, available for fair use in Scribd. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sm20CtGEAYQ Avandaro], Fair use super 8 shortfilm produced by Luis Gutierrez y Prieto and directed/edited by Alfredo Gurrola, 1971. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uLGYhsp5Rdc Las glorias de Avandaro]. Fair use and independently produced documentary by Arturo Lara Lozano, Carlos Cruz, Manuel Martinez, Angel Velazquez and Arnulfo Martinez y Torres, Mexico 2005. *[http://www.azteca.com/capitulos/lahistoriadetrasdelmito/151078/la-historia-detras-del-mito-de-avandaro La historia detras del mito: Avandaro] A fair use documentary produced by TV Azteca, 2013. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WDgVrNpM0og Programa especial "El observador": 40 años de Avándaro, Parte 1]. First part of a fair use special program produced by Television Metropolitana S.A. de C.V.-Canal 22. Consejo Nacional para la Cultura y las Artes, 2013. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4KPcMIUOTn4 Programa especial "El observador": 40 años de Avándaro, Parte 2]. Second part of a fair use special program produced by Television Metropolitana S.A. de C.V.-Canal 22. Consejo Nacional para la Cultura y las Artes, 2013. *[http://www.appalachiangetaways.com/Avandaro%20Mexican%20Woodstock.html The Day that Rock Music in Mexico was Forced Underground]. From the Appalachian Getaway Magazine, 2005. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141015165446/http://www.carlosbaca.mx/comic_portaditas.html ''Aliviane a la Madre Tierra'']. Carlos Baca's official website. Avandaro Comics and pictures available for fair use. *[https://enriquemarroquinz.wordpress.com/ Enrique Marroquin]. Enrique Marroquin's official website. Pictures and Avandaro/La Onda-related content available for fair use. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141017151602/http://amar.hsclib.sunysb.edu/cdm/landingpage/collection/rodante Piedra Rodante]. Complete collection of the iconic [[La Onda]] tabloid available for fair use by [[Stony Brook University]]. *[http://www.alfredogurrola.com Alfredo Gurrola]. Gurrola's official website which includes free links to his Avandaro iconic film and more. {{Historic rock festival}} {{Rock festivals}}

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=September 2013}} {{refimprove|date=August 2013}} }} '''Halfway Jam''' was an 1980s music festival in [[Royalton, Minnesota]] (minutes outside [[St. Cloud, Minnesota|St. Cloud]], and an hour north of [[Minneapolis]]) that takes place generally in the later part of July until more recently with newer bands being added.<ref>{{cite news | title = Halfway Jam celebrates 10 years of rock | url = http://www.sctimes.com/article/20130725/ENT02/307250011/Halfway-Jam-celebrates-10-years-rock | work = St. Cloud Times | date = July 24, 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130729081114/http://www.sctimes.com/article/20130725/ENT02/307250011/Halfway-Jam-celebrates-10-years-rock | archivedate = July 29, 2013 | df = }}</ref>
The Jam is now a 3-day event (Thur-Sat) which draws 6-9K per night and allows on-site camping. Started as a Friday/Saturday event, Halfway added a 3rd day that was initially tribute bands, but started adding original acts in 2011.
The festival started in 2003 & drew around a thousand people until the promoters started booking the more name bands. There is a second stage (Rhino Stage) that features local/tribute bands from the area that plays in between main stage acts.
2004: Johnny Holms, Killer Hayseeds, Rollie Show, High Noon
2005: Blue Oyster Cult, Guess Who, Foghat
2006: Credence Clearwater Revisited, Eddie Money, Georgia Satellites, Badfinger
2007: [[Ted Nugent]], [[Night Ranger]], Starship w/Mickey Thomas, [[Quiet Riot]], Guess Who
2008: [[Jackyl]], [[Drowning Pool]], [[Everclear (band)|Everclear]], [[Cracker (band)|Cracker]], [[Head East]], [[The Romantics]], [[Marshall Tucker]], [[Georgia Satellites]], [[Kentucky Headhunters]], [[Grand Funk Railroad]], [[The Smithereens]]
2009: [[Dokken]], [[Skid Row (American band)|Skid Row]], [[Jackyl]], [[Great White]], [[Bulletboys]], [[April Wine]], [[The Sweet|Sweet]]
2010: [[Tesla (band)|Tesla]], [[Dokken]], [[LA Guns]], [[Winger (band)|Winger]], [[Warrant (American band)|Warrant]], [[Vince Neil]]
2011: [[Quiet Riot]], [[Firehouse (band)|Firehouse]], [[Stephen Pearcy]], [[Kix (band)|Kix]], [[Cinderella (band)|Cinderella]], [[Slaughter (band)|Slaughter]], [[Lita Ford]], [[Skid Row (American band)|Skid Row]]
2012: [[Bang Tango]], [[Trixter]], [[Jackyl]], [[Blackfoot (band)|Blackfoot]], [[Molly Hatchet]], [[38 Special (band)|38 Special]], [[Enuff Z'nuff]], [[Lynch Mob (band)|Lynch Mob]], [[Stryper]], [[Queensrÿche]] (first show w/new singer [[Todd La Torre]])
2013: [[Pop Evil]], [[Saliva (band)|Saliva]], [[Smile Empty Soul]], [[Bulletboys]] (cancelled a week before Jam), [[Jack Russell (musician)|Jack Russell]]'s Great White, [[Survivor (band)|Survivor]], [[Tesla (band)|Tesla]], [[Steelheart]], [[Ratt]], [[Loverboy]]
2014: Honeymoon Suite, Winger, Vixen, Kix, Sebastian Bach, Firehouse, April Wine, Jackyl
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{official website|http://halfwayjam.com/}}
[[Category:Rock festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Jam band festivals]]
{{music-festival-stub}}
