{{About|the management style in business|micromanagement in video gaming|Micromanagement (gameplay)}}
In [[business]] [[management]], '''micromanagement''' is a management style whereby a manager closely observes and/or controls the work of his/her subordinates or [[employee]]s.
Micromanagement is generally considered to have a negative [[connotation]], mainly due to the fact that it shows a lack of freedom in the workplace.<ref name=Chambers>Chambers, Harry (2004). [http://www.bkconnection.com/static/mywayPR.pdf ''My Way or the Highway'']. Berrett Koehler Publishers, San Francisco. Retrieved on 20 June 2008.</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Micromanagement |newspaper=Small Business Resource Centre (2006) |url=http://www.smbresource.com/micromanagement.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724040432/http://www.smbresource.com/micromanagement.html |archivedate=24 July 2008 |df= }}</ref>
==Definition== [[Merriam-Webster's Online Dictionary]] defines<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/micromanage "Micromanage"], via ''Merriam-Webster's Online Dictionary''.</ref> micromanagement as "manage[ment] especially with excessive control or attention on details". [[Reference.com|Dictionary.com]] defines micromanagement as "manage[ment] or control with excessive attention to minor details".<ref>Dictionary.com (2008). [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/micromanage ''Definition of micromanage'']. Retrieved on 21 June 2008.</ref> The online dictionary [[Encarta]] defined micromanagement as "atten[tion] to small details in management: control [of] a person or a situation by paying extreme attention to small details".<ref>Encarta Dictionary (2008). [http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/refpages/search.aspx?q=micromanage ''Definition of micromanage'']. Retrieved on 21 June 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/5kx5yd3aW?url=http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/refpages/search.aspx?q%3Dmicromanage Archived] 2009-11-01.</ref>
The notion of micromanagement can be extended to any social context where one person takes a [[bullying|bully]] approach in the level of control and influence over the members of a group. Often, this excessive obsession with the most minute of details causes a direct management failure in the ability to focus on the major details.<ref name=Chambers/>
==Symptoms== Rather than giving general instructions on smaller tasks and then devoting time to supervising larger concerns, the micromanager monitors and assesses every step of a business process and avoids [[delegation]] of decisions.<ref name=McConnell>McConnell, Charles (2006). [http://www.nfib.com/object/IO_31411.html ''Micromanagement is Mismanagement'']. National Federation of Independent Business. Retrieved on 20 June 2008.</ref> Micromanagers are usually irritated when a subordinate makes decisions without consulting them, even if the decisions are within the subordinate's level of authority.
Micromanagement also frequently involves requests for [[TPS report#In popular culture|unnecessary and overly detailed reports]] ("reportomania"). A micromanager tends to require constant and detailed performance feedback and to focus excessively on procedural trivia (often in detail greater than they can actually process) rather than on overall performance, quality and results. This focus on "low-level" trivia often delays decisions, clouds overall goals and objectives, restricts the flow of information between employees, and guides the various aspects of a project in different and often opposed directions. Many micromanagers accept such inefficiencies as less important than their retention of control or of the appearance of control.
It is common for micromanagers, especially those who exhibit [[Narcissism|narcissistic]] tendencies and/or micromanage deliberately and for [[Strategy|strategic]] reasons, to [[delegate]] work to subordinates and then micromanage those subordinates' performance, enabling the micromanagers in question to both [[Plagiarism|take credit]] for positive results and [[Fall guy|shift the blame]] for negative results to their subordinates.<ref>Thomas, David. ''Narcissism: Behind the Mask'' (2010)</ref> These micromanagers thereby delegate accountability for failure but not the [[Ought implies can|authority to take alternative actions]] that would have led to success or at least to the mitigation of that failure.
The most extreme cases of micromanagement constitute a management pathology closely related to [[workplace bullying]] and [[narcissism|narcissistic]] behavior. Micromanagement resembles addiction in that although most micromanagers are behaviorally dependent on control over others, both as a lifestyle and as a means of maintaining that lifestyle, many of them fail to recognize and acknowledge their dependence even when everyone around them observes it.<ref name=Chambers/> Some severe cases of micromanagement arise from other underlying mental health conditions such as [[obsessive–compulsive personality disorder]]. (Renee Kowalski)
Although micromanagement is often easily recognized by employees, micromanagers rarely view themselves as such. In a form of [[denial]] similar to that found in addictive behavior, micromanagers will often rebut allegations of micromanagement by offering a competing characterization of their management style such as "structured", "organized", or "[[Perfectionism (psychology)|perfectionistic]]".
==Compared with mismanagement== Micromanagement can be distinguished from the mere tendency of a manager to perform duties assigned to a subordinate. When a manager can perform a worker's job more efficiently than the worker can, the result is merely suboptimal management: although the company suffers [[Opportunity cost|lost opportunities]] because such managers would serve the company even better by doing their own job (see [[comparative advantage]]). In micromanagement, the manager not only tells a subordinate what to do but dictates that the job be done a certain way regardless of whether that way is the most effective or efficient one.
==Causes== The most frequent motivations for micromanagement, such as detail-orientedness, [[emotional insecurity]], and doubts regarding [[Competence (human resources)|employees' competence]], are internal and related to the personality of the manager. Since manager-employee relationships include a difference in power and often in age, workplace psychologists have used models based on [[transference]] theory to draw analogies between micromanagement relationships and dysfunctional parent-child relationships, ''e.g.'', that both often feature the frequent imposition of [[double bind]]s and/or a tendency by the authority figure to exhibit [[Criticism#Hypercriticism|hypercriticality]].<ref name=Chambers/> However, external factors such as organizational culture, severe or increased time or performance pressure, severe demands of the regulatory environment, and instability of managerial position (either specific to a micromanager's position or throughout an organization) may also play a role.
In many cases of micromanagement, managers select and implement processes and procedures not for business reasons but rather to enable themselves to feel useful and valuable and/or create the appearance of being so. A frequent cause of such micromanagement patterns is a manager's perception or fear that they lack the competence and creative capability necessary for their position in the larger corporate structure. In reaction to this fear, the manager creates a "fiefdom" within which the manager selects performance standards not on the basis of their relevance to the corporation's interest but rather on the basis of the ability of the manager's division to satisfy them.
Such motivations for micromanagement often intensify, at both the individual-manager and the organization-wide level, during times of economic hardship. In some cases, managers may have proper goals in mind but place disproportionate emphasis on the role of their division and/or on their own personal role in the furtherance of those goals. In others, managers throughout an organization may engage in behavior that, while protective of their division's interests or their personal interests, harms the organization as a whole.
Micromanagement can also stem from a breakdown in the fundamentals of delegation. When a task or project is delegated in an unclear way, or where there is a lack of trust between the manager and the person doing the work, micromanagement naturally ensues. Clearer delegation, with a well defined goal, clear vision of the constraints and dependencies, and effective oversight, can help prevent micromanagement.<ref name="Canner and Bernstein">{{cite journal|last1=Canner|first1=Niko|last2=Bernstein|first2=Ethan|title=Why is Micromanagement So Infectious?|journal=Harvard Business Review|date=August 17, 2016|url=https://hbr.org/2016/08/why-is-micromanagement-so-infectious|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>
Less frequently, micromanagement is a tactic consciously chosen for the purpose of eliminating unwanted employees: A micromanager may set unreachable standards later invoked as grounds for termination of those employees. These standards may be either specific to certain employees or generally applicable but selectively enforced only against particular employees. Alternatively, the micromanager may attempt by this or other means to create a stressful workplace in which the undesired employees no longer desire to participate. When such stress is severe or pervasive enough, its creation may be regarded as [[constructive dismissal|constructive discharge]] (also known in the United Kingdom as "constructive dismissal" and in the United States as "constructive termination").
==Effects== Regardless of a micromanager's [[Motivation|motive]] for their conduct, its potential effects include: * Creation of ''[[ex post]]'' [[resentment]] in both ''vertical'' (manager-subordinate) and ''horizontal'' (subordinate-subordinate) relationships * Damage to ''[[ex ante]]'' trust in both vertical and horizontal relationships * Interference with existing [[teamwork]] and inhibition of future teamwork in both vertical relationships (''e.g.'', via [[malicious compliance]]) and horizontal relationships (''e.g.'', exploitation of [[moral hazard]] created by poorly proportioned effort-reward structures).
Because a pattern of micromanagement suggests to employees that a manager does not trust their work or judgment, it is a major factor in triggering employee disengagement, often to the point of promoting a dysfunctional and [[hostile work environment]] in which one or more managers, or even management generally, are labeled "control freaks."<ref>Bielaszka-DuVernay, Christina (2008). [http://discussionleader.hbsp.com/hmu/2008/02/micromanage-at-your-peril.php Micromanage at Your Peril] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120707150829/http://discussionleader.hbsp.com/hmu/2008/02/micromanage-at-your-peril.php |date=7 July 2012 }}. ''Harvard Business School Publishing Corporation''. Retrieved on 23 June 2008.</ref> Disengaged employees invest time, but not effort or creativity, in the work in which they are assigned. The effects of this phenomenon are worse in situations where work is passed from one specialized employee to another. In such a situation, apathy among upstream employees affects not only their own productivity but also that of their downstream colleagues.
Severe forms of micromanagement can completely eliminate trust, stifle opportunities for learning and development of interpersonal skills, and even provoke anti-social behavior. Micromanagers of this severity often rely on [[Culture of fear#In the workplace|inducing fear in the employees]] to achieve more control and can severely affect [[self-esteem]] of employees as well as their [[mental health|mental]] and [[physical health]]. Occasionally, and especially when their micromanagement involves the suppression of [[Criticism#Constructive criticism|constructive criticism]] that could otherwise lead to internal reform, severe micromanagers affect subordinates' mental and/or physical health to such an extreme that the subordinates' only way to change their workplace environment is to change employers or even leave the workplace despite lacking alternative job prospects (see [[constructive discharge]], ''[[Micromanagement#Causes|supra]]'').
Finally, the detrimental effects of micromanagement can extend beyond the company itself, especially when the behavior becomes severe enough to force out skilled employees valuable to competitors. Current employees may complain about micromanagement in social settings or to friend-colleagues (''e.g.'', classmates and/or former co-workers) affiliated with other firms in a field. Outside observers such as consultants, clients, interviewees, or visitors may notice the behavior and recount it in conversation with friends and/or colleagues. Most harmfully to the company, forced-out employees, especially those whose advanced skills have made them attractive to other companies and gained them immediate respect, may have few reservations about speaking frankly when answering questions about why they changed employers; they may even deliberately badmouth their former employer. The resulting damage to the company's reputation may create or increase insecurity among management, prompting further micromanagement among managers who use it to cope with insecurity; such a [[feedback]] effect creates and perpetuates a vicious cycle. It may follow the forced-out employee to the new job and create an environment of new micromanagement.
==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Abusive power and control]] * [[Blame in organizations]] * [[Control freak]] * [[Machiavellianism in the workplace]] * [[Megalomania]] * [[My way or the highway]] * [[Narcissism in the workplace]] * [[Narcissistic leadership]] * [[Overparenting]] * [[Psychopathy in the workplace]] * [[Seagull manager]] * [[Setting up to fail]] * [[Toxic leader]] * [[Toxic workplace]] }}
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * Harry Chambers: "My Way or the Highway: The Micromanagement Survival Guide", Berrett-Koehler Publishers (2004), {{ISBN|978-1-57675-296-8}} * Niko Canner and Ethan Bernstein: "[https://hbr.org/2016/08/why-is-micromanagement-so-infectious Why is Micromanagement So Infectious]?", Harvard Business Review, August 17
==External links== * [http://www.softpanorama.org/Social/Toxic_managers/micromanagers.shtml Softpanorama micromanagement page] * [http://www.transassoc.com/org-real-micromanagement Organizational Realities - Micromanagement: What It Is and How to Deal with It] * [https://www.thehrdigest.com/real-cost-micromanagement/ The Real Cost of Micromanagement]

{{advert|date=August 2015}}
{{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Mile of Music | image = [[File:Mile of Music Main Logo.jpg|300px]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = | location = [[Appleton, Wisconsin|Appleton]], [[Wisconsin]] | years_active = 2013-present | Creator/Producer = Dave Willems (marketing executive and community advocate); Willems Marketing staff | attendance = 65,000 - 75,000 | genre = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], Roots, [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Indie folk|Indie]], [[Indie rock]][[Singer/Songwriter]] | website = {{Official website|https://mileofmusic.com/}} }} '''Mile of Music''' (also known as '''MoM''' or '''The Mile'''{{cn|date=May 2017}}) is an annual [[Americana (music)|Americana]] and Roots music festival located in downtown [[Appleton, Wisconsin]]. Started in 2013, the four-day festival runs Thursday through Sunday and is a collaborative community event with support from nearly 50 business and community sponsors as well as 400 volunteers. The festival concept was created by long-time community advocate and marketing executive Dave Willems and his team at Willems Marketing, Inc., located in downtown. Willems recruited then Nashville-based touring artist and Appleton hometowner Cory Chisel to join the founding team along with Willems' staff at his marketing firm, which specializes in community and non-profit projects.
The festival features original, handcrafted Americana music of varying styles – [[Folk music|folk]] and [[indie rock]] to [[Soul music|soul]], [[Alternative (music)|alternative]] and [[Country music|country]] – with on average 225+ performers and nearly 1000 total performances. It's focus is on showcasing largely undiscovered, touring troubadours and bands with the mantra, "artists you may not know but should." The festival is "cover-free", meaning no cover songs and no cover charges. Almost every show at the festival is free to the public.
The festival's success over the years has benefited the local community, through significant creative economy impact as well as local youth music education and other scholarships.<ref>http://whby.com/index.php/News/WHBY_News/555622, WHBY News, August 20, 2015</ref>
The festival has spawned its own beer, the Americana Pale Ale by Stone Arch Brew House, a local brewery in the area.<ref>http://www.postcrescent.com/story/money/companies/buzz/2015/06/28/mile-of-music-beer-arrives-early/29352299/</ref>
==Events== The festival changes with each year, as it introduces more venues, and adds more charity events. The event is modeled after other music festivals, most notably [[South by Southwest]] in [[Austin, Texas]].<ref>http://www.sheboyganpress.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/01/07/cory-chisel-sheboygan/21400755/, Sheboygan Press, Jan 2015</ref>
===Mile 1 (2013)=== *Date: August 8–11, 2013 *Attendance: ~15,000 to 20,000<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scrippsmedia.com/nbc26/news/Million-Dollar-Impact-for-Mile-of-Music-270409921.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924095631/http://www.scrippsmedia.com/nbc26/news/Million-Dollar-Impact-for-Mile-of-Music-270409921.html |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref>
The inaugural year of the festival had over 220 performances in 40 venues.<ref>http://mileofmusic.com/2014/04/were-on-mile-2-announced/</ref> The 107 musical acts included [[Rodney Crowell]], [[Justin Townes Earle]], [[Cory Chisel and The Wandering Sons|Cory Chisel]], Hillary Reynolds Band, [[Nicole Atkins]], [[The Candles]] and an unofficial appearance by [[Norah Jones]].
===Mile 2 (2014)=== *Date: August 7–10, 2014 *Attendance: ~35,000<ref name="traction">http://www.jsonline.com/business/pressrelease/national-press-releases/mile-of-music-festival-gains-substantial-traction-in-second-year--has-estimated-economic-impact-of-nearly-2-million-271223011.html</ref>
The Mile of Music's sophomore year had more than 60 venues, had more than 200 performers,<ref name="Successful2">{{cite web |url=http://www.scrippsmedia.com/nbc26/news/Mile-of-Music-Wraps-Up-a-Successful-Second-Year-270687201.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924095629/http://www.scrippsmedia.com/nbc26/news/Mile-of-Music-Wraps-Up-a-Successful-Second-Year-270687201.html |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.postcrescent.com/article/20140424/APC0502/304240256/?nclick_check=1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924081012/http://www.postcrescent.com/article/20140424/APC0502/304240256/?nclick_check=1 |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref> and had 625 live performances. There were three 'main' stages for the festival, [[Lawrence University]]’s Memorial Chapel, and outdoor stages at Houdini Plaza and Jones Park. The festival generated nearly $2 million in economic development for the community. The four-day event featured Americana and Roots music.<ref name="traction"/>
Musical acts included performances by event co-founder and Appleton home-towner, [[Cory Chisel and The Wandering Sons|Cory Chisel]], [[The Autumn Defense]], [[Sturgill Simpson]], [[The Baseball Project]] and [[Butch Vig]] playing with The Emperors of Wyoming. [[Richie Ramone]] made a special guest appearance. Brooklyn-based [[Swear and Shake]] also returned for a surprise Mystery Music Stage performance at [[Lawrence University]]’s Stansbury Theatre. [[The Milk Carton Kids]] were scheduled to headline but cancelled. They were replaced by an outlaw-themed show including Cory Chisel, [[Langhorne Slim]] and [[Ruby Amanfu]].<ref>http://www.postcrescent.com/story/entertainment/music/mile-of-music/2014/08/01/milk-carton-kids-cancel/13471227/</ref>
New attractions included the Mile of Music Bus, which festival goers could board to hear live music from performers and pop-up performances along the mile-long stretch of Downtown Appleton. An expanded family-friendly music education series was also featured with over 30 events and workshops that offered different interactive experiences including bucket drumming and Balinese Gamelan. These events also included educators from the Appleton Area School District and Lawrence University.
This was the first year that the Mile of Music app was released for smartphones.
===Mile 3 (2015)=== *Date: August 6–9, 2015 *Attendance: ~50,000
The festival officially began on Thursday Aug. 6th, but a 'First Songs' concert was held the night before at the Fox Cities Performing Arts Center. The festival ended with a special concert called "Songs Before We Go," which was held at the Lawrence Memorial Chapel.
Musicians who partook in 2015 included [[The Milk Carton Kids]],<ref>http://www.postcrescent.com/story/entertainment/music/mile-of-music/2015/07/29/milk-carton-kids-make-good-mile-music-promise/30827117/</ref> [[Roadkill Ghost Choir]], [[Tim Barry]], [[Swear and Shake]], [[Wild Adriatic]], [[Cory Chisel and The Wandering Sons|Cory Chisel]], The Suitcase Junket, [[The Crane Wives]], [[Water Liars]] and Motherfolk.
As in the previous year, main stages were situated in the Memorial Chapel on Lawrence University's campus, and outdoor stages at the downtown Houdini Plaza and Jones Park. Some outdoor shows had to be moved indoors due to rain.<ref>http://wbay.com/2015/08/07/rain-postpones-outdoor-mile-of-music-concerts/</ref><ref>http://fox11online.com/news/local/fox-cities/the-show-goes-on-at-mile-of-music-despite-rain</ref>
More than 225 artists participated in 750 performances. Live music sets were held in more than 60 venues on or near College Avenue and along the riverfront.<ref>http://www.postcrescent.com/story/entertainment/music/mile-of-music/2015/08/10/early-estimates-put-mile-attendance/31407429/</ref>
===Mile 4 (2016)=== *Date: August 4-7, 2016 *Attendance: ~60,000
240 bands and troubadours performed 904 sets in the 2016 festival and included Aaron Lee Tasjan, Cory Chisel, Wild Adriatic, Jamie Kent and Kristin Diable.
Main stages were at the Lawrence Memorial Chapel, Houdini Plaza (outdoor), the OuterEdge Stage (indoor) and Jones Park (outdoor).
More than 65 Downtown Appleton venues participated in the 2016 festival.
Mile of Music also hosted its first-ever hip-hop showcase at Lawrence University's Stansbury Theatre.
===Mile 5 (2017)=== *Date: August 3-6, 2017
The 2017 festival featured 70 Downtown Appleton venues that hosted 950 live music sets from 250 artists.
Main stages included the Lawrence Memorial Chapel, Houdini Plaza, The OuterEdge Stage. Jones Park is under construction and will return for the 2019 festival. Washington Square served as a "replacement" for the park and became a popular venue. Festival organizers plan to utilize it as a permanent addition to the festival.
Artist included San Fermin, Ron Gallo, Bishop Gunn, Traveler, Tenement and Dan Rodriguez.

{{Infobox concert | concert_name = Most Wanted | image = Most Wanted (concert).jpg | image_size = 220px | landscape = yes | image_caption = Promotion poster for Most Wanted | artist = [[Daniel Padilla]] | type = [[Philippines]] | album = ''[[I Feel Good (album)|I Feel Good]]'' | start_date = {{Start date|2015|06|13|df=yes}} | URL = | last_tour = [[DOS (concert)|DOS]]
(2014) | this_tour = '''Most Wanted'''
(2015) | next_tour = [[DJ Classics: Back at the Araneta]]
(2017) }} '''Most Wanted''' is the third solo [[concert]] by [[Filipino people|Filipino]] [[actor]] and [[Recording artist|singer]] [[Daniel Padilla]], as support of his third full-length studio album, ''[[I Feel Good (album)|I Feel Good]]''. On June 13, 2015 at the [[Mall of Asia Arena]], Padilla sang 14 songs in total. These featured songs from his latest album, "Fly Me to the Moon", "How Sweet It Is (To be Loved by You)", and "Isn't She Lovely". He also sang duets, "Moon River" with [[KZ Tandingan]], "Nothing’s Gonna Stop Us Now" with "The Voice of the Philippines" finalist [[Morissette Amon]], "Moondance" with Kyla, and "So Real So Good" with [[Kathryn Bernardo]]. Other guests included ''Your Face Sounds Familiar'' finalists Nyoy Volante and Edgar Allan Guzman and the Harana Boys. ==Concerts== Padilla held a press conference for his "Most Wanted" concert at Dong Juan in Quezon City, on June 6, 2015.References for press conference of Padilla's "Most Wanted": * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170126212145/http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/entertainment/2015/06/06/daniel-padilla-attributes-success-best-people-showbiz-411678 Daniel Padilla attributes success to best people in showbiz"]. Archived from [http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/entertainment/2015/06/06/daniel-padilla-attributes-success-best-people-showbiz-411678 the original] on January 26, 2017 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20151016035349/http://starcinema.abs-cbn.com/latest-news/june/june6/10-revelations-from-daniel-padilla "10 revelations from Daniel Padilla"]. Archived from [http://starcinema.abs-cbn.com/latest-news/june/june6/10-revelations-from-daniel-padilla the original] on October 16, 2015. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160310022415/http://abscbnpr.com/daniel-to-conquer-moa-arena-with-most-wanted-concert-on-june-13/ "DANIEL TO CONQUER MOA ARENA WITH “MOST WANTED” CONCERT ON JUNE 13"]. Archived from [http://abscbnpr.com/daniel-to-conquer-moa-arena-with-most-wanted-concert-on-june-13/ the original] on March 10, 2016 The concert, held on June 13, 2015, was Padilla's first concert at the SM MoA Arena and also the first time to be directed by Johnny Manahan with musical direction by Marvin Querido.* for Padilla's first concert at the SM MoA Arena see: [https://web.archive.org/web/20170126191833/http://filipinojournal.com/daniel-padilla-waxes-nostalgic-in-moa-concert/ "Daniel Padilla waxes nostalgic in MoA concert"]. Archived from [http://filipinojournal.com/daniel-padilla-waxes-nostalgic-in-moa-concert/ the original] on January 26, 2017. * for Padilla's first time directed by Johnny Manaham with musical direction by Marvin Querido see: [https://web.archive.org/web/20170126190339/http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/likestyle/show-updates/2015/06/09/daniel-dedicates-most-wanted-gig-to-fans "Daniel dedicates ‘Most Wanted’ gig to fans"]. Archived from [http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/likestyle/show-updates/2015/06/09/daniel-dedicates-most-wanted-gig-to-fans the original]. on January 26, 2017. Padilla opened his concert with his song. His first guest was ''X Factor Philippines'' champion KZ Tandingan. He sang the duets "Moon River" and "Quando Quando" with her. While he went backstage, KZ Tandingan sang a solo, "Till I Met You". The next guests, ''Your Face Sounds Familiar'' finalists Nyoy Volante and Edgar Allan Guzman, sang [[Maroon 5]]'s "She Will Be Loved". A recording that showed Padilla's career in 2015 played, with the caption "Crazy and Beautiful". Then he sang his soundtrack contribution for his movie ''[[Crazy Beautiful You]]'', "Nothing's Gonna Stop Us Now", featuring Morissette Amon. After singing "What a Wonderful World", Padilla asked everyone to retweet the selfie that he took during his concert. He revealed that for every retweet, [[Pepsi]] Philippines will donate $1 to lighting projects that will benefit an Aeta community in [[Tarlac]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20170126191640/http://www.pep.ph/guide/photos/6987/most-wanted-photos-daniel-padilla-sings-ikaw-ang-aking-mahal-for-kathryn-bernardo "MOST WANTED PHOTOS: Daniel Padilla sings "Ikaw ang Aking Mahal" for Kathryn Bernardo"]. Archived from [http://www.pep.ph/guide/photos/6987/most-wanted-photos-daniel-padilla-sings-ikaw-ang-aking-mahal-for-kathryn-bernardo the original] on January 26, 2017. Padilla and Harana Boys then sang [[Eraserhead]]'s songs. Padilla then sang his remake of [[VST & Co.]]'s "Ikaw ang Aking Mahal". During this song, Bernardo's picture was revealed on the screen. The next guest was [[Kyla]], with whom Padilla sang the duet "Moon Dance". Then Padilla greeted [[Vice Ganda]], who was sitting in the front row, and sang "How Sweet It Is To Be Loved By You". The next guest is [[Gary Valenciano]], who performed solo on stage. The last guest was [[Kathryn Bernardo]], with whom Padilla shared the stage for "So Real So Good".[https://web.archive.org/web/20170126191640/http://www.psr.ph/index.php/highlights-daniel-padillas-wanted-concert/ "Highlights of Daniel Padilla’s ‘Most Wanted Concert’"]. Archived from [http://www.psr.ph/index.php/highlights-daniel-padillas-wanted-concert/ the original] on January 26, 2017. Unfortunately, Padilla was not able to perform his final song, "[[For Once in My Life]]", because the fans had become unruly, swarming the stage and forcing security to step in and whisk their idol backstage.[https://web.archive.org/web/20160205091824/http://entertainment.inquirer.net/172442/mr-dj-can-i-make-a-request "Mr. DJ, can I make a request?"]. Archived from [http://entertainment.inquirer.net/172442/mr-dj-can-i-make-a-request the original] on January 26, 2017. During this event, the actor announced that his fourth studio album, titled ''[[I Feel Good (album)|I Feel Good]]'', was already available.[https://web.archive.org/web/20170126191640/http://www.pep.ph/guide/photos/6987/most-wanted-photos-daniel-padilla-sings-ikaw-ang-aking-mahal-for-kathryn-bernardo "MOST WANTED PHOTOS: Daniel Padilla sings "Ikaw ang Aking Mahal" for Kathryn Bernardo"]. Archived from [http://www.pep.ph/guide/photos/6987/most-wanted-photos-daniel-padilla-sings-ikaw-ang-aking-mahal-for-kathryn-bernardo the original] on January 26, 2017. ==In media== Unlike his previous concert that only streamed live via Sky Cable's pay per view services in Metro Manila, Laguna, Rizal, Bacolod, Dumaguete, at General Santos City, this concert also streamed live in the cinemas of [[Shopping mall|mall]]s in [[Davao City|Davao]], [[Cebu]], [[Iloilo]], [[Cabanatuan]], [[Pampanga]], and [[Legazpi, Albay|Legazpi]].*[https://web.archive.org/web/20170126190339/http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/likestyle/show-updates/2015/06/09/daniel-dedicates-most-wanted-gig-to-fans "Daniel dedicates ‘Most Wanted’ gig to fans"]. Archived from [http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/likestyle/show-updates/2015/06/09/daniel-dedicates-most-wanted-gig-to-fans the original] on January 26, 2017. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20170126190007/http://www.mysky.com.ph/GenSan/updates/128/2015/06/08/daniel-padilla-s-most-wanted-concert-live-on-sky-pay-per-view "DANIEL PADILLA’S MOST WANTED CONCERT, LIVE ON SKY PAY-PER-VIEW!"]. Archived from [http://www.mysky.com.ph/GenSan/updates/128/2015/06/08/daniel-padilla-s-most-wanted-concert-live-on-sky-pay-per-view the original] on January 26, 2017. The Most Wanted concert also could be played during a limited period from ABS-CBNmobile-powered mobile devices.[https://web.archive.org/web/20160816010924/http://abscbnpr.com/daniel-padilla-reaches-out-to-fans-with-most-wanted-concert-on-demand-on-abs-cbnmobile/ "DANIEL PADILLA REACHES OUT TO FANS WITH “MOST WANTED” CONCERT ON-DEMAND ON ABS-CBNmobile"]. Archived from [http://abscbnpr.com/daniel-padilla-reaches-out-to-fans-with-most-wanted-concert-on-demand-on-abs-cbnmobile/ the original] on August 16, 2015. ==Setlist== {{hidden | headercss = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 65%; | contentcss = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 75%; | header = Setlist | content = '''Daniel intro''' * [[James Brown]]'s "I Feel Good (I Got You)" ''' First guest''' * "Moon River" (with [[KZ Tandingan]]) * "Quando Quando" (with [[KZ Tandingan]]) * "Till I Met You" ([[KZ Tandingan]]) '''Second guest''' * [[Maroon 5]] - "She Will Be Loved" (Nyoy Volante and Edgar Allan Guzman) '''VCR Crazy Beautiful 2015''' '''Third guest''' * "Nothing's Gonna Stop Us Now" (Morissette Amon) * "What a Wonderful World" '''Fourth guest''' * Eraserheads - "Kailan" * Eraserheads - "A Smile in your Heart" * [[VST & Co.]] "Ikaw Ang Aking Mahal" '''Fifth guest''' * "Moon Dance" (with Kyla) * "How Sweet It Is To Be Loved By You" '''Sixth guest: Gary Valenciano solo''' * "Just The Way You Are" * "Uptown Funk" '''KathNiel''' * "Pangako Sa'Yo" * "So Real, So Good" '''Encore''' * "[[For Once in My Life]]"{{efn|Padilla was not able to do this final song, because the fans came up to the stage and forced the security to step in and take him backstage.[https://web.archive.org/web/20160205091824/http://entertainment.inquirer.net/172442/mr-dj-can-i-make-a-request "Mr. DJ, can I make a request?"]. Archived from [http://entertainment.inquirer.net/172442/mr-dj-can-i-make-a-request the original] on January 26, 2017.}} }} ==Concert dates== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! Date ! City ! Country ! Venue ! Attendance |- | June 13, 2015 | [[Manila]] | [[Philippines]] | [[SM Mall of Asia Arena]] | |} ==Guests== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! Date ! Guest |- | June 13, 2015 |The Edgar Allan Guzman, Nyoy Volante, [[KZ Tandingan]], [[Morissette Amon]], [[Harana (band)|Harana]], [[Kyla]], [[Gary Valenciano]] and [[Kathryn Bernardo]][https://www.pressreader.com/philippines/philippine-daily-inquirer/20151229/282230894661079 "How Daniel Padilla Stay on Top of His Game"]. Archived from ''[[Manila Bulletin]]'' on ''Press Reader''. June 10, 2015 edition. Retrieved on January 29, 2015. |} ==Personnel== * Artists: [[Daniel Padilla]] * Concert organizer: [[ABS-CBN]] * Concert promoter: Star Events * Director: Johnny Manahan * Musical Director: Marvin Querido ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Daniel Padilla}} [[Category:Daniel Padilla]] [[Category:Concerts]]

{{Infobox person | name = Grégory Villemin | image = Grégory_Villemin.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Grégory Villemin | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1980|08|24}} | birth_place = France | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1984|10|16|1980|08|24}} | death_place = near [[Docelles]], France | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = [[France|French]] | other_names = | home_town = [[Lépanges-sur-Vologne]], France | parents = Jean-Marie Villemin
Christine Villemin | ethnicity = }} '''Grégory Villemin''' (24 August 1980 – 16 October 1984) was a French boy from [[Lépanges-sur-Vologne]] who was murdered at the age of 4. His body was found {{convert|7|km}} away in the [[Vologne]] River near [[Docelles]]. The case became known as the '''Grégory Affair''' ({{lang-fr|l'Affaire Grégory}}) and for decades has received widespread media coverage in France, where it continues to capture the public interest.{{cite news|publisher=The New York Times|title=All of France is asking: Who killed petit Gregory?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/07/16/world/all-of-france-is-asking-who-killed-petit-gregory.html|date=16 July 1985|accessdate=31 January 2017}} The murder remains unsolved.{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.fr/20130425/gregory-boy-murder-france-haunt|title=The smiling boy whose murder haunts France|publisher=The Local Fr|date=25 April 2013|accessdate=31 January 2017}} ==Preceding events== In the years preceding the murder, Gregory's parents, the Villemins, had been receiving anonymous letters and phone calls from a male threatening revenge against Grégory's father, Jean-Marie Villemin. This person, who had detailed knowledge of the extended Villemin family, was later referred to as ''Le Corbeau'' ("the Crow", French slang for "the informant").{{cite news|publisher=Los Angeles Times|title=COLUMN ONE : The Long Shadow of 'The Crow'|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-12-09/news/mn-65497_1_anonymous-letter|date=9 December 1993|accessdate=31 January 2017}} ==Murder== At 5 P.M 32. on 16 October 1984, an anonymous call was made to Gregory's uncle, stating that the boy had been taken and had been thrown into the [[Vologne|Vologne River]]. Grégory, who had been playing in front of his house, was later confirmed as a missing person, thus beginning a manhunt. Grégory's body was later found in the Vologne with his hands and feet bound with rope and a woolen hat pulled down over his face. ==Aftermath== [[File:Vologne-deycimont.JPG|thumb|The [[Vologne]], where Grégory Villemin's body was discovered]] On 17 October the Villemins received an anonymous letter that said "I have taken vengeance". Bernard Laroche, a cousin of Jean-Marie Villemin, was implicated in the murder by handwriting experts and by Laroche's sister-in-law and taken into custody on 5 November 1984. The sister-in-law later recanted her testimony and Laroche, who denied any part in the crime or being "the Crow", was released from custody on 4 February 1985. Jean-Marie Villemin vowed in front of the press that he would kill Laroche. On 25 March handwriting experts identified Grégory's mother Christine as the likely author of the anonymous letters. On 29 March 1985, Jean-Marie Villemin shot Laroche dead as he was leaving for work. Jean-Marie Villemin was convicted of murder and served 5 years in prison. In December 1986, Christine Villemin was charged with the murder, but was ultimately cleared of the charges on 2 February 1993.{{cite news|publisher=The Independent|title=Mother cleared in 'little Gregory' murder case|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/mother-cleared-in-little-gregory-murder-case-1470769.html|date=3 February 1993|accessdate=31 January 2017}} The case was reopened in 2000 to allow for DNA testing on a stamp used to send one of the anonymous letters, but the tests were inconclusive.{{cite news|publisher=France 24|title=Judge reopens case of four-year-old Gregory, murdered in 1984|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20081203-judge-reopens-case-four-year-old-gregory-murdered-1984-|date=6 December 2008|accessdate=31 January 2017}} In December 2008, following an application by the Villemins, a judge ordered the case reopened to allow DNA testing of the rope used to bind Grégory, the letters, and other evidence. This testing proved inconclusive. Further DNA testing in April 2013 on Grégory's clothes and shoes was also inconclusive. In June 2017, based on new evidence, three people were arrested.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=15 June 2017 |title=Gregory Villemin child murder: Three held in 1984 French mystery|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-40277466 |publisher=BBC|location= |access-date= }} Grégory's great-aunt and great-uncle, as well as an aunt—the widow of a biological uncle who died in 2010—were arrested on 14 June 2017. The aunt was released, while the great aunt and great uncle have invoked their right to remain silent. The police stated that they did not know who killed the child, but that there are multiple new suspects.{{cite news|last1=Blavignat|first1=Yohan|last2=Piquet|first2=Caroline|title=Affaire Grégory : «plusieurs personnes ont concouru» au crime|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/actualite-france/2017/06/14/01016-20170614ARTFIG00187-affaire-du-petit-gregory-trois-personnes-interpellees-dans-les-vosges.php|accessdate=16 June 2017|work=Le Figaro|date=14 June 2017|language=fr-FR}} On 11 July 2017, the magistrate in charge of the first investigation, Jean-Michel Lambert, committed suicide, citing in a farewell letter to a local newspaper the increasing pressure resulting from the reopening of the case.{{cite web|url=http://www.rtl.fr/actu/societe-faits-divers/affaire-gregory-l-ancien-juge-jean-michel-lambert-retrouve-mort-7789303749|title=Affaire Grégory : l'ancien juge Jean-Michel Lambert retrouvé mort|publisher=RTL|date=11 July 2017|accessdate=6 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714052001/http://www.rtl.fr/actu/societe-faits-divers/affaire-gregory-l-ancien-juge-jean-michel-lambert-retrouve-mort-7789303749|archivedate=14 July 2017|df=}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Villemin, Gregory}} [[Category:1980 births]] [[Category:1984 deaths]] [[Category:1984 crimes in France]] [[Category:1984 in France]] [[Category:October 1984 events]] [[Category:Murder in 1984]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in France]] [[Category:Murdered French children]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]]

page.title: NHRA Mello Yello Drag Racing Series

revision.text:
{{Infobox motorsport championship | logo = NHRA Mellow Yello Drag Series.png | pixels = | category = [[Drag racing]] | country/region = {{USA}} | inaugural2 = 1965 | drivers = | teams = | constructors = | tires = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]]
{{flagicon|Germany}} [[Continental AG|Continental (Pro Modified only)]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Hoosier Racing Tire|Hoosier]] (Pro Stock only but partial)
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Cooper Tire & Rubber Company]] (Pro Stock Motorcycles only) | champion driver = | champion team = | manufacturer = | current_season = 2019 NHRA Mello Yello Drag Racing Series | website = http://www.nhra.com }} The '''NHRA Mello Yello Drag Racing Series''' is a [[drag racing]] series organized by the [[National Hot Rod Association]] (NHRA). It is the top competition series of the NHRA, comprising competition in four classes, including [[Top Fuel|Top Fuel Dragster]], [[Funny Car]], [[Pro Stock]], and [[Pro Stock Motorcycle]]. The champion of each category is determined by a point system where points are given according to finishing placement and qualifying effort. The season is divided into two segments. After the first 18 races, the Top 10 of each pro category are locked in and compete in the last six races with the difference in points greatly minimized. ==History== The series has four main professional classes: [[Top Fuel|Top Fuel Dragster]], [[Funny Car]], [[Pro Stock]], and [[Pro Stock Motorcycle]]. Top Fuel was the first category, with Funny Cars added in 1966, Pro Stock four years later and Pro Stock Motorcycles in 1987. Both Top Fuel and Funny Cars regularly see top speeds in excess of {{convert|300|mph}} today, and one thousand foot times anywhere from 3.70 to 4 seconds. Both these cars burn fuel consisting of 90% [[nitromethane]] and 10% [[methanol]]. The Pro Stock record is {{convert|214|mph}}, with times often in the 6.4-6.7 second range and the Pro Stock Motorcycles usually run at 190+ mph ({{convert|190|mph|disp=output only}}), with times in the low 7- to high 6-second range. Top Fuel (class designation: AA/D top fuel dragster) and Fuel Funny Car (class designation: AA/FC top fuel coupe) have recently been limited to a {{convert|1000|ft|m|adj=on}} track, instead of the historic 1/4 mile [{{convert|1320|ft|m|0}}], as a means to limit top speeds and increase safety (there had been a number of engine explosions at or near 300 mph resulting in driver injuries and death). Currently, driver and spectator safety has been enhanced even while top speeds often approach and exceed 300 mph. Some of the popular racers to come through the series include [[Don Garlits|"Big Daddy" Don Garlits]], [[Don Prudhomme|Don "The Snake" Prudhomme]], and [[Shirley Muldowney]]. Those three gained much attention from the 1960s through 1970s with their speed and personalities, a combination rarely achieved today through the political correctness of sponsorship in today's drivers. Nonetheless there are still colorful characters today, such as 16-time Funny Car world champion [[John Force]]. His daughter, 2007 Rookie of the Year [[Ashley Force]] Hood has made appearances on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' and ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' and was voted AOL's Hottest Female Athlete in 2007.{{cite web | url=http://sports.aol.com/story/ar/_a/meet-the-hottest-athlete-in-sports/20070831141709990001 | title=Meet the Hottest Athlete in Sports |accessdate= 2009-09-08}}. On July 2, 2008, following the death of Funny Car driver [[Scott Kalitta]], the NHRA announced that race distances for Top Fuel and Funny Car classes would temporarily be reduced to 1,000 ft from the traditional 1/4 mile (1320 ft).[http://www.nhra.com/content/news/30355.htm NHRA News: In interim measure, Top Fuel, Funny Car to race 1,000 feet] The measure was intended to be temporary while safety solutions were explored; however, the races have remained at 1000 feet since Kalitta's death. Although unpopular with the fans, the distance remains at 1,000 feet today at the request of the teams as a cost-saving measure, with no indication by NHRA officials of any intent of returning to the full quarter-mile format any time soon. By late 2012, 1,000 foot racing became globally recognised as the 2012 FIA European title in Top Fuel became 1,000-foot championships, as [[Santa Pod Raceway|Santa Pod]] and [[Hockenheimring|Hockenheim]] (the last two quarter-mile nitro strips) made the switch, and [[Australian National Drag Racing Association|Australian]] nitro racing switched to the 1,000-foot distance only for selected tracks. ===The Countdown=== Starting with the 2007 season, the NHRA implemented a playoff system to determine the champion in each class, billed as the ''Countdown to The Championship''. Each season is divided into two segments of races, with the bulk of the races making up the first segment, and the final events making up the second segment. After the first segment is complete, the drivers in each class at or above the cutoff point in the standings (8th place up to 2007 and 10th place thereafter) become eligible for the championship, while the drivers below the cutoff point are eliminated from championship contention, though they still participate in the remaining race events. The points for the advancing drivers are readjusted so that they are separated by a fixed margin, with first place receiving bonus points. The drivers then compete for the championship over the final races of the season.{{cite web |url=http://countdown.nhra.com/content/general.asp?articleid=21167 |title=What is the Countdown? |accessdate=2009-11-16}} == Title sponsors == [[Winston (cigarette)|Winston cigarettes]] was the [[title sponsor]] of the series from 1975 until 2001, when a condition of the [[Master Settlement Agreement]] required Winston to drop either its sponsorship of the NHRA, or the [[NASCAR Winston Cup Series]]; Winston chose to retain its NASCAR sponsorship.{{cite news|title=After 27 Years, Series Goes Off Tobacco Road|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/nov/08/sports/sp-1765|accessdate=15 July 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 8, 2001}} Winston ended their sponsorship with NASCAR two years later. [[The Coca-Cola Company]] has since held the title sponsorship rights for the series, under a deal that, in 2012, was extended through 2018. From 2001 to 2008, the series was branded with the company's [[Powerade]] brand, before switching to [[Full Throttle (drink)|Full Throttle]] in 2009. In 2013, following Coca-Cola's most recent extension of its sponsorship, the title sponsor was changed to [[Mello Yello]].{{cite web|title=Mello Yello taking over as NHRA title sponsor|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2012/08/27/Marketing-and-Sponsorship/Mello-Yello.aspx|website=Sports Business Journal|accessdate=15 July 2015}} With Mello Yello having introduced a new logo, the NHRA unveiled a new logo for the series in January 2016, as well as a new "My NHRA" marketing campaign that plays upon the logo to feature drivers and other personalities discussing what the NHRA means to them.{{cite web|title=NHRA Mello Yello Drag Racing Series logo gets bold makeover|url=http://autoweek.com/article/nhra/nhra-mello-yello-drag-racing-series-logo-gets-bold-makeover|website=Autoweek}} ==Champions== [[File:2009NHRATopFuelChampTrophyTonySchumacher.jpg|thumb|upright|right|2009 [[Top Fuel]] trophy]] Before 1974, the season champion was determined by the winner of the World Finals event. The Professional categories contain the divisions of Top Fuel, Funny Car, Pro Stock (Automobile), and Pro Stock Motorcycle. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! [[Top Fuel]] ! [[Funny Car]] ! [[Pro Stock]] ! [[Pro Stock Motorcycle]] |- | 1965 || [[Maynard Rupp]] ||{{n/a}} || Gary Lawson||rowspan="22" align="center" bgcolor="silver"| Classification

Funny Car||2011, 2015 |- |Robert Hight||align="center"|2||Funny Car||2009, 2017 |- |Shirl Greer||align="center"|1||Funny Car||1974 |- |Richard Tharp||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||1976 |- |Larry Lombardo||align="center"|1||Pro Stock||1976 |- |Don Nicholson||align="center"|1||Pro Stock||1977 |- |Kelly Brown||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||1978 |- |Rob Bruins||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||1979 |- |Jeb Allen||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||1981 |- |Mark Oswald||align="center"|1||Funny Car||1984 |- |Dick LaHaie||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||1987 |- |Gary Ormsby||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||1989 |- |Bruce Larson||align="center"|1||Funny Car||1989 |- |John Mafaro||align="center"|1||Pro Stock Motorcycle||1989 |- |Eddie Hill||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||1993 |- |Geno Scali||align="center"|1||Pro Stock Motorcycle||2003 |- |Mike Edwards||align="center"|1||Pro Stock||2009 |- |Hector Arana||align="center"|1||Pro Stock Motorcycle||2009 |- |LE Tonglet||align="center"|1||Pro Stock Motorcycle||2010 |- |Jack Beckman||align="center"|1||Funny Car||2012 |- |Allen Johnson||align="center"|1||Pro Stock||2012 |- |Shawn Langdon||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||2013 |- |Ron Capps||align="center"|1||Funny Car||2016 |- |Jerry Savoie||align="center"|1||Pro Stock Motorcycle||2016 |- |Brittany Force||align="center"|1||Top Fuel||2017 |- |Bo Butner||align="center"|1||Pro Stock||2017 |} == Broadcasting == NHRA events have been broadcast on television, with such efforts dating back as far as 1985. By the 1990s, events were split between [[ESPN]], [[NBC Sports|NBC]], and [[Spike (TV network)|The Nashville Network]]. TNN also broadcast a weekly highlight program, ''NHRA Today''. Due to logistical and scheduling issues, including the possibility of long turnaround times between heats, weather delays, and other factors, events are typically broadcast in a condensed form via [[Broadcast delay|tape delay]]. From 1992 until 2000, TNN carried live coverage of selected final rounds, typically with a condensed package to air until the finals began.{{cite news|last1=Sharrington|first1=Kevin|title=Renovations, TV taking the credit for bigger, diverse crowds|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1990-10-28/sports/1990301134_1_drag-racing-restroom-facilities-meyer|accessdate=12 August 2015|work=Dallas Morning News|date=October 28, 1990}}{{cite news|title=NHRA still finding itself at mercy of TV networks|url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/sports/article/NHRA-still-finding-itself-at-mercy-of-TV-networks-5422818.php|accessdate=12 August 2015|work=Houston Chronicle|date=April 22, 2014}}{{subscription required}} In 2001, the NHRA entered into an agreement with ESPN for it to become the exclusive broadcaster of NHRA events, shortly after MTV Networks had effectively shut down the CBS motorsport operations after its acquisition of CBS Cable, and the demise of TNN. During its 14-year stint as rightsholder, ESPN faced criticism for the structure and scheduling of its coverage. Due to scheduling conflicts with other sports properties to which it held rights, ESPN typically broadcast its NHRA coverage in inconsistent and otherwise undesirable timeslots. In the final years of the contract, the NHRA attempted to structure selected events so that they could be televised live; by the 2015 season, at least six events were broadcast live. In July 2015, ESPN and the NHRA agreed to end their contract one year early, with the association citing ESPN's scheduling issues as a concern. In turn, the NHRA announced a new television deal with [[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]] beginning in the 2016 season. Coverage primarily airs on the [[Fox Sports 1|FS1]] and [[Fox Sports 2|FS2]] cable channels, while 4 events per-season are broadcast on [[Fox network|Fox]] (including the flagship U.S. Nationals). Fox committed to televising live Sunday coverage from at least 16 of the 23 events per-season, two-hour qualification broadcasts and encores (including the condensed highlights program ''NHRA in 30''), and coverage of selected Sportsman Series events. NHRA president Peter Clifford explained that the deal would be a "game-changer" for the association, citing Fox's history of motorsports programming, as well as its commitment to increased coverage of NHRA events, including live network television coverage.{{cite web|title=Sources: NHRA Races To Air On FS1, Ending 14-Year ESPN Tie-In|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Closing-Bell/2015/07/13/fs1.aspx|website=Sports Business Journal|accessdate=15 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=NHRA president calls move to Fox Sports in 2016 a 'game-changer' for series|url=http://autoweek.com/article/nhra/nhra-moving-fox-sports-2016|website=Autoweek|accessdate=15 July 2015}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/motorsports/2017/12/06/fox-tv-releases-2018-nhra-drag-racing-series-schedule/928916001/|title=Fox TV releases 2018 NHRA Mello Yello drag-racing series schedule|work=USA Today|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en}} During the first two years of the contract, Fox had achieved an average viewership of 600,000 viewers—a major increase over ESPN's broadcasts. Some events had attracted an audience of over 1 million. The association cited favorable scheduling practices (including better time slots and additional encores, as well as using [[Fox NASCAR|NASCAR broadcasts]] as a lead-in), and increased promotion of the event broadcasts as part of FS1 and FS2's programming, as having helped build their audience.{{Cite news|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/racing/nhra-chief-content-officer-ken-adelson-talks-changes-2018-relationship-fox-sports.html|title=NHRA Chief Content Officer Ken Adelson talks changes for 2018, relationship with Fox Sports|date=2018-02-06|work=Awful Announcing|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en-US}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nhra.com Official website] * [https://secure.nhra.powerade.com/contest/podcast.asp Official NHRA Drag Racing Podcasts]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.dragracecentral.com/ Drag Race Central] The Latest NHRA News and Analysis {{NHRA Drag Racing years}} {{NHRA dragstrips}} [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 1965]] [[Category:NHRA Mello Yello Drag Racing Series|*]]

[[File:Nordia 2017 logo.png|thumb|Official show logo]] The '''Nordia 2017 Stamp Exhibition''' was an international [[stamp exhibition]] held 27–29 October 2017 at the Spektrum and [[DGI-Huset]] in [[Vejle]], Denmark. The exhibition was granted patronage from the [[Federation of European Philatelic Associations]] (FEPA).<ref>http://fepanews.com/International%20Exhibitions</ref>
The event included the 4th International Polar Philatelic Exhibition.
==Palmares== The Grand Prix awards went to the following exhibits:<ref>http://www.nordia2017.dk/resultater</ref>
The Grand Prix Nordic went to Klaas Biermann for ‘Norway Coat Of Arms 1855-1868‘ (92 points).
The Grand Prix International went to Per Bunnstad for ‘Albatross: A Dramatic Event during the First World War‘ (92 points).
The Grand Prix National went to Torben Malm for ‘Service Stamps of Denmark, 1871-1924‘ (95 points).
The Polar Grand went to Hugh Osborne for ‘South Georgia Postal History, 1904-1942‘.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{commons category|Stamp exhibitions}} * {{Official website|http://www.nordia2017.dk/}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox recurring event | |name= Numaish |motto= |logo= |image= Ajanta gate, Numaish.jpg |caption= Ajanta Gate |location= [[Hyderabad, Telangana]], [[India]] |years_active= 1938 – present |dates= 1 January - 15 February |genre= [[State fair]] |website={{URL|http://Www.numaishonline.com}} }} '''Numaish Masnuaat-e-Mulki''' or '''Numaish''' also known as '''Exhibition''' is an annual [[Fair|consumer exhibition]] held in [[Hyderabad, Telangana]], [[India]].<ref>{{cite news |title= Exhibition named ‘Numaish’ at last|author= |url= http://www.siasat.com/english/news/exhibition-named-%E2%80%98numaish%E2%80%99-last|newspaper= The Siasat is a Daily|date= |accessdate=6 February 2012}}</ref> The exhibition has remained the only event of its kind in the world to be organised at a stretch for a 46-day period at its {{convert|23|acre|m2|adj=on}} permanent venue in [[Nampally, Hyderabad|Nampally]].<ref>{{cite news |title= ndustrial expo in Jan in Hyderabad|author= |url= http://www.thehindubusinessline.in/2003/12/30/stories/2003123002510500.htm|newspaper= The Hindu|date= |accessdate=6 February 2012}}</ref> It features joy rides, eateries and other entertainment options for the visitors.<ref name="Hyderabad Government and Administration">{{cite web| url=http://www.hyd.co.in/category/attractions/| title=Hyderabad Government and Administration| accessdate=20 August 2011}}</ref>
==History== ''Numaish Masnuaat-e-Mulki'' meaning ''Exhibition of the Local Products'', was started in 1938 by a group of graduates of [[Osmania University]] to showcase local products. It was the reign of the Last [[Nizam]] of [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], [[Mir Osman Ali Khan]]. From a mere 100 stalls in 1938 started at the [[Public Gardens, Hyderabad|Public Gardens]], the venue has shifted to the Exhibition Grounds, near [[Nampally Railway Station]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.hindu.com/2003/12/30/stories/2003123010140300.htm | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=Industrial exhibition to open on January 1 | date=30 December 2003}}</ref> The original name was changed to All India Industrial Exhibition, and was renamed to its original name, the ''Numaish'' in 2009.
==Exhibition== [[File:Numaish.jpg|thumb|Shops at Numaish]] [[File:Rides Numaish.jpg|thumb|Rides at Numaish]] [[File:Toy train, Numaish.jpg|thumb|Toy train]] The exhibition features dry fruits and handicrafts of Jammu and Kashmir to handmade garments from Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Madhya Pradesh, handicraft items from all over India and electronic goods of the best brands in the country. There are special stalls organized by different ladies groups, convicts and much more.<ref>http://www.indianmuslims.info/news/2008/jan/06/hyderabads_numaish_has_something_everyone.html</ref> The exhibition also featured [[carpets]] of [[Iran]] and some stalls from [[Pakistan]] till 2011. But due to diplomatic reasons they will not be available from 2012.<ref name="articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com">{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-30/hyderabad/30572566_1_numaish-vehicle-parking-parking-problems | work=The Times Of India | title=Numaish parking plans in place | date=30 December 2011}}</ref> The [[Hyderabadi haleem]] is sold by Hyderabadi restaurant Pista House at the exhibition.
There are three entry points: Gate No. 1 (Gandhi Bhavan Gate), Gate No. 2 (Ajanta Gate), Gate No.3 (Goshamahal Gate). The Ajanta Gate is the main entrance and the biggest.
==Entry and Car parking== For entry to the exhibition, INR25 is charged per head.
From 2012, car parking is provided with fixed Rs 50 as fee for four-wheelers and Rs 20 for two-wheelers. Besides, there is a lot of parking space inside the exhibition grounds. Vehicles are allowed entry till 4 pm. Another official parking space has been identified on the premises of Government Junior College, [[Nampally, Hyderabad|Nampally]] (opposite [[Gandhi Bhavan]])<ref name="articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com"/> Still there are incidents of duping people in name of car parking. The miscreants who have leased out the open grounds near the exhibition charge Rs 50 for a four-wheeler and Rs 20 for a two-wheeler.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/article2795302.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=‘Open loot' at Numaish | date=12 January 2012}}</ref>
==Surveillance== 25 CCTVs, a three-tier security system has been put in place while door-frame-metal detectors have been installed at the three entry locations. Apart from these, watch and ward are on duty till 9 pm everyday during the exhibition. Live video streaming of the Numaish with the help of two tilt and zoom cameras is posted on the internet. From 2012, [[Geographical Information System]] (GIS) has been used to allot the stalls based on the availability of the space in the grounds.
== Revenue ==
In 2011, about 21 lakh people visited the exhibition and the society collected a revenue of Rs 13 crore.<ref name="articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com"/>
==Cultural Programs== Several cultural programs are conducted in the Exhibition Club during the 46-day period that include classical and popular musical concerts, magic shows, [[mushaira]] (poetry) etc. In recent times Bollywood and Tollywood artists have also performed during the Numaish.
The 75th edition of the Numaish inaugurated on 1/1/2015 saw many special programs in Telugu and Urdu including performances by Tollywood artists as well as special Ghazal programs and Comedy programs that have been attended in large numbers by visitors. The newly renovated club hall was the venue for a special tribute to Legendary poets of Urdu performed by top ghazal singers of Hyderabad. This was a rare occasion where so many well known ghazal singers got together and performed on the same stage. Some of the poets whose ghazals were presented are [[Ghalib]], Iqbal, Mir Taqi Mir, Faiz Ahmed Faiz, Ibn-E-Insha and more.
Games will be available from 6pm onwards.
The Legendary Indian Artist, Padma Bhushan Awardee S.P. Balasubramanium was felicitated by the Exhibition Society on 8th February 2015 in a Grand Program arranged by the Society's Club and Reception Sub-Committee. The President of the society, Eatala Rajender, Telangana Minister for Finance, did the honors along with the other office bearers of the society. S.P Balasubramanium spoke and praised the services being rendered by the Exhibition Society. He also performed a few of his numbers along with a number of other Telugu Film Industry singers who came and performed as a tribute to Balu Sir (as he's fondly addressed).
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.4)
revision.text:
'''Nvision''', stylized as '''NVISION''', is a stand-alone event organized by [[NVIDIA]] to promote visual [[computing]] among enthusiasts and journalists.
The event is mostly centered on NVIDIA's own products but offers activities usually found at other types of events: a [[demoscene]] event, scientific talks, and programming classes. It's been replaced by the [[GPU Technology Conference]] in following years.
The same name was also used for Nvidia's quarterly magazine, published by [[Future plc]]. Publication was ceased after the 'Winter 2011' (#7) issue.
== NVISION 08 ==
[[Image:Diggnationlive.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kevin Rose]] and [[Alex Albrecht]] hosting a live ''[[Diggnation]]'' show.]]
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:NVISION08Mythbusters.jpg|thumb|right|The [[MythBusters]], [[Adam Savage]] and [[Jamie Hyneman]], paintball the [[Mona Lisa]]]] -->
The first NVISION event, NVISION 08, was held at the San Jose Center for the Performing Arts<ref>[http://revision3.com/blog/2008/08/13/live-show-diggnation-in-san-jose-ca-the-san-francisco-bay-area/ Live SHOW - Diggnation in San Jose, CA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913005223/http://revision3.com/blog/2008/08/13/live-show-diggnation-in-san-jose-ca-the-san-francisco-bay-area/ |date=2008-09-13 }}</ref> from August 25 to August 28, 2008 in [[San Jose, California]].<ref>[http://www.nvidia.com/content/nvision2008/index.html NVISION 08: Updates from the show]</ref>
[[Adam Savage]] and [[Jamie Hyneman]], of [[MythBusters]] fame, demonstrated how [[GPU]]s solve specific tasks faster in parallel than they can be executed on general purpose [[CPU]]s by painting a [[Mona Lisa]] with a massively parallel [[Paintball marker|paint gun]].<ref>[http://www.nvidia.com/content/nvision2008/art_science/index.html NVISION 08 Highlights: GPU vs. CPU Demonstration]</ref>
[[Guinness World Records]] was present to officiate the record for the longest continuous [[LAN party]] at 36 hours.<ref>[http://www.tomsguide.com/us/NVISION-LAN-Party,news-2512.html Tom's guide, Longest LAN party]</ref>
Kevin Gee from [[Microsoft]] revealed more details publicly about what would be in the next [[Direct3D|DirectX 11]].<ref>[http://www.custompc.co.uk/news/604734/microsoft-reveals-more-details-about-directx-11-tesselation.html Custom PC, DirectX11] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829135620/http://www.custompc.co.uk/news/604734/microsoft-reveals-more-details-about-directx-11-tesselation.html |date=2008-08-29 }}</ref>
[[Revision3]]'s [[Kevin Rose]] and [[Alex Albrecht]] were present to host a live ''[[Diggnation]]'' show.<ref>[http://revision3.com/blog/2008/08/13/live-show-diggnation-in-san-jose-ca-the-san-francisco-bay-area/ Live SHOW - Diggnation in San Jose, CA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913005223/http://revision3.com/blog/2008/08/13/live-show-diggnation-in-san-jose-ca-the-san-francisco-bay-area/ |date=2008-09-13 }}</ref>
France-based Games Services was present to host the [[2008 Electronic Sports World Cup]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS181298+30-Apr-2008+PRN20080430 World's Top Professional Gamers to Compete in ESWC Grand Final at NVISION 08]</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{no footnotes|date=August 2012}} {{distinguish|Oireachtas}} [[Image:Oireachtas na Gaeilge.png|150px|thumb|Oireachtas na Gaeilge.]] '''Oireachtas na Gaeilge''' ({{IPA-ga|ɛrʲaxt̪ˠasˠ nə ˈɡeːlʲɟə}}) is an annually held arts festival of [[Ireland|Irish]] culture, which has run since the 1890s. Based on the Welsh [[Eisteddfod]], Oireachtas na Gaeilge runs for one week, featuring performances, demonstrations and competitions. The festival is held in two portions: a [[visual arts]] festival in April/May and the festival proper on the last weekend of October or the first of November, when more than 10,000 people attend the seven-day event. In 2007, the festival was held at [[Westport, Ireland|Westport]]. The 2008 festival took place in the Cork city suburb of Douglas, the local support committee was under the chairmanship of [[Peadar Ó Riada]], son of the composer and founder of the male choir [[Cór Chúil Aodha]], [[Seán Ó Riada]].
==History== The first Oireachtas na Gaeilge festival was organised in 1897 by [[Conradh na Gaeilge]] (the Gaelic League), which envisaged it as part of a renaissance of traditional Irish arts and culture.<ref name="ITM2017">{{cite book|last1=Ó hAllmhuráin|first1=Gearóid|title=A Short History of Irish Traditional Music|date=2017|publisher=The O'Brien Press|location=Dublin|isbn=9781847179401|page=55|url=https://ebookcentral-proquest-com.ezproxy.slv.vic.gov.au/lib/slv/detail.action?docID=4840554|accessdate=27 September 2017|language=en|format=via [[State Library of Victoria]]}}</ref> in the Round Room of Dublin's [[Rotunda (architecture)|Rotunda]], one of the largest halls in the city at that time. It was just a half-day festival, but the attendance still exceeded a thousand people, an unexpected level of interest.
In contrast to today's festival, there was little emphasis on the performing arts. The competitions included two for poetry, five for prose essays, one for poetry compilations; a competition for unpublished songs or stories in Irish; a competition for new song compositions and a recitation competition.
While the festival management pulled off accomplishments including the staging of the [[Eithne (opera)|first Irish-language opera]], the popularity of the Oireachtas waned in the early part of the twentieth century, and the festival was cancelled for a number of years in the 1920s and 1930s. In response, the organisers, under the Directorship of Liam Ó Maolaodha attempted from the 1990s on to market the festival to younger speakers of Irish via outings, discos, and other youth-oriented events.
The festival was originally held in [[Dublin]], but since the 1970s, it has been held in different cities and towns around Ireland. The festival culminates in four major competitions over the weekend: Comórtas na mBan, a [[Sean-nós song|Sean-nós]] singing competition for women, Comórtas na bhFear, for men, [[Corn Uí Riada]], for all age and gender categories, and the Comórtas Damhsa ar an Sean Nós ("Steip"), a [[Sean-nós dance|free-style dancing]] competition mainly based on the Conamara individual step style now popular around the country, but also includes dancing in other regional styles. Past winners of [[Corn Uí Riada]] include [[Áine Uí Cheallaigh]], [[Lillis Ó Laoire]], [[Máirtín Tom Sheánín Mac Donnchadha]], [[Mícheál Ó Confhaola]] and 2008 winner [[Ciarán Ó Con Cheanainn]] from [[Spiddal|An Spidéal]]. [[County Galway|Contae na Gaillimhe]].
===Venue===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Venue ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2020 || [[Galway]] || |- | 2019 || [[Dublin]] || |- | 2016–18 || [[Killarney]] || |- | 2015 || [[Dublin]] || |- | 2013–14 || [[Killarney]] || |- | 2012 || [[Letterkenny]] || |- | 2010–11 || [[Killarney]] || |- | 2009 || [[Letterkenny]] || |- | 2008 || [[Cork (city)|Cork]] || |- | 2007 || [[Westport, County Mayo|Westport]] || |- | 2006 || [[Derry]] || |- | 2005 || [[Cork (city)|Cork]] || |- | 2004 || [[Letterkenny]] || |- | 2003 || [[Tralee]] || |- | 2002 || [[Gweedore]] || |- | 2001 || [[Dingle]] || |- | 2000 || [[Catlebar]] || |- | 1999 || [[Dungarvan]] || |- | 1997 || [[Belfast]] || |- | 1995 || [[Dublin]] || |- | 1994 || [[Dungarvan]] || |- | 1993 || [[Galway]] || |- | 1991 || [[Dublin]] || |- | 1990 || [[Ennis]] || |- | 1989 || [[Glencolmcille]] || |- | 1988 || [[Tralee]] || |- | 1980 || [[Gweedore]] || |- | 1977 || [[Gweedore]] || |- | 1974 || [[Cois Fharraige]] || |- | 1939–1973 || [[Dublin]] || |- | 1924–1938 || no Oireachtas || |- | 1923 || [[Dublin]] || |- | 1920 || [[Dublin]] || |- | 1919 || [[Cork (city)|Cork]] || |- | 1917 || [[Waterford]] || |- | 1915 || [[Dundalk]] || |- | 1914 || [[Killarney]] || |- | 1913 || [[Galway]] || |- | 1897–1912 || [[Dublin]] || |}
==Media coverage== [[RTÉ Raidió na Gaeltachta]] has been covering the bigger Oireachtas events live since 1973 and these broadcasts are in considerable demand from internet audiences around the globe, particularly Corn Uí Riada and the sean-nós stage competitions. Steip, the Sean nós dancing competition, on [[TG4]] has consistently attracted the station's highest annual audience figures. Its success is due to the hard work of Festival administrator Máirín Nic Dhonnchadha who effectively revived the competition from 2000 onwards. In 2008, for the first time, the station broadcast live segments of the Corn Uí Riada competition.
==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite book | title=Scéal an Oireachtais 1897 – 1924 | publisher=An Clóchomhar Tta | author=Ó Súilleabháin, Donncha | year=1984 | location=Dublin|language= Irish}} *{{cite book | title=Réamhchonraitheoirí | publisher=Clódhanna Teo | author=Ní Mhuiríosa, Máirín | year=1968 | location=Dublin|language= Irish|ISBN= 0-9501264-0-3}} *{{cite book | title=Oireachtas na Gaeilge 1897 - 1997 | publisher=Conradh na Gaeilge | author=Mac Aonghusa, Proinsias (Ed.)| year=1997 | authorlink= Proinsias Mac Aonghusa| location=Dublin}} *{{cite book | title=Cuimhní Cinn ar an Oireachtas | publisher=Conradh na Gaeilge | author=Mac Mathúna, Seán | year=1997 | location=Dublin|language= Irish}}
==External links== *[http://www.antoireachtas.ie Festival website] *[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2008/1027/1224838873956.html An Irishwoman's Diary] Preview in Irish Times 2008 by Catherine Foley {{Gaels}}
