{{rail-interchange|gb|Rail}} [[London Waterloo railway station|Waterloo]] |website = [http://www.oldvictheatre.com oldvictheatre.com] }} [[File:Sir Derek Jacobi on the Old Vic Theatre.ogg|thumb|Audio description of the theatre by [[Derek Jacobi]]]] '''The Old Vic''' is a 1,000-seat, [[nonprofit organization|not-for-profit]] [[producing house|producing theatre]], located just south-east of [[London Waterloo railway station|Waterloo station]] on the corner of [[The Cut (London)|the Cut]] and [[Waterloo Road, London|Waterloo Road]] in [[Lambeth]], London, England. Established in 1818 as the '''Royal Coburg Theatre''', and renamed in 1833 the '''Royal Victoria Theatre''', in 1871 it was rebuilt and reopened as the '''Royal Victoria Palace'''. It was taken over by [[Emma Cons]] in 1880 and formally named the '''Royal Victoria Hall''', although by that time it was already known as the "Old Vic". In 1898, a niece of Cons, [[Lilian Baylis]] assumed management and began a series of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] productions in 1914. The building was damaged in 1940 during [[The Blitz|air raids]] and it became a [[Grade II* listed building]] in 1951 after it reopened.[http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?pid=2&id=204779 English Heritage listing details] 28 April 2007 The Old Vic is the crucible of many of the performing arts companies and theatres in London today. It was the name of a [[repertory]] company that was based at the theatre and formed (along with the [[Chichester Festival Theatre]]) the core of the [[National Theatre of Great Britain]] on its formation in 1963, under [[Laurence Olivier]]. The National Theatre remained at the Old Vic until new premises were constructed on the [[South Bank]], opening in 1976. The Old Vic then became the home of [[Prospect Theatre Company]], at that time a highly successful touring company which staged such acclaimed productions as [[Derek Jacobi]]'s ''Hamlet''. However, with the withdrawal of funding for the company by the [[Arts Council of Great Britain]] in 1980 for breaching its touring obligations, Prospect disbanded in 1981. The theatre underwent complete refurbishment in 1985. In 2003, [[Kevin Spacey]] was appointed artistic director, which received considerable media attention.{{cite news|title=Spacey 'to run Old Vic'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/2723437.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=3 February 2003|accessdate=9 March 2014}} In 2015, [[Matthew Warchus]] succeeded Spacey as artistic director.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/may/22/matthew-warchus-kevin-spacey-old-vic-theatre|title=Matthew Warchus to take Kevin Spacey's role running the Old Vic|last=Brown|first=Mark|date=22 May 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=22 June 2016|via=}} ==History== ===Origins=== [[File:Royal Coburg Theatre 1822.jpg|thumb|left|Royal Coburg Theatre in 1822]] The theatre was founded in 1818 by James King and Daniel Dunn (formerly managers of the [[Surrey Theatre]] in [[Bermondsey]]), and [[John Thomas Serres]], then the marine painter to the King. Serres managed to secure the formal patronage of [[Princess Charlotte Augusta of Wales|Princess Charlotte]] and her husband [[Leopold I of Belgium|Prince Leopold of Saxe-Coburg]], and named the theatre the Royal Coburg Theatre. The theatre was a "minor" theatre (as opposed to one of the two [[patent theatre]]s) and was thus technically forbidden to show serious drama. Nevertheless, when the theatre passed to George Bolwell Davidge in 1824 he succeeded in bringing legendary actor [[Edmund Kean]] south of the river to play six Shakespeare plays in six nights. The theatre's role in bringing high art to the masses was confirmed when Kean addressed the audience during his curtain call saying "I have never acted to such a set of ignorant, unmitigated brutes as I see before me." More popular staples in the repertoire were "sensational and violent" melodramas demonstrating the evils of drink, "churned out by the house dramatist", confirmed [[teetotaller]] [[Douglas Jerrold]].{{cite book|last=Frick|first=John W. |title=Theatre, culture and temperance reform in nineteenth-century America|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, England|year=2003|page=86|isbn=978-0-521-81778-3}} When Davidge left to take over the [[Surrey Theatre]] in 1833, the theatre was bought by [[Daniel Egerton]] and [[William Abbot]], who tried to capitalise on the abolition of the legal distinction between patent and minor theatres, enacted in [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] earlier that year.{{cite book|last=Rowell|first=George Presbury|title=The Old Vic Theatre: a history|year=1993|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, England|isbn=0-521-34625-8|pages=26–29}} On 1 July 1833,{{cite news |title=Royal Victoria Theatre |newspaper=[[London Evening Standard|Standard]] |location=London |date=2 July 1833 }} the theatre was renamed the Royal Victoria Theatre, under the "protection and patronage" of [[Princess Victoria of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld|Victoria, Duchess of Kent]], mother to [[Queen Victoria|Princess Victoria]], the 14-year-old [[heir presumptive]] to the British throne. The duchess and the princess visited only once, on 28 November of that year, but enjoyed the performance, of light opera and dance, in the "pretty...clean and comfortable" theatre. The single visit scarcely justified the "Old Vic" its later billing asf "Queen Victoria's Own Theayter".{{cite news |title=Court Circular |newspaper=[[The Times]] |location=London |date=30 November 1833 }}{{cite book|last=Newton|first=Henry Chance|authorlink=Henry Chance Newton|title=The Old Vic. and its associations; being my own extraordinary experiences of "Queen Victoria's own theayter"|year=1923|publisher=Fleetway Press|location=London|oclc=150444870}} By 1835, the theatre was advertising itself simply as the Victoria Theatre. [[File:Old Vic0185.JPG|thumb|right|The Old Vic, photographed in 2012]] In 1841, David Osbaldiston took over as lessee, and was succeeded on his death in 1850 by his lover and the theatre's leading lady, Eliza Vincent, until her death in 1856. Under their management, the theatre remained devoted to melodrama. In 1858, sixteen people were crushed to death inside the theatre after mass panic caused while an actor's clothing caught fire.https://www.standard.co.uk/go/london/theatre/old-vic-theatre-celebrates-200th-birthday-7-fascinating-things-you-never-knew-a3835981.html Coleman (2014), pp. 22–36. In 1867, Joseph Arnold Cave took over as lessee. In 1871 he transferred the lease to Romaine Delatorre, who raised funds for the theatre to be rebuilt{{clarify|date=May 2018}} in the style of the [[Alhambra Music Hall]]. Jethro Thomas Robinson was engaged as the architect. In September 1871 the old theatre closed, and the new building opened as the Royal Victoria Palace in December of the same year, with Cave staying on as manager. By 1873, however, Cave had left and Delatorre's venture failed.Coleman (2014), pp. 43–57. In 1880, under the ownership of [[Emma Cons]] (for whose memory there are plaques outside and inside the theatre) it became the Royal Victoria Hall and Coffee Tavern and was run on "strict [[Temperance movement|temperance]] lines"; by this time it was already known as the "Old Vic".[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=47035 'The Royal Victoria Hall –The Old Vic'], ''Survey of London: Vol. 23''. Lambeth: South Bank and Vauxhall (1951), pp. 37–9. Retrieved 28 April 2007. The "penny lectures" given in the hall led to the foundation of [[Morley College]]. An endowment from the estate of [[Samuel Morley (MP)|Samuel Morley]] led to the creation of the ''Morley Memorial College for Working Men and Women'' on the premises, which were shared; lectures were given back stage, and in the theatre dressing rooms. The [[adult education]] college moved to its own premises nearby in the 1920s. ===Old Vic company=== [[Image:Old vic night.JPG|thumb|left|The theatre at night]] With Emma Cons's death in 1912 the theatre passed to her niece [[Lilian Baylis]], who emphasised the [[William Shakespeare|Shakespearean]] repertoire. The Old Vic Company was established in 1929, led by [[John Gielgud|Sir John Gielgud]]. Between 1925 and 1931, [[Lilian Baylis]] championed the re-building of the then-derelict [[Sadler's Wells]] Theatre, and established a ballet company under the direction of [[Ninette de Valois|Dame Ninette de Valois]]. For a few years the drama and ballet companies rotated between the two theatres, with the ballet becoming permanently based at Sadler's Wells in 1935. ===Wartime exile=== The Old Vic was damaged badly during [[the Blitz]], and the war-depleted company spent all its time touring, based in [[Burnley]], Lancashire at the Victoria Theatre during the years 1940 to 1943. In 1944, the company was re-established in London with [[Ralph Richardson]] and [[Laurence Olivier]] as its stars, performing mainly at the [[Noël Coward Theatre|New Theatre]] (now the Noël Coward Theatre) until the Old Vic was ready to reopen in 1950. In 1946, an offshoot of the company was established in [[Bristol]] as the [[Bristol Old Vic]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} ===National Theatre company=== In 1963, the Old Vic company was dissolved and the new [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] Company, under the artistic direction of [[Laurence Olivier|Lord Olivier]], was based at the Old Vic until its own building was opened on the [[South Bank]] near [[Waterloo Bridge]] in 1976. [[Image:Old Vic.jpg|thumb|Staircase of the Old Vic]] In July 1974 the Old Vic presented a rock concert for the first time. National Theatre director [[Peter Hall (theatre director)|Sir Peter Hall]] arranged for the progressive folk-rock band [[Gryphon (band)|Gryphon]] to première ''Midnight Mushrumps'', the fantasia inspired by Hall's own 1974 Old Vic production of ''[[The Tempest]]'' starring [[John Gielgud]] for which Gryphon had supplied the music.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} ===Prospect Theatre Company=== For two years prior to the departure of the National Theatre company, [[Toby Robertson]], director of the [[Prospect Theatre Company]], sustained a campaign that the Old Vic should make Prospect its resident company.Rowell, p. 157 For the Old Vic, Robertson's overtures proved increasingly hard to resist in the face of poor box office returns achieved by productions staged by other visiting companies; against this, Prospect staged a highly successful season which opened in May 1977, including ''Hamlet'' with [[Derek Jacobi]], ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' with [[Alec McCowen]] and [[Dorothy Tutin]]; and ''[[Saint Joan (play)|Saint Joan]]'' with [[Eileen Atkins]].Rowell, p. 158{{cite web | title =History of the Old Vic, 1950–1999 | publisher =The Old Vic | url =http://www.oldvictheatre.com/about-us/history-of-the-old-vic-2/1950-1999/ | accessdate = 5 September 2014 }} In July the Governors of the Old Vic announced "a marriage that was all but a merger" between the Vic and Prospect. In September Toby Robertson, director of Prospect, was asked to take artistic control of the Old Vic, and Christopher Richards, general manager of the Old Vic, became general manager of Prospect.{{cite web | title =Prospect Theatre Company | publisher =Ian McKellen Stage | url =http://www.mckellen.com/stage/r2/prospect.htm | accessdate = 4 September 2014 }} One major problem, though, was the terms of Prospect's funding by the [[Arts Council of Great Britain]]: this was on the basis of it being a touring company, and the Council – already funding the National Theatre and the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] in London – could not accept a case for a third major company in the capital and repeatedly refused requests to fund any London seasons staged by Prospect. Therefore, any London-based productions would have to succeed financially without Arts Council support. Prospect's first season at the Old Vic recouped its costs but left no surplus to fund future productions. Further stagings by visiting companies were box office failures and stretched the theatre's finances to breaking point.Rowell, p. 159 Yet Prospect continued to draw audiences to the Old Vic where other companies failed. In December 1978, the governors of the Old Vic agreed to a five-year contract with Prospect, announcing to the press on 23 April that henceforth they would be styled "Prospect Productions Ltd., trading as the Old Vic Company".Rowell, p. 160 Unfortunately Prospect's touring commitments kept the company out of the theatre for the first half of 1979, leaving the theatre to sink further into debt. The company returned in July with Jacobi's ''Hamlet'' (toured afterwards to Denmark, Australia and China, the first English theatre company to tour that country), followed by ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', and ''[[The Government Inspector]]'' with [[Ian Richardson]]. The following season, however, proved controversial: the proposed programming, including the double bill of ''The Padlock'' and ''[[Miss in Her Teens]]'', to mark the bicentenary of [[David Garrick]]'s death, and a revival of ''[[What the Butler Saw (play)|What the Butler Saw]]'', were deemed by the Arts Council unsuitable for touring repertory. An internal report by Prospect now questioned "whether Prospect can any longer satisfy the triple task of filling the Vic, of satisfying the Arts Council Director of Touring's requirements for product of a certain familiar sort, and of realising the vision of Toby Robertson".Quoted in Rowell, p. 160 Robertson was in effect fired as artistic director in 1980 while he was abroad with the company in [[China]], [[Timothy West]] replacing him.{{cite web | url= https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/jul/08/toby-robertson | work=[[The Guardian]] | accessdate=16 September 2013 | date=8 July 2012 | title= Toby Robertson obituary| first=Michael | last=Coveney }} The following season, West's first as Robertson's successor, saw ''[[Macbeth]]'' with [[Peter O'Toole]], ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' with West as Shylock, and a gala performance presented to the Queen Mother to celebrate her eightieth birthday. On 22 December 1980, four days after the gala performance, the Arts Council withdrew its funding from the company, sealing its inevitable demise.{{cite book | last =Hunter | first =Adriana | authorlink = | title ="Prospect Theatre Company" in Continuum Companion to Twentieth Century Theatre | publisher =A&C Black | series = | volume =| edition = | date =2006 | location =| pages =623 | language = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=cFlFhuVMFGQC&pg=PA623&lpg=PA623&dq=%22The+Old+Vic%22+%22Prospect+Theatre%22+%22Toby+Robertson%22&source=bl&ots=mV8ooYukE5&sig=glE3lOsUU5ecrBRdq_ryN_aoDJA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qeYIVKGqJMzYao2MgvgJ&ved=0CCMQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Old%20Vic%22%20%22Prospect%20Theatre%22%20%22Toby%20Robertson%22&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =9781847140012 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}Rowell, p. 161 The company gave a final season at the Old Vic in 1981, staging ''The Merchant of Venice'', then gave a final tour of Europe, giving its last performance in Rome on 14 June before disbanding. === Youth Theatre === The 'Old Vic Youth Theatre’ was an acting company for young people between the ages of 12 and 20 mainly from the London Borough of Southwark. The group was founded by Tom Vaughan of the Old Vic Theatre, Raymond Rivers of Morley College and Barry Anderson of the Southbank Education Institute. The [[Inner London Education Authority]] (ILEA) was the enterprise’s main funding body. During the early spring term of 1977 auditions consisting of improvisational scenes run by the Youth Theatre’s first professional directors Lucy Parker and Frederick Proud took place and around 40 applicants were chosen to form the company. By the middle of the summer in 1977 the 'Old Vic Youth Theatre’ had performed two plays for the paying public. First was ‘The Kitchen’ by [[Arnold Wesker]] which also incorporated improvised scenes alongside the actual script and was staged in the Emma Cons Hall at Morley College. The Youth Theatre’s second production, ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ by William Shakespeare was first performed at the George Inn Courtyard as part of the Southwark Shakespeare Festival the same year and was the company’s debut production at the Old Vic Theatre itself. In the autumn of 1977 a new round of auditions took place and the existing group expanded into two. One group concentrated on a famous scripted play whilst the other would devise a play through improvisation from which the material was scripted into a play by a professional playwright. The Youth groups continued to produce plays with new members auditioning each September until the mid 1980s. ===Reopening=== The Old Vic was significantly restored under the ownership of Toronto department-store entrepreneur [[Edwin Mirvish|'Honest Ed' Mirvish]] in 1985. In 1987, his son [[David Mirvish]] installed [[Jonathan Miller]] as artistic director of the Old Vic and the theatre enjoyed several critical successes – including an [[Olivier Award]] for a production of the musical ''Candide'', but suffered three straight years of financial loss. In 1990, Mirvish terminated Miller's contract over budgetary issues, earning much negative criticism in the British press. In 1997, Mirvish appointed [[Peter Hall (director)|Sir Peter Hall]] as artistic director and, again, enjoyed critical acclaim with such productions as ''[[The Master Builder]]'' with [[Alan Bates]] and ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' with [[Ben Kingsley]], but continuing financial loss. Within a year of the appointment, Mirvish terminated Hall's contract – again to much negative comment in the press – and put the Old Vic up for sale. In 1998, the building was bought by a new charitable trust, the ''Old Vic Theatre Trust 2000''. In 2000, the production company Criterion Productions was renamed ''Old Vic Productions plc'', though relatively few of its productions are at the Old Vic theatre. In 2003, actor [[Kevin Spacey]] was appointed as new artistic director of the Old Vic Theatre Company. Spacey said he wanted to inject new life into the British theatre industry, and bring British and American theatrical talent to the stage. Since 2015 [[Matthew Warchus]] has been Artistic Director of The Old Vic.{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/may/22/matthew-warchus-kevin-spacey-old-vic-theatre | title=Matthew Warchus to take Kevin Spacey's role running the Old Vic | work=The Guardian | date=22 May 2014 | accessdate=19 May 2015}} His debut season opened in September 2015 with Warchus's production of a new play about education, ''Future Conditional'' by Tamsin Oglesby. ===Bicentenary=== On 24 October 2017 The Old Vic announced its bicentenary seasonhttps://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/old-vic-bicentennial-season-monster-calls-sylvia_44947.html. The theatre celebrated its 200th birthday on Friday 11 May 2018 with a free performance of Joe Penhall's Mood Music, featuring Ben Chaplin.https://www.standard.co.uk/go/london/theatre/the-old-vic-is-giving-out-free-tickets-to-new-show-mood-music-and-cake-for-its-birthday-a3796236.html == Recent and current productions == {{Infobox recurring event | name = <!--Uses page name if omitted--> | logo = Oslo-Forum-Logo.jpg | logo_alt = The Oslo Forum - Network of Mediators | status = Active | genre = Conference | frequency = Annual | location = [[Oslo]] | country = Norway | established = 2003 | activity = Improve mediation practice and build a community of conflict mediation practitioners | participants = {{circa|100}} | organised = [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Royal Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] and the [[Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue]] (HD) | website = {{URL|http://www.osloforum.org/ }} }} The '''Oslo Forum''' convenes senior conflict mediators, high level decision makers, key peace process actors, analysts and experts in an informal and discreet retreat to share their experiences, identify challenges and reflect on mediation practice."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = About Oslo forum|url = http://www.osloforum.org/|website = www.osloforum.org|accessdate = 20 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Norway's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Børge Brende, met with Kosovo delegation|url = http://www.norway-kosovo.no/News_and_events/Events-in-Norway/Deputy-Prime-Minister-Thaci-visited-Norway/#.ViYk3X7hBD9|website = www.norway-kosovo.no|accessdate = 20 October 2015}}</ref> The retreat is held annually in June in [[Oslo]], Norway, and is co-hosted by the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Royal Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Governments turn to NGOs as proxy conflict negotiators|url = http://www.dw.com/en/governments-turn-to-ngos-as-proxy-conflict-negotiators/a-15211415|website = Deutsche Welle|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |date = 8 July 2011}}</ref> and the [[Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue]] (HD), a private diplomacy organisation based in Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Oslo Forum 2012|url = http://www.odi.org/events/oslo-forum-2012|website = Overseas Development Institute (ODI)|accessdate = 20 October 2015}}</ref> Participation is by invitation-only. All discussions take place under the [[Chatham House Rule]].<ref name=":0" />
The Oslo Forum also features biennial regional retreats in Africa and Asia.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Retreats: OSLOFORUM|url = http://www.osloforum.org/content/retreats|website = www.osloforum.org|accessdate = 20 October 2015}}</ref>
== History ==
The Mediators' Retreat, which in 2006 became known as the Oslo Forum, was initiated in 2003<ref>{{Cite web|title = Mediators’ Retreat to be held in Oslo on 18–19 June|url = https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/mediators_retreat_to_be_held_in/id251039/|website = Government.no|date = 17 June 2003 |accessdate = 20 October 2015 |language = |first = Ministry of Foreign|last = Affairs}}</ref> as a small gathering of mediation practitioners. The first Forum only included 17 participants but the event has now expanded to around 100 participants each year. The Forum is scheduled over two days.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.hdcentre.org/uploads/tx_news/HD-Oslo-Forum-2014.pdf|title = Oslo Forum 2014: Engaging with radical groups in conflicts. What can we accomplish through dialogue?|last = |first = |date = 2014|journal = |doi = |pmid = |access-date = 20 October 2015}}</ref>
In November 2005, a regional retreat was organised for the first time in Singapore to discuss peace processes in South and South East Asia. Since then, Asian and African regional retreats have regularly taken place to complement the global retreat organised in Oslo.<ref>{{Cite press release|title = Welcome Remarks by Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Zainul Abidin Rasheed at Asian Mediators' Retreat|url = http://www.mfa.gov.sg/content/mfa/media_centre/special_events/pedrabranca/press_room/mfa_pr/2006/200611/press_200611_1.html|website = www.mfa.gov.sg|accessdate = 20 October 2015|date = 27 November 2006}}</ref>
== Purpose == The Forum aims to improve mediation practice, build a community of conflict mediation practitioners and increase peer learning. The Oslo Forum functions as a laboratory for testing peacemakers’ assumptions and ideas from diverse conflicts and regions, and as a safe venue for sharing lessons learnt and best practices, and challenging commonly held preconceptions.<ref name=":1" />
== Participants == [[File:Oslo Forum 2014 - Dr Funmi Olonisakin, H.E. Mr Børge Brende and H.E. Mr Kofi Annan.jpg|thumb|Dr Funmi Olonisakin, H.E. Mr [[Børge Brende]] and H.E. Mr [[Kofi Annan]]]] Oslo Forum retreats attracts approximately one hundred senior mediators, key actors from the [[United Nations]], intergovernmental and regional organisations, as well as government officials, private organisations, conflict party representatives, war correspondents, outstanding analysts, thinkers and experts.<ref name=":3">{{cite journal |url = http://www.consilium.europa.eu/uedocs/cms_data/docs/pressdata/en/esdp/90605.pdf|title = Mediating Today's Conflicts for Tomorrow's Peace|last = Solana|first = Javier|date = 27 June 2006|journal = |doi = |pmid = |access-date = |issue = S183/06|publisher = European Council}}</ref>
Participants have included [[Kofi Annan]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Kofi Annan og Jimmy Carter til Oslo Forum|url = https://www.regjeringen.no/no/aktuelt/oslo-forum/id762852/|website = Regjeringen.no|date = 12 June 2014 |accessdate =20 October 2015 |language = no|last = Utenriksdepartementet}}</ref> [[Jimmy Carter|President Jimmy Carter]],<ref name=":2" /> [[Aung San Suu Kyi]],<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title = Oslo Forum: Paneldebatt med Aung San Suu Kyi og Bono|url = https://www.regjeringen.no/no/dokumentarkiv/stoltenberg-ii/ud/lyd-og-bilde/2012/oslo-forum---suu-kyi/id685558/|website = Regjeringen.no|date = 14 June 2012 |accessdate = 20 October 2015|language = no|last = Utenriksdepartementet}}</ref> [[Martti Ahtisaari|President Martti Ahtisaari]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Fredsmeglersamlingen Oslo Forum 26.-29. juni|url = https://www.regjeringen.no/no/aktuelt/fredsmeglersamling/id473379/|website = Regjeringen.no|date = 21 June 2007|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |language = no|last = Utenriksdepartementet}}</ref> [[Catherine Ashton|Baroness Catherine Ashton]],<ref>{{cite journal |url = http://www.asktheeu.org/es/request/1948/response/7004/attach/3/annexes.pdf|title = List of documents Initial request Ms Vicky Cann (CEO) 2015/2376- Post-mandate activities Baroness Ashton|last = |first = |date = 29 May 2015|journal = |doi = |pmid = |access-date = 20 October 2015|publisher = European Commission|issue = Ref. Ares(2015)2249335 - 29/05/2015}}</ref> [[Mohammad Khatami|President Mohammad Khatami]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Pretzels and Policies with Mohammad Khatami - Harvard - Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs|url = http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/publication/18388/pretzels_and_policies_with_mohammad_khatami.html|website = belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu|accessdate = 20 October 2015|date = 30 June 2008}}</ref> [[Olusegun Obasanjo|President Olusegun Obasanjo]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Annual international conference of armed conflict mediators and peace process actors - International Security Sector Advisory Team (ISSAT)|url = http://issat.dcaf.ch/Share/Events/Annual-international-conference-of-armed-conflict-mediators-and-peace-process-actors|website = issat.dcaf.ch|accessdate = 20 October 2015}}</ref> [[Juan Manuel Santos|President Juan Manuel Santos]],<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|title = Santos: América Latina, el Caribe y Europa apoyan el proceso de paz|url = http://www.noticiasrcn.com/nacional-dialogos-paz/santos-america-latina-el-caribe-y-europa-apoyan-el-proceso-paz|website = Noticias RCN|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |date = 16 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Santos: es obsoleto recurrir a la guerra para resolver conflictos|url = http://www.noticiasrcn.com/nacional-dialogos-paz/santos-obsoleto-recurrir-guerra-resolver-conflictos|website = Noticias RCN|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |date = 16 June 2015}}</ref> [[Javier Solana|Dr Javier Solana]],<ref name=":3" /> [[Gerry Adams]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Gerry Adams to participate in Oslo Forum|url = http://www.sinnfein.ie/contents/6942|website = www.sinnfein.ie|accessdate = 20 October 2015|date = 23 June 2006}}</ref> and many others.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Participants: OSLOFORUM|url = http://www.osloforum.org/content/participants|website = www.osloforum.org|accessdate = 20 October 2015}}</ref>
The participation of conflict protagonists has attracted international media attention. In 2015 Reuters reported that Afghan senior officials as well as [[Taliban]] representatives attended the Oslo Forum.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Afghan, Taliban delegates attend Oslo talks on ending conflicts|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/16/us-norway-afghanistan-idUSKBN0OW17B20150616|newspaper = Reuters|date = 16 June 2015 |access-date = 20 October 2015}}</ref> Syrian government and opposition representatives have attended in recent years.<ref>{{Cite web|title = EU-sanctioned Assad adviser in Oslo for secret talks|url = http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jun-21/260977-eu-sanctioned-assad-adviser-in-oslo-for-secret-talks.ashx|website = The Daily Star Newspaper |location= Lebanon|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |date = 21 June 2014}}</ref> Media also reported the attendance of representatives from the Philippines Government and the [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front]] (MILF) in the context of a resumption of talks in summer 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Gov’t-MILF talks to resume in July|url = http://globalnation.inquirer.net/78391/govt-milf-talks-to-resume-in-july|website = globalnation.inquirer.net|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |date = 22 June 2013}}</ref>
== Media coverage == All discussions at the Oslo Forum are held under the Chatham House Rule of non-attribution. International media outlets have, however, covered main themes discussed at the Oslo Forum. This includes for example BBC coverage of discussions on possible peace talks with the Taliban in 2010<ref>{{Cite web|title = Afghanistan peace conundrum flummoxes mediators - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/10358053|website = BBC News|accessdate = 20 October 2015|language = |date = 19 June 2010}}</ref> and 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Afghanistan's leaders face battle for peace - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-33242063|website = BBC News|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |date = 23 June 2015}}</ref> Interviews with selected Oslo Forum participants on the side lines of the event and a recap of main themes have also featured in the New York Times,<ref>{{Cite news|title = Scandinavia's Scarred Mr. Dialogue|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/14/opinion/14cohen.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 14 July 2008 |access-date = 20 October 2015 |issn = 0362-4331|first = Roger|last = Cohen}}</ref> the Economist<ref>{{Cite news|title = Privatising peace|url = http://www.economist.com/node/18895458|newspaper = The Economist|access-date = 20 October 2015|issn = |date = 30 June 2011}}</ref> and numerous other outlets. The presence of Burmese politician and Nobel Peace Prize laureate Aung San Suu Kyi (2012),<ref name=":4" /> [[U2]] frontman [[Bono]] (2012),<ref>{{cite AV media | date = 18 June 2012 | title = Bono at Oslo Forum 18.06.2012 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2t5Sd4TuXIo | access-date = 20 October 2015 | location = Norway}}</ref> Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos (2015)<ref name=":5" /> and other prominent public figures has also attracted international media attention.
== Publications == [[File:Oslo Forum 2014 - ICC Prosecutor-Fatou-Bensouda.jpg|thumb|[[International Criminal Court]] Prosecutor [[Fatou Bensouda]] speaking at the Oslo Forum in 2014]]A summary of discussions at the Oslo Forum is available to the public through annual reports, published by the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD). HD also commissions policy and background papers specifically for Oslo Forum retreats. These papers are published online upon completion of each retreat and can be accessed through the Oslo Forum website and HD website. Selected public speeches held at the Oslo Forum are available online.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Opening Speech at Oslo Freedom Forum|url = https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/apningsinnlegg-pa-oslo-freedom-forum/id2413515/|website = Government.no|date = 28 May 2015 |accessdate = 20 October 2015|first = Ministry of Foreign|last = Affairs}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Oslo Forum|url = http://wp.presidencia.gov.co/Noticias/2015/Junio/Paginas/20150616_02-The-Oslo-Forum.aspx|website = wp.presidencia.gov.co|accessdate = 20 October 2015 |last = Santos|first = Juan Manuel|date = 16 June 2015}}</ref> {{Clear}}
