====Other American groups==== In December 2017, more than 130 [[Jewish studies]] scholars from across North America criticized the Trump administration's decision, calling on the U.S. government to take actions to de-escalate the tensions and "clarify Palestinians' legitimate stake in the future of Jerusalem."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.jta.org/2017/12/10/news-opinion/united-states/over-130-jewish-studies-scholars-sign-statement-criticizing-trumps-jerusalem-decision |title=Over 130 US Jewish studies scholars criticize Trump's Jerusalem decision |agency=Jewish Telegraph Agency |date=December 10, 2017 |accessdate=December 11, 2017}}</ref> According to ''[[Haaretz]]'', many of these scholars have been critical of the Trump administration and the current Israeli government.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Maltz |first1=Judy |title=Trump's Jerusalem Backlash Continues: Over 100 Jewish Studies Scholars Issue Condemnation |url=https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/1.827850 |accessdate=December 11, 2017 |work=[[Haaretz]] |date=December 9, 2017}}</ref>
[[American Muslim]] [[Civil and political rights|civil]] [[advocacy groups]] rejected the policy change, including the [[Council on American-Islamic Relations]] (CAIR) and the [[Muslim Public Affairs Council]] (MPAC). On December 5, Muslim, [[Interfaith]] and [[human rights group]]s held a protest outside the White House.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ghazali |first1=Abdus Sattar |title=American Muslims reject Trump's move to recognize Jerusalem as capital of Israel |url=http://www.milligazette.com/news/16018-american-muslims-reject-trumps-move-to-recognize-jerusalem-as-capital-of-israel |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |work=[[The Milli Gazette]] |date=December 7, 2017}}</ref>
==Israeli and Palestinian responses==
===Israel=== [[File:Relocation of US Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem DSC0565 (41211030695).jpg|thumb|Jerusalem on 7 May 2018]] On December 6, shortly after Trump's statement, Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] said the announcement was a "historic landmark" and praised the decision as "courageous and just". During his remarks Netanyahu said there is "no peace that doesn't include Jerusalem as the capital of the State of Israel", adding that Jerusalem has "been the capital of Israel for nearly 70 years".<ref name=bbc3/> He later said that he has heard condemnation about the announcement but has "not heard any condemnation for the [[Palestinian rocket attacks|rocket]] firing against Israel that has come and the awful incitement against us".<ref name=bbc2>{{Cite news |title=US allies round on Trump over Jerusalem |work=BBC News |accessdate=December 10, 2017 |date=December 10, 2017 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42297437}}</ref>
The announcement was well received by [[Knesset]] members of left, right and centre parties including [[Yesh Atid]], [[Bayit Yehudi]], [[Yisrael Beytenu]], and [[Likud]]. [[Isaac Herzog]] called it an "act of historic justice" but also added that the next step was to "realize the vision of two states". In contrast, [[Bezalel Smotrich]] of the [[religious zionist]] Bayit Yehudi party issued the following statement: "For 30 years we have fallen into the pit of the Palestinian state as a realistic solution. The time has come to rethink things". [[Avi Gabbay]], who was recently elected to lead the [[Zionist Union]], also supported Trump's announcement, saying that recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital is more important then a peace deal.<ref name=cook>{{Cite web |title=How will US Jerusalem move affect Israel's far right? |accessdate=December 10, 2017 |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/jerusalem-move-affect-israel-171210122104793.html}}</ref><ref name=knesset>{{Cite web |title=Knesset Speaker: Thank you, POTUS — now, the rest of the world |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Knesset-Speaker-Thank-you-POTUS-now-the-rest-of-the-world-517223}}</ref>
Israel's Deputy Education Minister [[Meir Porush]] of [[United Torah Judaism]] party said building in "parts of [[Judea and Samaria Area|Judea and Samaria]] and Jerusalem that need housing would be better than a declaration that means nothing". [[Yisrael Eichler]], also of UTJ, expressed similar views saying he would "rather have 1,000 homes for young couples in Jerusalem than one American embassy building." In contrast, left-wing party [[Meretz]] said recognition of Jerusalem should only come with the establishment of a Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, adding that Trump's declaration "de facto betrays the Zionist vision and the values on which the State of Israel was established".<ref name=knesset/>
[[Hanin Zoabi]] and [[Ayman Odeh]], both members of the [[United Arab List]] party, said the US could no longer act as a peace mediator. Odeh said that "Trump is a pyromaniac and will set the entire region ablaze with his madness".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Labor’s Gabbay welcomes Trump’s Jerusalem move, urges ‘trust-building’ measures |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |work=Times of Israel |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/labors-gabbay-welcomes-trumps-jerusalem-move-urges-trust-building-measures/}}</ref>
===Palestinian Authority and Hamas === Palestinian officials said the announcement disqualifies the United States from peace talks.<ref name=bbc /> Palestinian prime minister [[Rami Hamdallah]] said the policy change "destroys the peace process".<ref name=pope /> Palestinian president [[Mahmoud Abbas]] gave a speech where he said the decision meant the United States was "abdicating its role as a peace mediator".<ref name=bbc3>{{Cite news |title=World reacts to Trump move on Jerusalem |work=BBC News |accessdate=December 11, 2017 |date=December 7, 2017 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-42250340}}</ref> Palestinian Foreign Minister [[Riyad al-Maliki]] similarly said the United States could no longer act as a mediator in the peace process because it had become a party to the dispute.<ref name=league/> [[Adnan al-Husayni]] asked the [[Organization of Islamic Cooperation]] to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Palestine.<ref name=frantzman>{{Cite web |title=Palestinian official urges Istanbul summit: Recognize Jerusalem as our capital |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Palestinian-official-Recognize-Jerusalem-as-Palestinian-capital-517735}}</ref>
[[Hamas]] called for a new [[Palestinian uprising|intifada]], but the response from Palestinians inside Jerusalem was relatively muted.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Williams |first=Dan |last2=al-Mughrabi |first2=Nidal |title=Hamas calls for Palestinian uprising over Trump's Jerusalem plan |work=Reuters |date=December 7, 2017 |access-date=December 8, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-israel/hamas-calls-for-palestinian-uprising-over-trumps-jerusalem-plan-idUSKBN1E11BR?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews}}</ref><ref name="GreenDown">{{cite news |last1=Green |first1=Emma |title=Trump Did Not Bring Jerusalem Crashing Down |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2017/12/trump-jerusalem-days-of-rage/547880/ |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |publisher=The Atlantic |date=December 8, 2017}}</ref> Protests were held in East Jerusalem, the West Bank, and the Gaza Strip. Palestinians burned portraits and effigies of Donald Trump and tore pictures of [[Salman bin Abdulaziz]] and [[Muhammad bin Salman]] in protest of the embassy move.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/Detail/2017/12/10/545091/Gaza-US-Palestine-Jerusalem-Israel-Trump-Salman-Saudi-Arabia |title=PressTV-Gazans burn photos of Saudi king, crown prince |publisher=}}</ref> The Israel military estimated that 3,000 people in the West Bank and 4,500 in the Gaza Strip participated in protests on December 8, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/palestinians-vent-their-fury-on-day-of-rage-against-trumps-jerusalem-move/2017/12/08/b89bed3a-db96-11e7-a241-0848315642d0_story.html|title=Israeli jets hit Gaza following rocket fire, as protests surge in wake of Trump announcement|last=Morris|first=Loveday|date=2017-12-08|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-05-19|last2=Eglash|first2=Ruth|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
The Jerusalem announcement inspired activist Ahmed Abu Artema to write a Facebook proposing the outlines of the [[Great March of Return]] protests.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/14/opinion/gaza-protests-organizer-great-return-march.html|title=Opinion {{!}} I Helped Start the Gaza Protests. I Don’t Regret It.|last=Abu Artema|first=Ahmed|date=2018-05-14|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-19|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Multiple camps of Palestinians engaged in protest along the fenceline of the Gaza Strip as part of this effort in late March 2018, demanding the right of Palestinian refugees and their descendants to return to their former homes in Israel, and an end to the blockade of the Gaza Strip, as well as rejecting recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20180401-why-did-palestinians-take-part-in-the-great-march-of-return/|title=Why did Palestinians take part in the Great March of Return?|date=2018-04-01|work=Middle East Monitor|access-date=2018-05-19|language=en-GB}}</ref> The opening of the US embassy in Jerusalem on May 14 coincided with a major escalation of the protests, resulting in the death of 64 protesters on that day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-gaza-protest-deaths-20180514-story.html|title=Celebration in Jerusalem as U.S. moves embassy, bloodshed in Gaza as dozens of Palestinians killed|last=King|first=Alexandra Zavis, Noga Tarnopolsky, Laura|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-05-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/two-palestinians-injured-in-gaza-border-protests-friday-die-of-wounds-1.6098160|title=Two Palestinians Injured at Friday Gaza Border Protests Die of Wounds|last=Khoury|first=Jack|date=2018-05-19|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-05-19|language=en}}</ref>
===Christian churches based in Jerusalem=== On December 6, 2017, the primate of the [[Greek Orthodox Church of Jerusalem]], Patriarch [[Patriarch Theophilos III of Jerusalem|Theophilos III]], widely regarded as the most senior Christian figure in Jerusalem, and twelve other church leaders in the Holy Land sent a letter to Trump warning that his move “w[ould] yield increased hatred, conflict, violence and suffering in Jerusalem and the Holy Land, moving us farther from the goal of unity and deeper toward destructive division”.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/06/us-recognition-of-jerusalem-as-israel-capital-what-it-means What does US recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital mean?] The Guardian, December 6, 2017.</ref> Apart from Theophilos III, the letter was signed by heads of Jerusalem's [[Syriac Orthodox Church|Syrian]], [[Armenian Orthodox Church|Armenian]], [[Ethiopian Orthodox Church|Ethiopioan]] and [[Coptic Orthodox Church|Coptic Orthodox]] patriarchates as well as the Roman Catholic Church's [[Apostolic Administrator]] for [[Jerusalem]] (the [[Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem]]). It was also signed by the [[Custody of the Holy Land|Franciscan Order]], the Greek-Melkite-Catholic patriarchate, the [[Maronite Church|Maronites]], the [[Episcopal Church in Jerusalem and the Middle East|Episcopal Church]], the [[Armenian Catholic Church|Armenian Catholic]] and [[Syriac Catholic Church|Syrian Catholic]] churches and the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in Jordan and the Holy Land|Evangelical Lutherans]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Surkes |first=Sue |title=Heads of Jerusalem churches deliver last-minute plea to Trump |accessdate=December 11, 2017 |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/heads-of-jerusalem-churches-deliver-last-minute-plea-to-trump/}}</ref>
==International response== Trump's Jerusalem decision was widely condemned by world leaders. European US allies that objected include Britain, Germany, Italy and France. Romania, on the other hand, declined to follow the EU position and also indicated it may relocate its embassy to Jerusalem.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/romania-decision-to-move-embassy-to-jerusalem-sparks-controversy-04-20-2018 |title=Romania President Slates Call to Move Embassy to Jerusalem |work=Balkan Insight |date=April 20, 2018 |access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/romania-begins-process-for-possible-move-of-its-embassy-to-jerusalem/ |title=Romania begins process for possible move of its embassy to Jerusalem |work=The Times of Israel |date=April 20, 2018 |access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-romania-diplomacy-jerusalem/romanian-ruling-party-chief-says-plans-to-move-israel-embassy-to-jerusalem-idUSKBN1HR0UW |title=Romania govt supports moving embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, president concerned |agency=Reuters |date=April 20, 2018 |access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref>
[[Pope Francis]] also made a plea that all nations remain committed to "respecting the status quo" of the city. China urged caution regarding the potential escalation of tensions in the Middle East.<ref name="pope">{{Cite news |issn=0362-4331 |last=Horowitz |first=Jason |title=U.N., European Union and Pope Criticize Trump's Jerusalem Announcement |work=The New York Times |accessdate=December 10, 2017 |date=December 6, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/06/world/europe/trump-jerusalem-pope.html}}</ref>
===United Nations === ====Pre-announcement==== Shortly before Trump's announcement, in November 2017, the [[United Nations General Assembly]] voted on a resolution in Jerusalem 151-6 with 9 abstentions. The resolution stated that "any actions by Israel, the occupying Power, to impose its laws, jurisdiction and administration on the Holy City of Jerusalem were illegal and therefore null and void. It further stressed the need for the parties to refrain from provocative actions, especially in areas of religious and cultural sensitivity, and called for respect for the historic status quo at the holy places of Jerusalem." It was part of six resolutions on Palestine and the Middle East.<ref name="UN resolution statement">{{Cite web |url=https://www.un.org/press/en/2017/ga11982.doc.htm |title=`Declaring Israel’s Actions in Syrian Golan, East Jerusalem ‘Null and Void’, General Assembly Adopts Six Resolutions on Palestine, Middle East |date=2018-11-30 |website=United Nations}}</ref>
====Security Council==== The United Nations Security Council vote on 7 December to condemn Trump's decision failed due to a veto by the United States, despite the support of the remaining fourteen members of the Council.<ref name=farnaz>{{Cite news |issn=0099-9660 |last=Fassihi |first=Farnaz |title=Fourteen of 15 Security Council Members Denounce U.S. Stance on Jerusalem |work=Wall Street Journal |accessdate=December 9, 2017 |date=December 9, 2017 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fourteen-of-15-security-council-members-denounce-u-s-stance-on-jerusalem-1512777971}}</ref> The emergency meeting was requested by Bolivia, Britain, Egypt, France, Italy, Senegal, Sweden and Uruguay.<ref name=pope /> US envoy [[Nikki Haley]] called the United Nations "one of the world's foremost centers of hostility towards Israel".<ref name=bbc/> Britain, France, Sweden, Italy and Japan were among the countries who criticized Trump's decision at the emergency meeting.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Friday |last2=December 8 |last3=Pm |first3=2017-08:15 |title=Trump's recognition of Jerusalem condemned at UN security council meeting |accessdate=December 9, 2017 |date=December 8, 2017 |url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/world/trumps-recognition-of-jerusalem-condemned-at-un-security-council-meeting-817874.html}}</ref> On 18 December, a Security Council resolution calling for the withdrawal of the recognition was vetoed by the United States, for a tally of 14–1.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Beaumont |first1=Peter |title=US outnumbered 14 to 1 as it vetoes UN vote on status of Jerusalem |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/18/us-outnumbered-14-to-1-as-it-vetoes-un-vote-on-status-of-jerusalem |accessdate=December 19, 2017 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=December 18, 2017}}</ref>
====General Assembly==== {{main|United Nations General Assembly resolution ES-10/L.22}} On 21 December 2017, the [[General Assembly]] voted for [[United Nations General Assembly resolution ES-10/L.22|Resolution ES-10/L.22]] by 128–9, with 35 abstentions and 21 absences, to condemn the US declaration on the status of Jerusalem as Israel's capital and enjoin other states to refrain from setting up diplomatic offices in Jerusalem.<ref name="nyt2017.12.21">{{cite news |url=https://nyti.ms/2p5V6aJ |title=Defying Trump, U.N. General Assembly Condemns U.S. Decree on Jerusalem |first=Rick |last=GLADSTONE |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 21, 2017 |access-date=December 22, 2017}}</ref> None of the United States' [[NATO]] [[Member states of NATO|allies]] opposed the resolution, with 25 of 29 voting for it.<ref name="country-list">{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/jerusalem-resolution-country-voted-171221180116873.html |title=UN Jerusalem resolution: How each country voted |website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref>
===Europe=== ====European Union==== The European Union's foreign policy chief [[Federica Mogherini]] emphasized that all governments of EU member states were united on the issue of Jerusalem, and reaffirmed their commitment to a Palestinian State with East Jerusalem as its capital.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Trump's Jerusalem plan revives tensions in EU diplomacy |work=Reuters |accessdate=December 9, 2017 |date=December 8, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-israel-france/u-s-has-excluded-itself-from-middle-east-peace-process-france-idUSKBN1E2102}}</ref> Mogherini said that embassies should not be moved to Jerusalem while the final status of the city was disputed. She also noted that Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem was considered a violation of international law under a [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 478|1980 United Nations Security Council resolution]].<ref name=pope/> On December 11, Mogherini said that European nations would not move their embassies to Jerusalem.<ref name=wapo/>
The EU countries of [[Austria]], [[Romania]], [[Hungary]] and the [[Czech Republic]] however defied the official EU stance and attended the official reception on the opening of the US embassy in Jerusalem.<ref>{{Cite news|title= The European Countries Expected to Rebel Against EU Policy on U.S. Embassy Move |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-the-european-countries-expected-to-defy-eu-policy-against-embassy-move-1.6076962|work=Haaretz|date=May 12, 2018}}</ref> In addition, the non-EU European countries of [[Albania]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Serbia]] and [[Ukraine]] also attended the opening.<ref>{{Cite news|title=The Countries That Attended The US Embassy Opening In Jerusalem [Infographic]|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/niallmccarthy/2018/05/15/the-countries-that-attended-the-us-embassy-opening-in-jerusalem-infographic/#635209f276cb|work=Forbes|date=May 15, 2018}}</ref>
====European political parties==== Trump's recognition of Jerusalem did receive some European support from anti-Islam politicians. Czech President [[Miloš Zeman]] said the European response was "cowardly". [[Geert Wilders]], leader of the Dutch anti-Islam party [[Party for Freedom]], said that "all freedom loving countries should move their embassy to Jerusalem" and affirmed his support for an undivided Jerusalem. [[Heinz-Christian Strache]], leader of the Austrian [[Freedom Party of Austria|Freedom Party]], similarly stated his wish to relocate the Austrian embassy to Jerusalem.<ref name=wapo2>{{Cite news |issn=0190-8286 |last=Taylor |first=Adam |title=Who supports Trump on Jerusalem? Europe’s anti-Islam politicians. |work=Washington Post |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |date=December 11, 2017 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/12/11/who-supports-trump-on-jerusalem-europes-anti-islam-politicians/}}</ref>
===Arab and Muslim world=== [[King of Saudi Arabia|King]] [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|Salman]] of [[Saudi Arabia]] said that moving the American embassy to Jerusalem would be a "flagrant provocation" to Muslims. Saudi Arabia and [[Egypt]]ian [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] both expressed similar concerns about the viability of the peace process. The [[Jordan]]ian government said Trump had violated international law and the UN charter.<ref name=bbc3/> Turkish president [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] called Israel a "terrorist state".<ref>"[https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/erdogan-israel-terrorist-state-171211085734826.html Erdogan: Israel is a terrorist state]". ''Al-Jazeera''. 11 December 2017.</ref>
On December 10, The [[Arab League]] held an emergency meeting in [[Cairo]]. After the meeting, the League's [[List of Secretaries General of the Arab League|Secretary-General]], [[Ahmed Aboul Gheit]] issued a statement saying the change in US policy was "against international law and "amounts to the legalization" of [[Israeli occupation]]. Gheit also questioned US commitment to the peace process.<ref name=league>{{Cite web |title=Arab League condemns US Jerusalem move |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |work=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/arab-league-condemns-move-dangerous-illegal-171209185754563.html}}</ref>
[[Iran]] said the U.S. announcement was in violation of international resolutions and could spark a "new intifada". [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] [[President of Lebanon|President]] [[Michel Aoun]] said the policy change would derail the peace process. [[Qatar]]'s [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Qatar)|Foreign Minister]] [[Mohammed bin Abdulrahman bin Jassim Al Thani|Mohammed Abdulrahman Al Thani]] called it "a death sentence for all who seek peace".<ref name=bbc3/> [[Indonesia]]n [[President of Indonesia|President]] [[Joko Widodo]] condemned the decision and asked the US to "reconsider the decision". [[Malaysia]]n [[Prime Minister of Malaysia|PM]] [[Najib Razak]] similarly did so, stating that "we strongly oppose any recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital for all time".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Varagur |first1=Krithika |title=Indonesia Slams American Jerusalem Plan |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/indonesia-slams-american-jerusalem-plan/4153226.html |accessdate=December 11, 2017 |work=VOA |date=December 7, 2017 |language=en}}</ref>
On December 13, 2017, during an [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]] (OIC) meeting held in [[Istanbul]], more than 50 Muslim majority countries rejected and condemned Trump's decision by passing the ''Istanbul Declaration on Freedom for al Quds'' ("Jerusalem" in Arabic) and calling for the worldwide recognition of "an independent Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its occupied capital". Palestinian President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] stated at the summit that the United States is no longer fit to participate in the Middle East peace process because of its bias and cannot be accepted as a "fair negotiator".<ref>{{cite news |last1=McKernan |first1=Bethan |title=Jerusalem latest: Palestinians will not accept any US role in peace process 'from now on', says Mahmoud Abbas |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/jjerusalem-latest-updates-mahmoud-abbas-palestinian-israel-us-middle-east-peace-process-palestine-a8107036.html |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |work=[[The Independent]] |date=December 13, 2017 |location=[[Beirut]]}}</ref><ref>[https://edition.cnn.com/2017/12/13/middleeast/oic-jerusalem-intl/index.html Muslim leaders call for recognition of East Jerusalem as Palestinian capital], ''CNN'', December 13, 2017. "Leaders from the 57-member Organisation of Islamic Cooperation recognized East Jerusalem as the occupied capital of a Palestinian state and called on the international community to do the same, according to the final communique from the group's emergency summit on Wednesday."</ref> While the summit did not produce any concrete sanctions against Israel or the United States,<ref>[http://www.france24.com/en/20171213-middle-east-muslim-leaders-urge-recognise-east-jerusalem-capital-palestine "Muslim leaders urge world to recognise East Jerusalem as capital of Palestine"], ''France 24'', December 13, 2017. "With the Islamic world itself mired in division, the summit fell well short of agreeing any concrete sanctions against Israel or the United States."</ref> ''The New York Times'' called the declaration "the strongest response yet" to Trump's decision.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/13/world/middleeast/muslims-jerusalem-palestinians.html "Muslim Leaders Declare East Jerusalem the Palestinian Capital"], ''The New York Times'', December 13, 2017. "Leaders and officials of Muslim nations declared East Jerusalem the Palestinian capital on Wednesday at a summit meeting in Istanbul, producing the strongest response yet to President Trump’s decision to recognize the city as Israel’s capital."</ref> The [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]] (OIC) urges its members to join in the Arab League boycott of Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/03/07/oic-calls-ban-israeli-products.html|title=OIC calls for ban on Israeli products}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/oicv2/subweb/cfm/41/cfm/en/docs/final/RES-IBO.pdf|title=islamic office for the boycott of israel |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005225104/http://www.oic-oci.org/oicv2/subweb/cfm/41/cfm/en/docs/final/RES-IBO.pdf|archivedate=5 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[Pope of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Pope]] [[Pope Tawadros II of Alexandria|Tawadros II]] of the [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria]] cancelled a meeting with [[Vice President of the United States|U.S. Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]] in protest of the American decision. The Coptic Church issued a statement that Trump's decision "did not take into account the feelings of millions of Arab people".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Egypt: Coptic pope cancels Pence meeting over Jerusalem |accessdate=December 11, 2017 |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/egypt-coptic-pope-cancels-pence-meeting-jerusalem-171209174617042.html}}</ref>
==== Jihadist movements ==== Jihadist movements from around the world responded with calls for armed struggle:<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |url=https://www.diis.dk/en/node/11704 |title=Trump’s Jerusalem Statements open up a new front for transnational jihadists |last=Kanwal Sheikh |first=Mona |date=December 12, 2017 |work=[[Danish Institute for International Studies]]|access-date=January 21, 2018|language=en}}</ref>[[Al-Qaeda in North Africa]] issued a statement exhorting all fighters to make the liberation of Palestine their central goal.<ref name=":0" /> [[Kashmir]]i group [[Ansar Ghazwat-ul-Hind]] called on Muslims worldwide to attack embassies of the US and Israel as well as harm the financial interests of both countries.<ref name=":0" /> The Egyptian [[Hasm Movement]] called for an uprising.<ref name=":0" /> [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] called on Muslims to support Palestinians with money and weaponry.<ref name=":0" /> The [[Taliban]] in Afghanistan called the US move "anti-Muslim bigotry".<ref name=":0" /> Somalia-based [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]] exhorted Muslims to respond with weapons.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Taliban]] and Shia extremist leaders likewise expressed their opposition.<ref name=isis>{{Cite news |issn=0362-4331 |last=Callimachi |first=Rukmini |title=Terrorist Groups Vow Bloodshed over Jerusalem Decision. ISIS? Less So. |work=The New York Times |accessdate=December 10, 2017 |date=December 8, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/08/world/middleeast/isis-jerusalem.html}}</ref> [[ISIL]] issued a response on December 8, which mainly focused on criticizing other [[jihadist]] groups and Arab leaders. They accused rival groups of politicizing the conflict to serve personal agendas and argued for the defeat of Israel's Arab neighbours who, according to ISIL, "surround [Israel] the same way a bracelet surrounds the wrist, protecting the Jews from the strikes of the mujahideen."<ref name=isis />
===China=== [[China]] has historically supported an independent Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, and said that this position remains unchanged in the aftermath of Trump's announcement.<ref name=scmp>{{Cite web |author=Liu Zhen |title=Why is China worried about Trump recognising Jerusalem as Israel’s capital? |work=South China Morning Post |accessdate=December 9, 2017 |date=December 6, 2017 |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/community/article/2123202/why-china-so-worried-about-us-recognising-jerusalem-israels}}</ref> Following the announcement, Chinese state media aired lengthy broadcasts emphasizing Palestinian opposition to it and lack of support for the move among America's European allies. Chinese news reports also stressed the risk of "instability and uncertainty" in the Middle East. Some analysts have argued that moving the embassy could push Israel to make concessions to the Palestinians in final status negotiations.<ref name=voa>{{Cite web |author=Bill Idle |title=China State Media: Sweeping Backlash to Trump's Jerusalem Decision |work=VOA |date=December 7, 2017 |accessdate=December 9, 2017 |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/china-state-media-backlash-to-trump-jerusalem-decision/4153187.html}}</ref> The Chinese embassy issued an alert to travellers regarding the increasingly complicated and intense safety conditions in Israel after the announcement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2123578/chinese-travellers-israel-put-alert-donald-trumps |author=Kinling Lo |title=Chinese visitors to Israel put on alert as Trump move boosts tensions |website=South China Morning Post |date=December 9, 2017}}</ref>
===Other===
[[Venezuela]]n [[President of Venezuela|President]] [[Nicolás Maduro]] defined the announcement on national television before travelling to [[Istanbul]] to preside a [[Non-Aligned Movement]] summit to discuss the position as "an illegal declaration, absolutely illegal, I would say irrational. A true provocation, a war declaration to the Arab people, to the Muslim people"<ref>{{cite news |title=Presidente Maduro viaja a Turquía para encuentro conjunto Mnoal con Comunidad Islámica frente a agresión de Trump contra Palestina |url=http://vtv.gob.ve/presidente-maduro-viaja-a-turquia-para-encuentro-conjunto-mnoal-con-comunidad-islamica-frente-a-agresion-de-trump-contra-palestina/ |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |agency=Venezolana de Televisión |date=December 11, 2017 |language=es-ES |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171214040937/http://vtv.gob.ve/presidente-maduro-viaja-a-turquia-para-encuentro-conjunto-mnoal-con-comunidad-islamica-frente-a-agresion-de-trump-contra-palestina/ |archive-date=December 14, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Following the announcement, right-wing Zionist organization [[Betar|World Betar]] called for international recognition of the [[Temple Mount]], [[Nablus]] and [[Hebron]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Right-wing groups call for international recognition of Temple Mount – International – Jerusalem Post |accessdate=December 18, 2017 |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Right-wing-groups-call-for-international-recognition-of-Temple-Mount-517743}}</ref>
On December 24, [[Guatemala]]n [[President of Guatemala|President]] [[Jimmy Morales]] said that his country would relocate its embassy to Jerusalem.<ref>[http://amp.timeinc.net/time/5078997/guatemala-israel-embassy-jerusalem Guatemala Says it Will Relocate its Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem], TIME, December 25, 2017</ref> The Guatemalan embassy was moved on May 16, two days after the American embassy was moved.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Heller |first1=Jeffrey |last2=Williams |first2=Dan |title=Guatemala opens embassy in Jerusalem, two days after U.S. move |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-palestinians-guatemala/guatemala-opens-embassy-in-jerusalem-two-days-after-u-s-move-idUSKCN1IH0Q7 |accessdate=25 July 2018 |date=16 May 2018 |work=Reuters}}</ref>
Several national governments responded directly to the opening of the United States Embassy in Jerusalem on May 14, 2018. [[Japan]] and [[Malaysia]] were among those expressing concern that the relocation could escalate tensions,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://japantoday.com/category/politics/Japan-expresses-concern-at-relocation-of-U.S.-Embassy-in-Israel-to-Jerusalem |title=Japan expresses concern at relocation of U.S. Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem |work=Japan Today |date=May 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nst.com.my/news/nation/2018/05/369541/malaysia-opposes-opening-us-embassy-jerusalem |title=Malaysia opposes opening of US embassy in Jerusalem |work=New Straits Times |date=May 15, 2018}}</ref> while [[Russia]] and [[Venezuela]] added that the move contradicted existing international agreements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-05/15/c_137178921.htm |title=Russia, Egypt criticize U.S. embassy relocation to Jerusalem |work=Xinhua |date=May 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Venezuela-Condemns-Israel-Attack-Against-Palestinian-People-20180514-0016.html |title=Venezuela Condemns Israel Attack Against Palestinian People |work=teleSUR |date=May 14, 2018}}</ref>
==Demonstrations and violence== Protests were held in many places across the world during the weekend of December 16 and 17. Crowds in the United States, Pakistan, Netherlands, Germany, Lebanon, Jordan, Australia, Montenegro, Iran, Morocco, Poland, United Kingdom, Greece and Indonesia gathered to protest against the decision.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.dailysabah.com/politics/2017/12/18/crowds-gather-around-world-to-protest-trumps-jerusalem-decision |title=Crowds gather around world to protest Trump's Jerusalem decision |publisher=Daily Sabah}}</ref>
===Israel and Palestine=== {{See also|2018 Gaza border protests}} [[File:The burning of the American and Israeli flags and the image of Mohammed bin Salman 02.jpg|thumb|Protest in Gaza, 9 December 2017]] In Bethlehem, religious leaders turned off Christmas tree lights outside the [[Church of the Nativity]] for three days to protest Trump's announcement.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Some tourists 'afraid to come' to Bethlehem after Trump's Jerusalem declaration: CBC's Derek Stoffel |work=CBC News |accessdate=December 15, 2017 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/trump-declaration-on-jerusalem-dampens-christmas-cheer-in-bethlehem-1.4442356}}</ref> [[Nazareth]] scaled back Christmas celebrations, cancelling singing and dancing performances in protest.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Nazareth cuts back Christmas celebrations to protest Trump's Jerusalem |work=Reuters |accessdate=December 15, 2017 |date=December 14, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-palestinians-christmas/nazareth-cuts-back-christmas-celebrations-to-protest-trumps-jerusalem-move-idUSKBN1E82AM}}</ref>
There were demonstrations throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip. {{As of|2017|12|18}} nine Palestinians had been killed in clashes.<ref>{{Cite web |title=UN Security Council to weigh resolution on Jerusalem |accessdate=December 18, 2017 |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/security-council-weigh-resolution-jerusalem-171217191838743.html}}</ref> Two protesters were shot dead when participating in a riot on the Gaza border fence on December 8. A 14-year old Palestinian boy suffered serious injuries after being hit by a [[rubber bullet]] during a protest.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Palestinian teen in coma after shot with rubber bullet |accessdate=December 19, 2017 |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/palestinian-teen-coma-shot-rubber-bullet-171217210649934.html}}</ref>
Two Hamas members were killed in Israeli airstrikes on December 9 on Hamas facilities in response to a rocket attack from Gaza. The Gaza Health Ministry reported that 15 people had been injured in a strike that hit a military facility.<ref name=Wapo>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/gaza-death-toll-in-us-embassy-violence-rises-to-4-as-israel-responds-to-rockets/2017/12/09/85755ae2-dc70-11e7-a241-0848315642d0_story.html |title=Gaza death toll in U.S. embassy violence rises to 4 as Israel responds to rockets |work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
An Israeli security guard was stabbed and critically wounded by a Palestinian near Jerusalem's central bus station on December 10.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Palestinian critically wounds security guard in Jerusalem stabbing |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |work=Jerualem Post |url=http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Stabbing-attack-at-Jerusalems-Central-Bus-Station-517600}}</ref> On December 11, the [[Israeli Defense Forces]] reported that two rockets were fired into Israel from the Gaza Strip.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/IDF-responds-to-Gaza-rockets-with-attacks-on-Hamas-517754 IDF RESPONDS TO GAZA ROCKETS WITH ATTACKS ON HAMAS TARGETS], JPost, December 11, 2017</ref> On December 12, two [[Islamic Jihad Movement in Palestine]] militants were killed in an explosion initially claimed to be a drone strike, however the IDF denied this and a later Islamic Jihad statement claimed this was an accident.<ref>[https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.828541 Gaza-based Islamic Jihad Drops Claim of Israeli Drone Strike], Haaretz, December 12, 2017</ref>
[[Israeli Air Force]] targeted three Hamas facilities on early morning of December 14 in response to rockets fired from Gaza hours earlier on the previous day with one landing in an open field of [[Eshkol Regional Council]], two shot down and one falling inside a school in Gaza's [[Beit Hanoun]], damaging a classroom. According to a Palestinian security official, the Hamas sites struck by Israeli military suffered major damage and some nearby homes suffered light damage, amidst reports of light injuries.<ref>{{Cite web |title=IAF attacks 3 Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket fire to Sderot, Eshkol |work=Ynetnews |accessdate=December 18, 2017 |url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5056572,00.html}}</ref>
On December 14, after Israel shut its border crossing with Gaza, tens of thousands of Palestinians and militants attended a Hamas rally in Gaza. The IDF said the [[Kerem Shalom crossing]] and [[Erez checkpoint]] would be closed indefinitely "in accordance with security assessments".<ref name=reuters/>
Four Palestinians were killed on December 15 during violent clashes according to Palestinian Health Ministry, including a disabled protestor in Gaza, and two others in the West Bank, including an attacker who stabbed an [[Israel Border Police|Israeli border police officer]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Four dead, hundreds wounded as protests over Jerusalem hit second week |work=CNN |accessdate=December 18, 2017 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/12/15/middleeast/jerusalem-protests-friday-intl/index.html}}</ref> Nearly 400 were injured in clashes according to the ministry.<ref>{{Cite web |title=4 Palestinians dead, hundreds injured in clashes ahead of Mike Pence's visit |work=ABC News |accessdate=December 18, 2017 |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/palestinians-killed-hundreds-injured-day-rage-pences-visit/story?id=51809870}}</ref>
Two Palestinians were killed and 120 injured in clashes on December 22, according to Palestinian Health Ministry. The IDF issued a statement which said that 2,000 protesters had faced off with the troops at the Gaza border fence, hurling rocks as well as burning tires at the troops.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Two Palestinians killed in anti-US protests after U.N. vote on Jerusalem-Gaza ministry |work=Reuters |accessdate=December 27, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-israel-palestinians/two-palestinians-killed-in-anti-us-protests-after-u-n-vote-on-jerusalem-gaza-ministry-idUSKBN1EG1GC}}</ref>
Palestinian rocket fire from Gaza in December 2017 was the most intensive series of rocket attacks on Israel since [[Operation Protective Edge]].<ref name=reutersrockets>{{Cite news |title=Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after Palestinian rocket attacks |work=Reuters |accessdate=December 25, 2017 |date=December 18, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-palestinians/israel-strikes-hamas-targets-in-gaza-after-palestinian-rocket-attacks-idUSKBN1EC0RZ}}</ref> As of January 1, 2018, Palestinian militants from Gaza had fired at least 18 rockets at Israel. Per Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu, IDF has struck 40 Hamas targets in response.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Israeli fighter jets strike Hamas facility in retaliation for Gaza rocket fire |work=i24News |accessdate=January 2, 2018 |date=January 1, 2010 |url=http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/israel/diplomacy-defense/164153-180101-rocket-fired-from-gaza-strip-hits-southern-israel}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Israel targets Hamas sites after Gaza rocket attack |work=Agence-France Presse |publisher=The National |accessdate=January 2, 2018 |date=January 1, 2010 |url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/mena/israel-targets-hamas-sites-after-gaza-rocket-attack-1.692167}}</ref> Per IDF's [[Chief of General Staff (Israel)|Chief-of-Staff]] [[Gadi Eizenkot]], 20 rockets had been fired in December 2017.<ref>{{Cite news |title=IDF Chief warns against excessive force in response to Gaza rocket fire |publisher=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=January 2, 2018 |date=January 2, 2010 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/IDF-Chief-warns-against-excessive-force-in-response-to-Gaza-rocket-fire-522632}}</ref>
Most of the rockets fired from Gaza did not land in Israeli territory, but some have landed near residential areas like [[Sderot]] and [[Ashkelon]]. Israel launched air raids on Hamas's military targets in Gaza in response and, according to ''Haaretz'', Hamas responded by arresting and probably torturing [[Salafi]] militants in the Gaza Strip to prevent further rocket fire.<ref name=nwrockets>{{Cite web |last=AM |first=Jack Moore On 12/19/17 at 4:57 |title=Hamas is arresting and torturing jihadis to prevent war with Israel |work=Newsweek |accessdate=December 25, 2017 |date=December 19, 2017 |url=http://www.newsweek.com/hamas-arresting-and-torturing-jihadis-prevent-war-israel-752108}}</ref>
Two Palestinians were killed on January 11 in clashes with Israel troops, one each in Gaza and West Bank. Israeli military said rioters had put their forces in danger in Gaza. In the other cases, it said troops fired at the main instigator after being attacked with rocks, though PA official Ghassan Daghlas however claimed it to be an unprovoked attack. This took the death toll to 16 Palestinians and one Israeli since Trump's declaration.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42654826|title=Two Palestinian teens killed in clashes with Israeli troops|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
===Muslim world=== [[File:Demonstrations and protests against United States recognition of Jerusalem in Tehran 017.jpg|thumb|Protest in [[Tehran]], Iran, 13 December 2017]] Following the announcement there were demonstrations in Iran, Jordan, Tunisia, Somalia, Yemen, Malaysia and Indonesia.<ref name=reuters/> Demonstrations and clashes continued on December 10. Demonstrators hurling rocks and bottles clashed with Lebanese security forces using tear gas and water cannons outside the American embassy near the Lebanese capital [[Beirut]].<ref name=wapo/>
Hundreds demonstrated outside US embassy in [[Amman]], demanding its closure and the expulsion of the US [[charge d'affaires]] from Jordan.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Jordanians demand closure of US embassy in Amman |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |work=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/jordanians-demand-closure-embassy-amman-171207170857947.html}}</ref> Thousands demonstrated outside the [[Embassy of the United States, Jakarta|American embassy]] in Indonesia's capital, [[Jakarta]].<ref name=bbc3/> On December 10, tens of thousands protested in the Moroccan capital of [[Rabat]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tens of thousands rally in Morocco against US Jerusalem move |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |work=Times of Israel |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/tens-of-thousands-rally-in-morocco-against-us-jerusalem-move/}}</ref>
On December 11, [[Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah]], the leader of Lebanese [[Hezbollah]], said the organization would once again focus on Israel and the Palestinian cause. He urged Arab states to abandon the peace process and called for a new Palestinian uprising.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Hezbollah's Nasrallah says group to focus on Israel |work=Reuters |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |date=December 11, 2017 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-israel-hezbollah/hezbollahs-nasrallah-says-group-to-focus-on-israel-idUSKBN1E51OV}}</ref> The same day, thousands of Hezbollah supporters demonstrated in Beirut, chanting "[[Death to America]]! Death to Israel!" while waving Palestinian and Hezbollah flags.<ref name=wapo>{{Cite news |issn=0190-8286 |last1=Loveluck |first1=Louisa |last2=Haidamous |first2=Suzan |title=Hezbollah rally attracts thousands as Trump’s Jerusalem fallout continues |work=Washington Post |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |date=December 11, 2017 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/hezbollah-rally-attracts-thousands-as-trumps-jerusalem-fallout-continues/2017/12/11/94374cf0-de93-11e7-9eb6-e3c7ecfb4638_story.html}}</ref>
Thousands of Hezbollah supporters in a Beirut rally demonstrated and chanted "Death to America!" and "Death to Israel!" A few hundred Iranian conservatives rallied against the US decision in [[Tehran]], playing music with addition of lyrics like "the US is a murderer", "Palestinian mothers are losing their children" and "Death to America".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/middle-east/162429-171211-death-to-america-israel-thousands-of-hezbollah-supporters-protest-in-beirut |title='Death to America, Israel': thousands of Hezbollah supporters protest in Beirut |publisher=ITV}}</ref>
An estimated 80,000 demonstrated against the decision in [[Jakarta]] on December 17, the 10th day of uninterrupted protests in [[Indonesia]]. Muslim clerics called for a boycott of American products. Anwar Abbas, a leading Muslim cleric of [[Indonesian Council of Ulema]], read the petition calling for the boycott.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/indonesia-clerics-want-boycott-of-us-goods-over-jerusalem-recognition/ |title=Indonesia clerics urge US boycott as 80,000 protest Jerusalem recognition |publisher=Times of Israel}}</ref>
On December 27, the Iranian government became the first Muslim nation that passed a bill recognizing Jerusalem as capital of Palestine.<ref>{{cite web |last=Moore |first=Jack |url=http://www.newsweek.com/iran-recognizes-jerusalem-capital-city-palestinians-response-trump-declaration-760356 |title=Iran Recognizes Jerusalem as Palestinian Capital City in Response to Trump Declaration |website=Newsweek |date=December 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/iran-assembly-recognizes-jerusalem-as-palestine-capital/1016460 |title=Iran assembly recognizes Jerusalem as Palestine capital |website=Anadolu Agency|access-date=January 1, 2018}}</ref>
===United States=== [[File:Jerusalem is Forever The Capital of Palestine 163829.jpg|thumb|Demonstration in [[Washington, D.C.]], United States, 16 December 2017]] Hundreds of Muslims attended the [[Jumu'ah|Friday prayers]] outside the [[White House]], in response to calls by American Muslim organizations. They wore [[Palestinian keffiyeh]] or colours of [[Palestinian flag]], with protesters holding placards denouncing Israeli presence in East Jerusalem and West Bank.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/muslims-pray-outside-white-house-to-protest-trump-jerusalem-move/ |title=Muslims pray outside White House to protest Trump Jerusalem move |publisher=Times of Israel}}</ref>
Protests were held against the decision in [[Times Square]], by hundreds of pro-Palestinian protesters who gathered on the sidewalk of the [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh Avenue]]. Some pro-Israeli counter-protestors also gathered nearby. Some pushing and shoving was reported as the two sides faced off at various points. One person was detained by the police.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Israel-Palestine-Jerusalem-Protest-Times-Square-462905703.html |title=Hundreds Protest Against US Jerusalem Move in Times Square |work=NBC New York}}</ref>
A former [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] who had been interacting with Facebook posts praising ISIL, was arrested over an ISIL-inspired terror plot on [[San Francisco]]'s [[Pier 39]] for Christmas. He had cited Trump's decision as one of the reasons behind the plot.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/12/22/ex-marine-cites-trumps-jerusalem-decision-planned-isis-attack-christmas-fbi/978164001/ |title=Ex-Marine cites Trump's Jerusalem decision in planned ISIS attack on Christmas: FBI |work=USA Today}}</ref>
===Europe=== Protesters gathered outside the [[Embassy of the United States, The Hague|US embassy]] in [[Hague]] on December 8 and chanted anti-Israeli and pro-Palestinian slogans. The protesters issued a joint press statement calling Trump's decision "against political, diplomatic and moral values". They further claimed that it was no surprise that Trump who was "known for his Islamophobia, xenophobia, racist and populist discourse and marginalization" made such a decision.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/protesters-in-europe-africa-decry-us-move-on-jerusalem/999260 |title=Protesters in Europe, Africa decry US move on Jerusalem |publisher=Anadolu Agency}}</ref>
[[File:Manifestation contre la reconnaissance de Jérusalem par les États-Unis, Paris 9 décembre 2017-2.jpg|thumb|Protest in [[Paris]], France, 9 December 2017]] More than a thousand anti-Israel and anti-American protesters protested outside the [[Brandenburg Gate]] in [[Berlin]], near the [[Embassy of the United States, Berlin|US Embassy]]. On December 10, around 2,500 demonstrators marched through [[Berlin]]'s [[Neukölln]] district and burned flags with the [[Star of David]]. Eleven people were detained and cited for criminal offences. The burning of Israeli symbols was condemned by German leaders.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.com/en/chancellor-angela-merkel-condemns-burning-of-israeli-symbols-in-berlin/a-41736113 |title=Chancellor Angela Merkel condemns burning of Israeli symbols in Berlin |work=Deustche Welle}}</ref>
Thousands protested outside the [[Embassy of the United States, London|US Embassy]] in [[London]] on the same day, with organizers claiming that there were 3,000 protesters and shouting pro-Palestine slogans. Protests were also held in cities of [[Manchester]], [[Bristol]], [[Birmingham]], [[Nottingham]], [[Dublin]], [[Belfast]] and [[Derry]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://aa.com.tr/en/europe/trumps-jerusalem-move-protested-across-uk/999335 |title=Trump's Jerusalem move protested across UK |publisher=Anadolu Agency}}</ref>
During a protest in [[Stockholm]] on December 8, an [[Flag of Israel|Israeli flag]] was set on fire.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thelocal.se/20171209/demonstrators-in-stockholm-set-fire-to-israeli-flag |title=Demonstrators in Stockholm set fire to Israeli flag |publisher=The Local}}</ref> During a protest march in [[Malmö]], [[Sveriges Radio]] reported that the demonstrators had shouted "We have announced the intifada from Malmö. We want our freedom back, and we will shoot the Jews."<ref name="ShootTheJews">{{cite news |title=Anti-Semitic chants heard at Malmö demonstration |url=https://www.thelocal.se/20171209/anti-semitic-chants-reported-at-malm-demonstration |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |publisher=The Local |date=December 9, 2017}}</ref><ref name=IntifadaMalmo>{{cite news |title=Second Jewish building in Sweden attacked with firebombs |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/second-jewish-building-in-sweden-attacked-in-attempted-firebombing/ |accessdate=December 12, 2017 |publisher=Times of Israel |date=December 12, 2017}}</ref>
On December 9, a dozen men hurled [[Molotov cocktail]]s at the [[Gothenburg Synagogue]]. No injuries were reported, and those inside the building hid in the basement. The incident followed a pro-Palestinian protest.<ref>[https://www.haaretz.com/world-news/europe/1.827932 Firebombs Hurled at Synagogue in Sweden Following Protests Against Jerusalem], Haaretz, December 10, 2017</ref> Three people were later arrested over the attack. [[Prime Minister of Sweden|Prime Minister]] [[Stefan Löfven]] and other top politicians condemned the attack.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/3-people-arrested-in-fire-bomb-attack-on-swedish-synagogue/2017/12/10/15d4b466-dd8e-11e7-b2e9-8c636f076c76_story.html |title=3 people arrested in firebomb attack on Swedish synagogue |publisher=The Washington Post}}</ref> On December 11, a chapel of a Jewish cemetery in [[Malmö]] was the target of an attempted arson attack.<ref name=IntifadaMalmo/><ref>[https://www.jta.org/2017/12/11/news-opinion/world/after-second-incident-swedish-anti-semitism-watchdog-warns-of-wave-of-attacks After second incident, Swedish anti-Semitism watchdog warns of wave of attacks], JTA, December 11, 2017</ref> Anti-Semitic chants including "Death to Israel" and "Slaughter the Jews" were also heard during protests in Berlin, Gothenburg and Vienna.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/angela-merkel-condemns-burning-of-israeli-flags-in-berlin-1.3323573 |title=Angela Merkel condemns burning of Israeli flags in Berlin |publisher=The Irish Times}}</ref>
===Other nations=== Two Danish journalists of the [[National Geographic (U.S. TV channel)|National Geographic channel]] were injured in [[Libreville]] on 16 December by an Islamist carrying a knife and crying "[[Allahu Akbar]]", according to [[Gabon]]'s Defense Minister Etienne Kabinda Makaga. The attacker, who was arrested, told the police that he was carrying out a revenge attack against the United States over the recognition of Jerusalem as Israeli capital.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gabon-attack/two-danish-journalists-wounded-in-islamist-knife-attack-in-gabon-idUSKBN1EB0B2 |title=Two Danish journalists wounded in Islamist knife attack in Gabon |publisher=Reuters}}</ref>
==Relocation of the Embassy to Jerusalem== [[File:Embassy Dedication Ceremony (41431876594).jpg|thumb|Dedication ceremony in Jerusalem, Israel, 14 May 2018]] In February 2018, the U.S. government made it known that it would open its embassy in the building of the U.S. consulate's compound in Jerusalem's southern neighbourhood of [[Arnona]] in May that year, thereby bringing president Donald Trump's plan to do so forward by about a year. The move was scheduled to coincide with the 70th anniversary of the establishment of the State of Israel.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/23/us-brings-forward-jerusalem-embassy-opening-israel-to-may US brings forward Jerusalem embassy opening to May: Ceremony timed to coincide with 70th anniversary of Israel’s independence] The Guardian, 23 February 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.timesofisrael.com/us-to-move-embassy-to-jerusalem-on-may-14-day-of-independence-declaration/ US Embassy in Jerusalem to open in May — in time for Israel’s 70th anniversary] The Times of Israel, 23 February 2018.</ref>
The U.S. delegation attending the embassy dedication ceremony on 14 May 2018 included the Trump administration's officials [[Steven Mnuchin]], [[Ivanka Trump]], and [[Jared Kushner]] as well as [[Robert Jeffress]] and [[John Hagee]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/14/world/middleeast/robert-jeffress-embassy-jerusalem-us.html Robert Jeffress, Pastor Who Said Jews Are Going to Hell, Led Prayer at Jerusalem Embassy] The New York Times, 14 May 2018.</ref>
Congressmen from both parties praised the move; [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Senate Minority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] said the move was "long overdue".<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Davis| first = Julie Hirschfeld| title = Jerusalem Embassy Is a Victory for Trump, and a Complication for Middle East Peace| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 2018-05-15| date = 2018-05-15| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/14/us/politics/trump-jerusalem-embassy-middle-east-peace.html}}</ref> [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Senators [[Lindsey Graham]] and [[Ted Cruz]] traveled to Jerusalem to attend the U.S. Embassy opening.<ref>"[https://www.timesofisrael.com/chuck-schumer-applauds-trump-for-opening-jerusalem-embassy/ Chuck Schumer ‘applauds’ Trump for opening Jerusalem embassy]". ''The Times of Israel.'' 14 May 2018.</ref> The relocation happened during an [[2018 Gaza border protests#14 May|escalation of the Gaza border protests]] and caused international condemnation.<ref name="indepspecial">[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/gaza-protests-latest-palestinians-killed-border-embassy-jerusalem-trump-a8351761.html In Jerusalem, an embassy opens. In Gaza, at least 58 die on bloodiest day in years: A special dispatch that contrasts violent scenes on the Israeli-Gaza border with celebrations marking opening of the US embassy in Jerusalem] The Independent, 14 May 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/05/world-leaders-react-embassy-relocation-jerusalem-180514142652207.html World leaders react to US embassy relocation to Jerusalem] Aljazeera, 14 May 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/05/14/palestinians-killed-israeli-troops-gaza-protests-ahead-us-embassy/ At least fifty-five Palestinians killed by Israeli troops in Gaza protests as US opens Jerusalem embassy] The Telegraph, 14 May 2018.</ref>

{{for|the alternate spelling of the Christmas holiday|Xmas}} {{infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = X-Mas Festival | image = | location = [[Europe]] | years_active= 1999-2005 | dates = December | genre = [[heavy metal music|Heavy metal]] }}
'''X-Mas Festival''' was a [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] [[festival]]/[[Concert tour|tour]] held annually in [[Europe]] from 1999 to 2005. It was organized by the [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[booking agency]] [[Metallysee]]. The 2006 and 2007 editions have been cancelled, and the future of the festival is in doubt. Metallysee plans to launch a new tour in January 2008 under the name [[Black Winter Festival]].<ref>[http://www.metallysee.com/news.htm Metallysee news] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071119173109/http://www.metallysee.com/news.htm |date=November 19, 2007 }}</ref>
==History== The 2006 edition was cancelled after [[Unleashed (band)|Unleashed]], [[Six Feet Under (band)|Six Feet Under]], [[God Dethroned]], [[Cataract (band)|Cataract]] and soon later [[Krisiun]] decided to pull out, [[Trail of Tears (band)|Trail of Tears]] disbanded and [[Soilwork]] refused to headline the tour. The last announced lineup featured [[Gorefest]], [[Belphegor (band)|Belphegor]], [[Prostitute Disfigurement]], [[Madder Mortem]], [[SkyForger]] and [[Darzamat]]. The owner of the agency blamed one of his employees for the cancellation, and this person left the company.<ref>[http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=72989 "Belgian booking agency apologizes for string of European tour cancellations"], [[Blabbermouth.net]], May 21, 2007</ref> Despite this, the 2007 edition was also called off without a reason. The lineup should have featured [[Mayhem (band)|Mayhem]], [[Samael (band)|Samael]], [[Malevolent Creation]], [[Onslaught (band)|Onslaught]], [[Wykked Wytch]], [[Blood Red Throne]] and [[Innerfire]]. The Onslaught website claims that the festival has been postponed, and will be held in January 2008 under the name [[Black Winter Festival]].<ref>[http://www.onslaughtfromhell.com/news.html Onslaught news]</ref>
